interviewee: **Interviewee**: It did not meet our needs because we were not able to cook some of the things.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you were using both firewood and the digester?
interviewee: \[response inaudible\]

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, that was tough. What were the challenges?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The challenge was that sometimes when we put the pot on the stove; it could not even heat up. Therefore, we used to go around searching for firewood so that we could continue cooking. Sometimes, around 11AM we could see the bag was full, but no gas was coming at the stove despite feeding it with manure and loads of water. Sometimes, it would produce very little gas would make the food became uncooked. So, they fire could come, but it was very weak just like of a candle light.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So what were you doing to make the gas strong again?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: On some particular day, you would just put a pot and you would get strong fire. So, it depend on what particular day it was. So, yeah, sometimes we could cook nsima on it. However, sometime even if we fed it and the bag was full, it could not just produce gas.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How long did it work before it stopped working?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Two years.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So in two year you were just using it in the afternoon? And, sometimes you could not even cook on it because there was no gas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Was there a day you used it in the morning, in the afternoon, and in the evening?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No. That's was just not possible. It was starting to work after the sun was out around 10:00 and 11:00 in the morning.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What days were you able to cook? Was it random or there was something about those days?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was just random. Sometimes, it would work for a straight one week without problem \[just in the afternoon\].

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So general in the 2 years, most times the gas was coming at the stove, it is just that some days the fire was very, very weak; and on some days, and sometimes the fire was good?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Spot on!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: But, after 2 years, that is when it stopped producing gas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, it stopped producing fire completely.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: When it was not working properly like the times it was producing little gas did you call the project implementers?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We reported the issue to the extension worker and he told us that he would inform the installers. But, they never came up to the point it completely failed.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you follow up again?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why did you not keep on follow up?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Aah, we thought the message was clear, and you cannot go to their office all the time because they were occupied with other work as well.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What do you think about this kind of information and do you think it would have helped you?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The information would have helped us because you could just have been referring to it whenever we had a problem to fix it. And maybe if we had that information it could have been working even today.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why are you so confident?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Because we were very committed to feed it, and our feeding was perfect. And, when we had no cow manure, we were going to our uncle, that house there, to get feedstock to feed it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How do you describe the current state of digested today?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It is no longer in existence. It is not there.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did it reach this stage?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The way it was behaving, it was as if we were working for nothing; also, the bag got a hole. Then after that, it got buried in the ground. So the time it was producing very little gas it had no hole anyway?

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did it get punctured? And, what kind of hole was it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The bag got puncture on its own underneath while it was in the hole. So, when we were feeding it the bag was not getting full.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you know that it had punctured?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was because the bag could not get full even after feeding. Previously, we wanted to find out how much gas was in the bag, we used to ask the children to jump on the bag. So that time when the children jumped on it, they stopped bouncing and they were going down with it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Who told you that children should be stepping on it to check if there was gas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They did not tell us but we started doing that ourselves to know if there was gas in the bag or not.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) why do you think it got punctured? Or, what specifically punctured it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Mmh, we do not know.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You cannot think of anything?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We cannot.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How to meet your energy needs now that it is not working?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We use the firewood and charcoal. Nowadays, we eat very late because it takes us time to find firewood; we eat very late these days.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laugh) is there anything wrong with eating late?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: There is problem, because when we go to farm in the morning we go with empty stomachs, so we expect that we should eat right after returning -- so we see that as a problem.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I am having lunch here today, what time are we eating?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We have already eaten.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You are telling me you eat late, but this is 1:30 PM and you have already eaten.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (laughs) we didn't go to the farm today.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many times do you eat in a day?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We eat twice.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How do you manage the feedstock now that it is not working?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It's in the cow house now waiting to be taken to the farm.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: We are going towards the end of the interview, how much did the reactor cost?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We don't know how much it cost, but it must be a lot. And, on our side, we lost a lot of money too in terms of paying the people who dug it, and also for building a wall around it. On top of that, we built the kitchen to block the wind from the stove.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Who paid for the kitchen?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was them.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you contribute anything any kind?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The cow manure was ours.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What else, bricks?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The bricks were ours.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much money did you spend on that?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was K6000.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did it save you money the time it was working?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah... It helped us to save the money that we were spending on charcoal.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, you reduced buying charcoal?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, we stopped completely. We were using firewood and biogas only; when it stopped, that's when we started using charcoal. And, because we want to cook fast, we put one pot on firewood for side dish, and another pot on charcoal... So we started using charcoal when it failed.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You said you were only using it in the afternoon, so how were you cooking that time?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were using firewood when biogas was not working.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So your primary source of energy is firewood?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, that time you were saving three bags of charcoal?
interviewee: \[response inaudible\]

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much was a bag of charcoal that time?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was K4500.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much is it now?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It's K6000 or K7000

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, things are expensive now, uh. What was the biggest difference in your life that time it was working?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: This were a bit easy that time; and our school going kids were finding food ready after knocking off from school. It was like after knocking off at 12 noon they would find food. But now it's tough. And, one thing about the digester is that we knew its cooking time, so we were forced to cook within that particular time, and that\`s why the children always found food ready.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, I see. We are remaining with two questions, what is your opinion of biogas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: If you could bring another biogas, then you should take us to training so that we should learn about it. And, the training should focus on how to fix it, and even how to make it work in the evening. I think that way it can work.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What are its props and cons?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The good thing about it is that you eat on time. The other thing was that it was a new thing in this community. So, to have it was special because we felt that we were above everyone. And, it made this house like a learning center, because many people were coming to learn about it, and they admired it. The main challenge though is the feedstock, sometimes we had to get a bucket or too from our uncle.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What is the future of biogas in Malawi? Is the future bright or groom?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The future is bright, like I said many people were coming to see it, and they showed interest.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: We are in 2022, you had it in 2016-17, and you are telling me that people wanted it but no one today has it, even you yourself don't have it. So, how is the future bright?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They didn't tell us that after it has stopped working, we could buy it in the shops, or what can we do after. Also, we didn't go for training, so we can't advocate someone to buy it because we may fail to help him or her if it fails.... So, it's hard.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, for it to have a future there must be training?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, because after that that's when you can be telling people to do this and that, and only them you can spark the interest in people. People were asking a lot of questions but we were failing to answer, so how could we tell them to buy it or how could they have been convinced by us when we seemed not to understand it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What questions were you receiving?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: People were asking us how we got it; and what they can do to get it; and where to get it -- lots of questions. But we had no responses to these questions. We were just telling them that they told us to feed it with cow manure (Laughs). And then we would take them to the stove to show them the gas.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) if you would have design your on the waste or energy intervention, what could you have chosen instead?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We are not educated so we don't know which technologies we can use or are available... we only saw them bring this technology and we accepted it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (Laughs) you don't electricity?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We want that.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why didn't you tell me that?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (laughs) yeah, electricity can help a lot too.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: That was my last question. Thanks for the interview.
interviewee: NA

interviewer: Where did this digester originate from?
interviewee: It came with \[name redacted\], the agriculture extension worker -- When he came, he identified a place and told us to dig a hole for the digester to be placed. Simply put it came with me our extension worker, \[name redacted\].

interviewer: When was this?
interviewee: It has been three years. It was 2018, if not 2017.

interviewer: Who built it?
interviewee: Four people built it; they line the digester with a brick wall; prepared the feedstock to start it up, and of course, draw water to feed it and other things.

interviewer: Who were these four people?
interviewee: It was two us, and two other people; we hired them to assist us with the work.

interviewer: How much did you pay them?
interviewee: We paid them K5000.

interviewer: How long did it take to build the digester?
interviewee: Firstly, they told us to dig a hole, and then build a brick wall around it. Then, they told us to wait for a day to allow the brick wall to dry. The following day, they came and installed the digester bag. They also made a structure for the stove on the same day. All this took three days.

interviewer: I take it that it was not just the four of you, who were involved in the building process. I believe the four of you worked with the people who brought the digester. How many people from the installation of company were involved in the construction or installation process?
interviewee: There was \[name redacted\] and two other extension workers of which one was short and dark in complexion. On top of this, there were two other people. They were not from this community nor extension workers.

interviewer: Okay**,** what was your role?
interviewee: Our main role was to find people to make a hole for the digester bag and to prepare feedstock to start it up. Besides this, we were also responsible for sourcing bricks for making a brick wall around the hole. Therefore, we went around the community to find a broken bricks for the wall. Nowadays, you cannot do that.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: People do sell broken bricks these days. It is just not possible to find broken bricks going free of charge like in the past

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What has changed really?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Everything is about money now. In the past, we could go to a brick clamp or a house construction, and get broken bricks free and build a pit latrine. Now people ask for money even for broken bricks.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, I see. How were you selected as a beneficiary?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was \[name redacted\], the extension worker, who identify us. In this community only two people were given the digester, it \[name redacted\] and I.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why do you think you were chosen? I mean, you are too many people in this community, why you?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (Laughs) they chose us because we had cows, I think. There was a cow house there. That is my mother.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Hello, mom. Yeah, we are doing a research about biogas. I came in June in preparation of this visit. I hope you were told. Right now, we are just chatting about your experiences with the digester.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, they give me this digester. However, after commissioning, I could only cook porridge and vegetables. After a little time, it stopped producing gas; it was on and off.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, then you can join us. I understand it has been many years, so it would be wonderful if you can join us and remind each other some of the things. I was asking my sister here why they chose you to be a beneficiary, and she told me it is because that time you had cows...
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, and that is true. It was because of the cows.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many cows did you have?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We had 10 cows, but I was not the sole owner.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: what do you mean?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Out of the 10 Cowboys, four were mine. The rest of the cows where brought by other people so that I could keep for them.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why asking you to keep for them?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They so that it was secure for them to keep the cows here; they had challenges keeping the cow.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many people?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Two people

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, did you know anything about biogas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, I did not.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Sister did you know anything about biogas?
interviewee: **Interviewee#2**: No

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So it was a new thing for both of you?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was a new thing to many; it was not only us.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: \[no question\]
interviewee: **Interviewee#2**: and people were coming to see it. I used to show them how to feed it and how the bag gets full after feeding. Moreover, then I would show them how to operate it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh nice, did you show them how to cook nsima on biogas and all that?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Mmh, no nsima. The firewood was not staying long, by now it could have stopped \[referencing the time taken for the interview (about 25 minutes)\].

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, what were your expectations?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I thought I was very lucky. In this community, only two of us benefited. So, we accepted the digester because we thought we were lucky to have it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You thought you had hit a jackpot.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (laughs) Yeah, so we thought I would use it for cooking. So, we expected to stop going around searching for firewood. We expected to have rest; we expected to take a break from sourcing firewood.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where do you get firewood?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: At the mountains.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How far?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We leave in the morning and return after 12 or 1 PM.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What time exactly in the morning?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We leave around 5 am

interviewer: **Interviewer**: eh, eh, it\`s far.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, is very far. The mountain is far from here.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I thought you have trees around, why do you not just you use the trees from within?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The mango trees? No! The trees give us fruits, my son

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I understand it is not easy to get wood from mountains. You think of forest officers and everything. How is it like that side?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, it is just like woodland. Plus, we have relatives who own land around, so we ask and get firewood from them.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, so when \[name redacted\] and his team came, what did they say you should expect from with the digester? What did they say about the digester?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They build the digester here so that I could use it for cooking -- And when things were working I reported to \[name redacted\]. He came and saw that it was not producing enough; and, he told us that the digester was not producing gas as it was supposed to.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: \[no question\]
interviewee: **Interviewee#2**: So, when he came that time and saw it producing little gas, we expected him to bring a new digester that we could use without problems.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, did they tell you that it could use it for lighting?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They did not -- This one was only meant for cooking.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What type of training did you receive from the installers?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They simply told me to feed it with six bags of cow manure. They said after feeding it, I will be able to know that it was good by just looking at how the bag was inflated. And, when the bag was full, they came and they showed me how to switch it on.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did they tell you about maintenance?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What did they tell you to do when the bag was not getting full?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They told us to feed it with food leftovers and everything decomposes, and we were doing just that.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How prepared to run or operate the digester did you feel were?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Very much so. And, we loved the digester, and we embraced it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you felt what they told you was enough to operate it and maintain it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: yeah, that is what we were told, and we thought it was fine.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you meet your energy needs before the intervention? Did you use anything apart from firewood?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Like I said, we get wood from the mountains. So, when this came we are so happy, and thought it was our time to stop going to the mountains to look forward.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Now, if you want to cook, do you still go there?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, we still go there.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: how is the situation there? Is firewood not depleting?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: it is depleting... Its depleted because of people who go there to cut trees to make charcoal.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Then, how are you going to survive?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We do not know -- You should help us with alternatives.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laugh) oh
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (Laughs) and as you can see, I am getting old. The last time they cheated to me about using it for cooking, so you need to support me on finding a solution to cooking.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Let us assume, I am not there, how are you going to survive?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (Laughs) you do not have to disappear. Do not shun us (laughs)! But, if worse come to worse, we will leave with no option, but on depend on maize stalk. But we cannot and do not rely on that, because it is somewhat seasonal.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You said you had 10 cows; four were yours and six were from other people. How many do you have now?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We do not have any. Thieves stole from us.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, true?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, you can even ask the kids. We tried everything to get it back, but couldn\'t.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: When was this?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Last year. They only left us with one cow.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: In most cases, people go to tradition witchdoctors after such an event, especially in cow farming. What did you do?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Eh, we tried literally everything -- And it is not only us, many people from the village were robbed that day. I am sure they used strong juju \[black magic\], because that cannot just happen. And, when we went to witch doctors nothing happened, so I am sure they used strong juju.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Sorry for your loss. How did you manage the feedstock before the intervention?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We simply gathered and processed the manure, and later use it as manure in our fields. That time I was able to gather 5 bags (50 kg) of manure, but if a man was doing that, he could have gathering more. So, from that I was able to harvest16 bags (50 kg) of manure.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh impressive, how much manure did you start it up with?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We started with six or seven buckets (20 kg) of cow manure.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where did you get the manure?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I got it from my cow house.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much water did add?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We started it with 5 buckets of (20 liters) of water. And, it was lot of work to prepare the feedstock at the first time. But, afterwards it was simple because we were feeding it a bucket or so.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where did you get the water?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: From a borehole.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How far is it from here?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: So far is there?

interviewer: **Interviewer**: That is 400 or 500 meters away. How long did it take to start up?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It took one week.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did it start after commissioning?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: After feeding it with the initial feedstock, we waited for a week for it to start up. During that week, the bag was getting bigger and bigger each day. On the 7^th^ day, it got full. Unfortunately, the gas we got was not strong enough to cook nsima. Like I said, I was only using it for cooking vegetables and porridge or light side dishes \[15 -- 30 minutes\]. And it was always on and off; sometimes we could switch it on and got little gas; sometimes we did not get gas at all.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Specifically, how much cooking time did you get when it worked? Were you able to cook breakfast lunch and supper?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, as I said, we could not cook on nsima on it. We only used it for cooking porridge and vegetables.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, that is like 15 or so minutes of gas. Apart from cooking, did you use it for any other purpose?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, it was only for cooking.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many people used it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were 3 people.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were the operation requirements?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: For it to function, it needed to be fed with cow manure. They also told us to feed it with food leftovers.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How often did you feed the digester?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Once we saw that the bag was not full.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you were basically waiting on it to shrink to feed?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, once we saw that the bag was not going to get full, that\'s when we were feeding it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why didn't you feed it on a daily basis?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I do not know if it was laziness, but in most cases it was taking as three or four days to feed it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did the installers tell you how you were supposed to feed it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They did

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What did they say?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They told us to feed it with cow manure, but my thinking was it was not going to take time provided again or to use it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you prepare the feedstock?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were simply putting the manure in a bucket, add water, and mix with a wooden stir or stick. After mixing, we were pouring the mixer into the digester bag.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Many people have told me that they were advised to use hand instead of stir to have good slurry. What is your take?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were also getting good slurry using a stick because some of the manure was fresh.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You were also using dry manure?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were just collecting manure, so some of the manure was dry.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Were you pre-treating the feedstock? For example, did you soak the manure for a certain time before feeding it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, we were just mixing the manure after collecting it from the cow house.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What was ratio of your feedstock? I mean, how much water were you adding to the manure?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Mostly, I was feeding it with seven buckets (20 liters) cow manure, and I was adding seven buckets (20 liters) of water.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: OK, So, it was a 1:1 ratio. Who was responsible for feeding it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I was responsible

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What about my sister here?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: She was also supporting me

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How would you describe the task of feeding it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It\'s hard work. But, it's worth it, if it can work without issues.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: In your case, was it worth it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The fact that we did not use it for cooking nsima, it's hard to say it was worth it. You know in Malawi, eating is synonym to nsima (laughs). Nsima is everything!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you get fertilizer?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The installer told us that after feeding it for some time, it produces digestate that can be used as fertilizer. They also told us that what remain I the bag is fertilizer, so when it stopped we got and used it as fertilizer.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What was your outlet like?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We dug a hole onto which the digester was flowing in. They told us that we could use the digester as fertilizer, so we used to collect the digestate and apply it in our farms.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What was your take on the digestate? How did you compare it with inorganic fertilizer or the fertilizer you where getting from you manure?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We don't use inorganic fertilizer. But, when we used the digestate, it worked.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why don't you use in organic fertilizer?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We can\'t afford it - we don\'t have money to buy inorganic fertilizer.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Now that you have only one cow. What will you do?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: My sister has a cow house, so I have moved the remaining cow to her place.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you will get manure from her?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I will probably get manure from her.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You sound so unsure, I mean, what is the plan now regarding fertilizer now that you don't cows?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I will grow maize without any fertilizer.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Is it possible in Malawi to grow maize without fertilizer?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, I do grow maize without fertilizer. What can I do when I don't have the money?

interviewer: **Interviewer**: And you do harvest enough?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Of course, we do get low yield. But, what can we do, my son?

interviewer: **Interviewer**: yeah, I see it's tough. What were the maintenance requirements?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The only told us to feed it, and after that feeding it for a long time, it was going to start producing manure -- So that was what I was doing.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did they tell you anything about how to fix or repair it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did it meet your needs?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Maybe, if it was installed properly, it would have met our needs. And, I think, had it worked as I expected, I would have the happiest person because I expected a lot; I expected it to take away all my cooking problems... I don't know if it was your team or not, who came to ask me similar questions and gave me three bundles of wood at the end.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: No, it wasn\`t us. It seems it did not meet your needs, because you could not cook nsima and the like, right?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, I couldn't cook in nsima; if I could have cooked nsima on it, it would have been just one portion of nsima; I couldn't cook nsima for two people.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What challenges were there?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It didn't work us one would do expect. I expected that I could use it for cooking but I never did.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Could you describe the fire you were getting?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was produce very little fire green in color. And, it was only producing fire for a very short time, after a short time it was going off completely.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much time was it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Just enough to cook porridge. After cooking porridge, it could not produce fire.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Maybe 15 - 30 minutes?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How long did it work before it stopped?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It worked for two or three months, after that it stopped completely. Then, I reported to \[name redacted\], the extension worker, who told me to wait, and hope that the installers would come again.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you only used it for two months.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, it worked for three months. After that, it stopped completely. I don't know how the other beneficiaries fared though.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Most of them they did fare like yours; two months, one month, one week, but there is one who used it for two years.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Two years? \[Surprised\]

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Yeah, they told me it was only working around lunchtime though.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, that\'s how it was for all of us. And, when we met and asked each other, the stories were kind of the same.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You are saying after it failed you reported to \[name redacted\], is there anything else you did before you reported to \[name redacted\]? Did you try to fix it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, we just reported to \[name redacted\]. When he came, he just moved around the bag. Then, he said we should just hope that the installers would one day come again.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How long did it take him to come after you report?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: He was quick. He came on the same day. And, when we met him on the road he would tell me not to worry, and that the installers would come one day.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: We are going towards the end of the interview. We have done 80% of the interview. Moving on, have you ever seen something like this \[intervention sheet\]?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What do you think of this type of information, and do you think it would have helped you?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, it would have helped.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We would have learned more about the digester from that information.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why would that be important?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It would have helped. This information is like you have been given a phone number. If you are given a phone number and you have a problem, you look for the contact and then make a call. In the same manner, if there was a problem, we could have been going to this information and act accordingly.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, today is 26 July. How do you describe the state your digester today?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Of all the things that I was given I'm only remaining with the pipes. As you can see, we have children running around so they misplaced everything. Thus, most of the things were damaged or lost because of them. Everything is lost except for the pipes and its inside. Also, we do have the bag, it\`s there on the roof structure. \[Interrupted by another woman\]

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Yeah, you are telling me it's dead; all the things are lost except for the pipes and the digester bag, which is now a roof sheet.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah. It's dead. We only have the pipes and digester bag.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, why do you think it failed?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It's because of how it worked after it was commissioned. I reported to \[name redacted\] how it was working, but nothing happened. So, it was more like throwing away a piece of cloth on the ground and leaving it there. What happens? You find it eaten and damaged by the termites.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you are saying it reached this state because it never really got off well and the installers did not follow-up?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yep, it is because of the installers. They left us in the middle of the journey; they did not come to service it when it malfunctioned. But, let me not pull them down, I might be wrong.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, (laughs) why? You think you would not be fair to them?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They gave us the digester, which is kindness on its own and then told us to feed it, so maybe we did not feed it right.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why do you say that? And, how were you feeding it again?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Because it is the only reason, I can think of as a reason that made it fail. As far as feeding it, I was feeding it with 6 buckets of manure and 5 buckets of water every three or four days.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: We are remaining with 5 questions or so. How much did the reactor cost?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Mmh, I cannot know. I can only remember that a lot of people we are coming in big cars -- and we simply accepted it and did not follow the other things.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you contribute anything in kind?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No. Nothing!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You told me bricks.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Oh, yeah, bricks, and the people I paid to build the wall around it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Apart from that, what else?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: That is all.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many people were there involved in digging?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was my two boys and me.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many did masonry work?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was two, and it took them two days.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did it help you to save money?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Approximately, how much do you feel you saved?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I saved maybe K3000... I sell traditional whisky, so that's my source of income. So, the money I saved came from that business (laughs).

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why didn't you use the digester for Kachasu (African traditional whisky) brewing?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, That was for cooking nsima and side dish. And, that's where we could have benefited more. That's for cooking nsima and not Kachasu.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why do you say that?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Aah no, my brother, Kachasu is not easy to cook; Kachasu needs a lot of energy to boil.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Maybe you are underestimating the digester. It produces strong flames.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: But, not to the point of cooking hard meals, and certainly not Kachasu. Kachasu requires a lot of fire. We use two bundles of firewood to make Kachasu. So, if you tell me that the digester can boil water for bathing, I would agree, but not Kachasu.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (Laughs) what was the biggest difference in your life when it was working?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The biggest change was that I was cooking without bothering about igniting fire. I was cooking like I was in town or somewhere, and I loved it. So, that was the biggest difference.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You wish to live in town?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (Laughs) who doesn't want to live in town. Is there a person who doesn't want good things (laughs)? That time it was like the town came to our village. Nankumba was like a town to us that time, for sure.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What is your opinion of biogas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Biogas is good and it is my prayer that one day I will have it again. Moreover, I would like to be trained properly afterwards, so that I could manage it properly -- that's all I want. I still think about it, and I wonder how we missed that opportunity, and how it didn't work. Nevertheless, throughout this time, \[name redacted\] has always been encouraging me; he comes repeatedly, and he is always telling me not to lose hope because the installer one day would come.

interviewer: ## **Interviewer**: What is the future of biogas in Malawi? Is the future bright or dim? Where do you see it five years?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, it has a bright future. I didn't know about it, but some people gave me. We have people who want others to have it, so it will spread in the end.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You were given one, and someone in this village was given one. But, not even one is working today. Do you think it's manageable?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It would be improper for me to say it can\'t work because I didn't stay with it for long. So, I don't really know it well, and I also don't know what went wrong. Maybe, I did something wrong on it; maybe they didn't install it properly. So, I can't say it\`s unmanageable.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Last question, if you could have designed your own waste or energy intervention, what would you have chosen instead?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I would chose the same if I had cows. But now I don't have cow I can't manage it. Maybe I can be sourcing it from other people, but like I have said everything is about money these day. Imagine if people would sell broken bricks, what more manure. So, if there can be a technology that can be used without using money regularly I would go for that.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, do you have any last words?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Biogas is a good thing to have. And I'm a very lucky person to have been given one. I never expected it come to me. In this village, we are too many, and to be a beneficiary is luck. The world is changing; the world is not like it was some years back, so we need this kind of thing to replace traditional methods of cooking. -- Yeah, I was excited that I got a Biogas.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Thanks for the interview.
interviewee: NA

interviewer: Where did this digester originate from?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I have forgotten.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: During you encounter with them, Where did they say the digester originate from?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I think they said India, if not China. It was China, I guess.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Who funded it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I think it was from China. Or, maybe some non-governmental organization.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Who built it and when was it built?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I have forgotten the date!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Or just the year.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I still need to be reminded.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Who was the president back then? Was it Bingu? Was it Peter? Or, Joyce? \[list of former presidents\]
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I think it was 2017.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I think you are right. I think it was 2016 or 2017.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: \[no response\]

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How long does it take to build?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Digging and lining the hole took a day. I did that together with my family.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many were you that time?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I had five children. I total we were seven including my husband. My children were helping my husband by collecting water while he was building the wall around it. So, that was how it was.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Is your husband a builder by profession?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes, he is.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Apart from that, was there anything else you did?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Before they came to install it that was what we did.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: On the day of installation, what did you do?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: On the day of installation, we collected cow manure and prepared the feedstock -- and it was hard work.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many bags of cow manure and water did you work with that day?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I have forgotten how much cow manure we used. Oh, it\`s been a long. But, it was a lot of cow manure. I think it was 6 bags of cow manure and 6 drums of water.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How were you as selected as a beneficiary?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We got it because my husband was mostly working with the agriculture department on various programs. For example, he was heavily involved in irrigation, so he was always in touch with the agriculture department. So, when the digester came through the agriculture department he was requested to be a beneficiary.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So beyond that why were you chosen as beneficiaries?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Our hard work! So, they knew we would embrace the project, and do the work as required.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Some say were chosen because we had cows. Did you have cows?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, we did not have cows.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, where were you getting cow manure?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were asking from the people who had cows.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How was it like going to people's houses to ask for cow manure for the digester?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was not hard because many people have a lot of cows here. And, people who have cows like it because it more like you are doing a service of removing cow manure from their cow house.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you know anything about biogas before?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We learnt about biogas when the installers came and explained about biogas. So, we were like, "oh okay, is it possible?" and they were like "yes". So, we were like bring it on.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What did they say about biogas that time?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: When they came, they told us that we would be able to cook using cow manure without any issues.....They said that cow manure would be our new firewood. They also mentioned that we would start using cow manure for cooking and eventually we would stop going to the forest to look for firewood.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, how was the selection process like?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I think there was something the project implementers especially the agriculture office looked in people. Therefore, I feel like they weighed the people to see who was capable to manage it. I do not think were just giving the digesters to any person. Moreover, the digesters came as part of a pilot project to see if they could work, so I do not think they could just give to any person.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Thanks for the puffs. Let us eat Ma'am. What were your expectations?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Thanks for the puffs. We expected to stop going around searching for firewood for cooking. So, we were so happy about it, and embraced the digesters wholeheartedly.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, basically, you expected to cook without firewood?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Aside from that, what else did you expect?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were just happy with the idea of cooking without going to the forest to look for firewood.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you think about the prospect of using it as a source of fertilizer?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes, we did. We were getting the slurry, which was coming out of the digester to the farm. So, it was helping us in terms of agriculture. I had a garden close to the digester, which I was using the digestate as fertilizer. Some people were not using the digestate, but some we were not.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why were some not using the digestate?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Some did not dig a hole, but a drain so it was simply flowing -- maybe they did not find it useful as they had other means of finding fertilizer.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you collect the digestate?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The maize was healthy, the yield was dumper, and we were not buying fertilizer. We were fully dependent on the digestate.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Which fertilizer were you using before this?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were buying inorganic fertilizer from Agora Shops.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many bags were sufficient for your needs?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I was simply buying in small quantities because I did not have the money to buy a bag or in bulks. So, I was buying 10 kgs of fertilizer at one point. Then, I would find that was not sufficient, so I was buying another 10kgs. So, it was always like that.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much fertilizer were you using at the end of all that?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: In one growing season, we used probably 100 kg of fertilizer and that\`s 2 bags of 50 kg fertilizer; one for quick growth of maize, and the other for strong maize kernels.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much was a bag of fertilizer then?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was K20000.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Now?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It's K60000 or K70000

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you prepare the digestate collection point at the outlet?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We dug a hole and digestate was flowing into the hole. So, we were collecting digestate from the hole.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Was the digestate not sipping into the ground? I mean, did not you lose some of the digestate by that collection system?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were getting the digestate straight to the farm, as it was plenty. Of course, some was lost in the way. Some was lost in the ground. So, we had challenge of collecting and containing it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why did you buy a big bucket and place it there? Or, why didn't you line the hole for the collection of digestate?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (laughs heavily) yeah, but I did not use it for long, because it did not last long. I only used it for one growing season. It did not last a year. So, I do not know if my colleagues used it for long, but as for me, I did not use it for more than a year. The pipes got broken, so it did not produce gas any more... And, the digester was made to produce digestate when it was producing gas. But, if there was no gas production, no digestate was produced.... So, I used it for a very short time. I think, I used it for 6 months.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What often did it release digestate and under what circumstances?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I do not know how often but after sometime digester just was producing digestate with a loud sound, if the sun was hot. When it was cloudy, the digester would not produce gas -- it did not work. Also, it was only working after 9 AM to 2 PM. It was working without the sun, so after 2 PM it was not working.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, what kind of training did you receive?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We didn\'t have any training.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Then, how were you able to switch it on and off?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The installer simply told what to do. But, we did not receive training.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were you told by the installers? What did they say?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They told us how to turn it on and off.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, then say they told you how to switch it on. Okay, what else?
interviewee: Interviewee: What else? That was that, because that meant that we would now cook. So, yeah, they showed us the button for switching the burners on and off.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did they tell you anything about maintenance?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, they didn't and that\'s why it didn\'t last long. And, that's why when it malfunctioned we did not know what to do to fix it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How prepared did you feel prepared were to run it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, we were very much prepared. And, that\`s why we were able to use it whenever there was sunlight

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You had the right to deny the digester. Why did you choose to accept it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes, indeed, it was possible to say no. And, when you think of the work that is involved, one would easily say no. I mean, we used to feed it with five buckets of cow manure, if I'm not mistaken. To that, we added water, so it was really a tiresome job.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Then, why did you accept it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: ... and the manure was flesh, not dry (laughs heavily) - fresh manure! But, we accepted it and persevered, And, I was also handling the manure with bare hands. So, it was tough, and I only accepted it because we wanted to cook without going around looking for firewood.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Is firewood hard to find here?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, very much. It is very hard to find firewood in this part.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where do you get wood?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It is very far from here - from the mountains.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, how did you meet your energy needs before the intervention? So, where you only using wood or you were also buying charcoal?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I was only using firewood.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Like how much firewood?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We collect wood in bundles. So, we used the bundles in three days.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: In a week, how many days were you going to the mountain to search for firewood?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Two times in a week.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Like if you go on Monday, you were using the wood from Monday through Wednesday. And, maybe go again on Thursday, and use the wood from Thursday to Sunday. That is some job.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: That some hard work indeed.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you differentiate cooking on biogas with cooking on firewood?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Biogas is fast. With firewood, you need to find grasses first to help start the fire. So, it\`s difficult to start up. So, biogas is fast because you simply need a matchstick to light up light up the burners... So, biogas is faster than firewood.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So it was faster because it did not involve so many processes or even because the flame itself was stronger?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The process is faster. The flame itself is stronger than that of firewood. But, if you put enough food, firewood produces stronger flames than biogas. Also, the flame of biogas was dependent on the sun. If the sun was minimal, the gas was less and the flame itself was not strong. But, at noon especially in October \[summer\], the flame was just strong.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: In June \[wet season\]?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Ah, we could not even cook in June.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, really?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, if the sun was like this \[humid and a little bit sunny\], we would not cook. It could not even start.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: But, it is not cold.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, we would not cook even when it was like this. It needed to be hot to get the flame

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, it is tough
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, and that is when the idea of putting a bag of sand or stones on top of the digester came. So, we used to put a load on top of the digester bag to help push the gas to the stove.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you learn that?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We just thought that on our own.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You said you were getting manure from other people. Before the digester, were you also doing the same?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, for what?

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Maybe for fertilizer?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Oh, yes, we did. We were using cow manure as fertilizer for our crops and vegetable garden.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: But you told me you were using organic fertilizer?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were mixing \[cow manure and inorganic fertilizer\]. Sometimes, we were only using manure extension workers told us to use. They told us that we could make strong fertilizer from cow manure by adding maize grain, yeast and 5 kgs of inorganic fertilizer.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much feedstock did you start it with?
interviewee: I believe it was 6 bags of 50 kg of cow manure.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Water?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I think it was 6 drums of water.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where did you get it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We got it from the lake. It is there.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, less than 150 meters. How long did it take to start up?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Our digester bag got fully inflated on the 3^rd^ day, and on the 4^th^ day we started using it. The installers came in their cars and moved from one beneficiary to another to commission the digesters.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much gas did it produce? How much cooking time did you? Were you able to prepare breakfast, lunch and supper after commissioning?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We could not cook breakfast in the morning. We used to cook after 9:00 o'clock when the sun was out. So we were basically cooking from noon to 2:00 PM. Thus, we could not cook in the morning and in the evening.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you were getting cooking time sufficient for cooking lunch only?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, we were only getting gas enough for cooking nsima and side dish as well as for boiling bathing water \[approximately one hour\].

interviewer: **Interviewer**: And only if there was sunlight?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, when the weather was like this, it would not even start.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you use the gas? Did you use it for cooking only?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, it was only for cooking.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were the operation requirements?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: First, you need to dig a hole and line it to prevent soil from collapsing into the bag. Then, you need cow manure and water -- That was it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were you doing with the cow manure and water?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were mixing cow menu with water using hands. Then, we used to pour the feedstock into the digester bag in one of the two white pipes. And, the pipe where the feedstock was not poured into, is where the digestate was coming out from

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you feel about all that?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We accepted with the digester, so could not have done otherwise. We did not feel disgusted because we accepted the whole process when we accepted the digester. Also, the installers were the first to mix the feedstock using bare hands, when they were teaching us how to make feedstock. So, that is also we were doing ourselves..

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) If the visitors were doing that.....
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (laughs).... What could we have done?

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (Laughs) how often did you feed it? And, in what quantities?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were feeding it with four buckets (20 liters) of cow manure every day.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Who was responsible for feeding it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: My family was responsible; I was my children, husband, and I.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were the maintenance requirements?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They told us to take good care of it; they said we should ensure that children are not playing around it. And, they said we should be alert and aware of the surrounding.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How were you supposed to take care good of it? Could you please elaborate on that?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Like to look after the pipes. If a pipe was bent or wound, we used to straighten them up. Also, check for loose connections in the connections, and generally monitor the pipe that over the ground.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So children were not supposed to come near it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I order to prevent them from cutting the pipes with razor blades or something, and even from disconnecting the pipes.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Who was responsible for maintenance?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was the installers. But they did not say we should be calling them if there was a problem with the digester.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did they give you their numbers?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes, they did. But they did not tell us that we could call them when there was a problem - They did not say anything like that, and that is why we abandoned it after it malfunctioned.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Is it wrong to say, it didn't meet your needs because you could not cook on it all the times?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: You are not wrong at all, because I was only able to cook on it at lunchtime, and I was still cooking using firewood to meet my cooking needs.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You said you were getting firewood from the mountains, are you still sourcing firewood from the mountain.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, I still go there twice a week to get firewood.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many times were you going there to get firewood when the digester was working?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: That time the digester was helping us. We could not go twice there as now. We were probably going there once a week, because the digester was supplementing the cooking time we were getting from firewood. Thus, we were only using firewood in the morning and at evening.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were the challenges?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It is mostly what I have already talked about; it was not giving us enough gas to cook for a long time. Moreover, it was not producing strong fire at times. It was taking a lot of effort to make feedstock, but it was only producing small cooking time -- that was a problem -- it did not meet our needs.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How was the fire going off?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was gradually going off, and eventually it was going off completely.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Was there are leakage?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, there was no leakage. But at the end, it developed a leak at the joint between the digester bag and pipe \[gas connector\]. So, we tried to bond the gas connector with glue, but it did not help, and that was the end of it. Because after that, when the bag was full, some of the gas was escaping and little gas was coming to the stove. Thus, we could not even cook at all.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you know that it was the gas connector? How did it manifest?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We did troubleshoot, when we saw that the bag was full and gas was not coming to the stove. So, we found out that gas was escaping at the joint.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you troubleshoot?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: When saw that the bag was full, but gas was not coming to the stove, we were very surprised. Then, we tried to find the problem. So, we moved our ears on and around gas connector and the pipes. Then, we heard a gas leaking sound at the gas connector.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) that was funny. How long did it work before it stopped working?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We used it for six months. After that leak at the gas connector, it did not work again because of a separation at that gas connector

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you call installers?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I think we called them and reported that gas was leaking at the gas connector. They just said okay and that they would see what they could do - that was it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did they come?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They never came. They never came to see the problem.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Have you ever seen something like this \[table of intervention\]? What do you think of information and do you think it would have helped?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: If they had given us this and told us where to find the materials, it would have helped. Therefore, with this we would have known what to do, if they had told us where to get the spare parts to fix the problem. It\`s sad they just give us the digester without necessary information, so when it malfunctioned that was the end of it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So if they had given this to you we would have been talking a different story or even eating nsima cooked on the digester?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (laughs) Yeah, You would have eaten nsima with bonya \[very small fish popular in the markets\] today

interviewer: **Interviewer**: If the installers call to ask about the digester, what would you say? I mean, how would you describe the current state of your digester?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It got broken long ago. I would say I don't have a digester.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Do you still have the equipment?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I still have a broken stove. I have the pipes, which I am using as a clothesline.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: In your opinion, what caused it to fail?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It\`s because gas connector had a problem, as it couldn't get a tight grip of digester bag. As a result, gas started to leak. And, once digester starts leaking gas at the gas connector, you should expect anything good to come out of it, because gas is what makes a digester produce gas at the burners, and it\`s hard to fix. So, after that, we could have done nothing, and it died.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: In your opinion, what was the major issue? Was it the fact that we did not come when there was a problem or the problem itself was big that it could not have managed to fix?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The main issue is that the installers did not help us. They should have given us spare part. Even a car has spare parts so that when it has a break down the parts that have malfunctioned should be replaced. Thus, if you given something without spare parts do not expect it to last, because once there is a problem you cannot remedy it, and eventually it dies.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How to meet your energy needs now that is not working? You said you use firewood?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What challenges do you meet there?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Thorns prickle us because trees we use for firewood here are thorny, so our hands get bloody sometimes. Snakes even bite us too.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, sorry
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Wasps even bite us.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: That\`s very tough. We are going towards the end of our interview. We have like 10% left. How much did the digester cost?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They did mention the cost, but I have forgotten what they said. It was a lot though.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you contribute anything in kind?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We provided bricks, cow manure, and water.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many bricks?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I have forgotten, but I think it was close to 500.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much did it cost you?
interviewee: Mmh, I cannot remember. However, I think in total, if all the labor and materials are accounted for, I think I spent more than K100000 in 6 months. That is considering the work of collecting water and manure. I think, if I had hired someone to do that, he could have charged me K25000 per month because that was a lot of work.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did the digging?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was my husband together with my two boys. The rest of us were simply collecting water.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: He did the masonry as well?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Is there anything else that had to be imported from another country? When you look at digester, do you think it is from Malawi?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I think, it is not for Malawi.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why do you say that?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The installers said it was from outside the country. And, even its appearance itself can tell that it is not from Malawi.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did it look?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Its design and appearance looked like nothing I had seen before. It was my first time to see it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What was the biggest difference in your life the time you had biogas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: There was a difference because I was free and happy. In addition, most people were coming to admire it as well, and they liked it when they saw you just switch it on with a button to get fire.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, many people showed interest?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They admired it a lot and wondered how they could own one someday. Then, I was telling them that one day their dream would become reality as this was only a demo. Therefore, if they continue showing interest then the installers were going to be motivated to bring more.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What is your opinion of biogas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I desire to have biogas again. But, next time they need to make adjustments to the digester itself?

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why and how?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The good thing is that it was taking the burden away from us; with 4 buckets of cow manure and water, I was able to cook. However, they need to address the issue concerning sunlight, because like I said without sunlight I wouldn't cook. It's very imperative that they solve this issue. Imagine, it was impossible for us to cook porridge for school going kids. It was even difficult to warm bathing water for the kids before they left for school, if there was not sunlight or early in the morning.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What technological modifications would you think of?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Maybe, if they can shift it to electric power before it is hard for people like us to go asking for manure all the times. If the can make it like solar, then we would appreciate it even more.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What are the pros and cons of biogas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: With biogas, you cook with ease. Moreover, it is easy to start the fire with matchstick. Its cons are; it is tiresome, as it needs daily feeding; you cannot do the work when you sick because it is intense. You need to be healthy to prepare the feedstock. Unlike solar, you just take the panel to the sun, and then you are safe.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, I get it. What is the future of biogas in Malawi?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It is bright and it can really help us to conserve the environment because it stops people from going to the forest to get wood.

interviewer: Do you think you are in a position to say that the future is bright when you were given one and now it is dead?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Good. With the research you are doing, you need to come up with ways of making it better, so that it can become durable and efficient, and help people better next time; do not stop the project here, keep it going.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Do you think if we can give 10 digesters to 10 people, or if we can give you another digester, do you think in five or ten years it can still be working?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes, it may be possible. On our part, we can be more than willing to get one again. And we can take good care of it. And you can even see that we still have materials for the last digester. But, you may need to tell us where to find the spare parts for it, so that we can fix it on our own once it malfunctions. Or, you can simply give us contacts of people who fix it too, so that we can call them once it malfunctions. We failed on this because there was no one to fix it for us. They simply abandoned the digester to us.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You give an example of a car. You said to maintain a car you need the spare parts. Spare parts are not free; can you be willing to pay for spare parts instead of going to the mountains to get firewood free?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Here people are very business oriented. So, what we can be doing is sell thobwa (traditional sweet beer) and save some of the money. It is the same like electricity, to keep it running you need a business to pay the bills.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Can you pay K15000 to fix your digester?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, I cannot. But, it can depend on other situations as well. If I can see that it is helping my family and it is contributing to my business, then I can. If I can see that I have stopped going to the forest to get firewood completely, then I can sacrifice money to fix it. To own something valuable you need to make sacrifices. It is like having a baby. When you have a baby, you are obliged to save money in case of an emergency.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (Laughs) so should we say you have money safer?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (Laughs) yeah, I do have. I have kids, so it is only necessary. I keep money in a safer. You cannot be going around asking for money from neighbors while your child is dying and in need of urgent medical support.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) true. Last one, though I feel like you have kind of answered it already. My next and last question is, if you could have designed your own waste or energy intervention, what would you have chosen instead of biogas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I would have chosen solar instead of biogas.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: With solar you do not need to go to a neighbor to ask for cow manure. You only needed to take out the solar panels to the roof, and with it, you can also use it for lighting.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Thanks. That was my last question. Do you have anything to say?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Biogas is very helpful. It makes you feel proud and it gives you peace. And when we had it we stopped going to the forest. Maybe, we were going just once instead of twice. It is very handy.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: When you say, you felt proud, what do mean?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It makes you feel like you have electricity in your house. A person who has a house connected to electricity is a happy person, because when he wants to cook, he only hit the switch. You do not get dirty; you do not get cough or flu because of the smoke. Biogas does not produce smoke; when you are cooking, you are peace; it does not blacked pots -- so it is a joy to have it!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: That's the end of our interview. I thank you for your time.
interviewee: NA

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where did this digester originate from?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Mmh (laughs) I am trying to recall the name, but it is not coming to my head... It's been long, so I've forgotten the name. All I can remember is that it came through the agriculture office under a project, which was aimed at conserving and protecting the environment. So, to be honest with you, I have forgotten exactly who brought it here because it's been a while.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, I presume the same people also funded it. Or, do you know who funded it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, it must be the same people.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Do you remember when it was built, and who built it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I think it was late 2016, if not 2017. I am saying this because I was also involved in a stove-making project around the same time.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How long did it take to build it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: At first, they came to explain about the project. After that, they went to people who had cows to see if they were interested in owning a biogas digester. Then, they said they were going to come back, and indeed, after three weeks they came. After a week, they brought the digester. Therefore, to make the long story short, they taught us about stove making and biogas. And, it took a month from the first time they came to the point they brought the digester.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What was your role?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: My first role was to take part in the free training. My second role was to provide cow manure from my cow house. To this, I added water to make feedstock that I did myself. I also brought bricks that were not used though. I also dug a hole for the digester bag.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Who did the digging? Was it only you?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I hired one person to dig the hole.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much did you pay?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I paid for K3500 for that. I also paid K5000 for the bricks.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Were you told that the work was going to need bricks? And, how come you did not use the bricks?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Good one. There was a problem because different people were coming on different days. When the individual who trained us on stove making and biogas came, he told us to dig a hole and to buy bricks and sand. We did that, and we asked him about cement. He told me that they would provide cement, and that they were going to bring two bags of cement. After that individual went, another individual came. When he came, he just came with a plastic digester bag and other equipment like pipes, stoves and stuff. Then, I inquired about cement, because they told me before installing the digester bag that they were going to line the hole with a brick wall. Then, he just responded that he was not gives, so because it was a different person I did bother to ask more questions.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (Laughs) did he take the cement for himself, or what?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (laughs) I do not know. But, that was the response I was given.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, how were you selected as a beneficiary? I mean, we have so many people in this community, how did it happen that it came to \[name redacted\] house?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It wasn't as if they came straight to me to tell me that they were coming to install the digester here. But, they called people who had cows at the agriculture offices. Then they asked who was willing to accept the technology -- that was it. Then, I think four people accepted in the technology. But, I had a great chance of getting one because around that time I was also involved in another project that was to do with the environment which was to do with construction of energy efficient stoves. So when the biogas project came, coupled with my previous experience in the environmental project, it was easy for me to accept it because it was basically aligned to the environment.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many people were called to the agriculture office?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I think it was seven to eight people -- I'm sure it was eight people... At that time, only eight people in this community had cows. And, some of the people who have cows now that time did not have cows. So, from the eight people, some gave excuses why they did not want to have a digester. Some said they did not like the process of making feedstock, as it was disgusting to them. Some said they had small fences so they had security concerns. Some said they did not have space to put the digester.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, did you know about biogas before?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes
