interviewee: **Interviewee**: The contractor was one but he came with a group of people. I think they came five or six people. I had a paper where they wrote their names and everything, but I lost the paper as I was renovating my house. My wife did not take care of it. All I can remember is that the installation company came as a team, and they were the same people who installed the digesters at Mtolongo.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many people from your side participated in the building process?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I did the work by myself.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, you dug the hole?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I dug the hole by myself. They only told me the dimensions of the hole.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were the dimensions?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I can only remember that it was 1 meter something deep. Ask for the diameter, I\'m not sure, but it was kind of round, maybe 2 meters. They told us that some part containing the manure would be in the hole, while some part would be out of the hole.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You have told me that during the construction process you were also involved in collection and making of feedstock. How much manure and water did you collect?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, we did mix cow manure and water to make the feedstock. I did collect 20 buckets (of 20 liters) of manure.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Water?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was the same; 20 buckets (20 liters) buckets.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: When was it built? And, how long did it take to build?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It did not take long. They assembled it in a day. Before that, they came to tell us the dimensions of the holes, and that they would come back again. So, when we dug the hole they came with the equipment on the day which they promised.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How long did it take you to dig the hole?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It took me two days.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What was your role apart from what you have said?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: That was it - digging the hole, collecting manure and water, and making the feedstock.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: In this village, we have many people, so how were you selected as a beneficiary?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: People were chosen based on handwork. Also, beneficiaries were supposed to have a cow house. Or, the person was supposed to be staying close to someone's cow house for easy access of manure.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So everyone who was chosen had cows or he had cows within?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Everyone who was chosen had a cow house within the house. However, one had cows but his cow house was far from his house. Therefore, it was tough for him to get manure from his cow house, so he was asking from the people around. But, for everyone else it wasn't too difficulty source manure, except for the first day when we started up the digesters. On that day, people went about asking for cow manure from other people because a lot of manure was required at once.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you buy or get it free?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I just asked and they gave me free because people saw that it as community thing.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You are saying people who had cows, and are hard working were chosen. How did they know that you are a hard working?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: In a community setting like this, people know each other very well. So, people knew that if I got a digester, I would manage it. That is evident by finding it today where it was installed; if it was given to someone you could not have found it where was installed.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you know each other?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, we know that if they give this one something, it will only be on paper that he has it, but on ground it will useless and not well taken off.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you know anything about biogas as before?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, I didn't know anything about biogas. I knew of biogas when they came with the digesters.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What was the selection process?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: "Nomination?" it happened through chiefs and other community leaders, as a small number of people was required. I think it was only 5 people who were supposed to benefit. So, they thought it was wise to call for a community meeting for transparency. But, it never happened because they thought it was going to create tension since biogas was a new thing and everyone would have wanted it. As a result, the chiefs and community committees congregated and chose the beneficiaries based on the factors I mentioned. After that, they informed the people that a new intervention for cooking was coming to the village.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did they inform the people?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Through a community meeting at group \[village\] level.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, everyone was there when they were announcing the beneficiaries?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, everyone was there. And, if you can show anyone a digester, and ask who benefited from the intervention they would tell you who the beneficiaries were -- "They will tell you Mkuzi, Faifi, Sewe and Samuel were beneficiaries"

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) Nice. So you were just told at the community meeting that the community committee and chief selected you as a beneficiary of biogas? Or, did you participate in the selection process at some point?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, I was just told at the community meeting that I was a beneficiary for the biogas intervention.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why didn't you say no? I mean, why did you accept to build it here?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: First, it is because I am a farmer, and I did not want to waste wood.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What is the connection of a farmer and wood?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: There is a connection; we use wood mostly for cooking instead of using it for agriculture activities, for example, building of cow house. So, we saw this as an opportunity of saving wood for the construction animals Also, as a farmer, I know cutting down of trees affect rainfall through climate change. So, I did not like the use of firewood cooking because it has negative consequences on agriculture.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, what were you expectations?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I expected to use biogas "continuously" for cooking, yeah!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What do you mean "continuously"?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I expected to use it on a daily basis.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: But you are also able to cook with firewood on daily basis, aren't you?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes, I do. However, if this had worked, I would have stopped using firewood.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I do not like using firewood these days because it is very hard for our women to find firewood these days. Therefore, women do struggle and are struggling. It is a burden to women. So, these days most people in this village prefer charcoal because it gives women freedom as we only buy from merchants around the community. But, it needs money so you cannot rely on it. Therefore, when we don\`t have money we simply use maize cobs.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What did the installers tell you to expect from this?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They said upon completion, we would be using it for cooking like an electric stove. On top of that, they said biogas is one way of conserving the environment. That was all.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What kind of training did you receive from the installers?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, we did not.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How is that possible? I mean, how would you even be able to switch it on and off?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Everything that was done was on the spot. They were like this is how we dig a hole; this is how we connect to the pipes; this is how we mix cow manure and water to make feedstock; then they said we should find a funnel for transferring feedstock into the digester through the inlet. In regards to starting flame, they said once we see that the bag is full, we could turn on the stove by using matchstick to light of the gas. So, it was not as if we sat down to talk about how it works and all that.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So after that how prepared to run or operate did you feel you were?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: After that, we felt confident that we would run and operate it. But, after problems started, we realized there was nothing we knew to remedy the problem. We were helpless. So once we had a problem that time, we just abandon it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why were you helpless?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were hopeless because after installation we never saw their faces again. If I saw them again, it was last year, if not the year before, when people from "MERA" came to follow up. So, I told them that for some of us we only used it for few days because we lack expertise to rejuvenate it. Then, we told them other problems too, one of which was they gave us the digesters without training. For them to bring it here, it means they received training on installation and its operate somewhere, so in the same way they should have trained us to know what to do in case of a break downs.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What did MERA say?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They said the contractor was at fault. First, the contractor did not install the digesters properly. Secondly, they faulted the contractor for not giving us training. Thirdly, they said the hole was supposed to be lined with a brick wall around especially at the top surface. They also said the contractor was supposed to make a digestate collection point at the outlet that we could use it as a source of fertilizer.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I supposed you were told to dig a hole that time for collection for digestate?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes, they told us.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you dig the hole?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes, we did. We dug it there

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So those were the key issues that were supposed to be done. Okay, did you use the digestate?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, we do not usually use fertilizer here.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It is tradition and that's what we were taught by our ancestors. Of course, sometimes people do apply manure for vegetables only though. We usually depend on the fertile soil that gets flooded here. So, our soil is fertile.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, that's great. So, you grow maize without fertilizer.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The maize you are seeing here grew without fertilizer.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: It doesn't show any deficiencies?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, it's always healthy. It is always "Green"

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You had the right to say no. Why did you accept to build it here?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They discussed it in a way I thought I was going to benefit. First, I thought I going to stop using firewood for cooking. Secondly, my wife would have stopped going to the mountains to get firewood, and thirdly, I thought I would stop damaging the environment.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I'm seeing a lot of trees around, why don\`t you use that for cooking?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I do cut and use the trees.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Then, why do you go to the mountains to source firewood?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I do use the trees economically. First, I use them for building and rehabilitating my cow house, and that is where most of my trees go. Secondly, I use it for brick clamp making. We use it because it is natural trees so it works well for brick making. Also, you cannot go to the mountains to get wood for that because you would be arrested\... Eh, natural trees are rarely the days so when you have them like this it's desirable.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I know it didn't work for long, but before it came how did you meet your energy needs?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I was using firewood for cooking

interviewer: **Interviewer**: And charcoal?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It's only recent that we started using charcoal. All along, we were using firewood

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, what has changed? What has made you move to charcoal too?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It is because of distance. It is far

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, you didn't feel that it was far in the past?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It's even farther away from where we used to get wood.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Meaning that you have exhausted all the trees from where you used to get them?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, we have exhausted it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: And now you go to another place?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, in the past the place we got wood was uninhabited; now the owners have taken down the trees, and build houses and fields. In the past, we could go there, ask for wood and get it. But, now the people cannot give you the wood.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So people have settled where you used to get firewood?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: How much charcoal do you use?
interviewee: I use a bag of charcoal**.**

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much is a bag of charcoal?
interviewee: It is K2500

interviewer: How did you manage your feedstock before the intervention?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I was doing nothing with it. But, in sweet potato season, I was using it to prepare sweet potato.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, but when we are approaching rainy season we take it out, so that when rain comes it does not create mud in the cow house.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I have always wondered to see people cook cooking sweet potatoes on ash like things; it must be the manure, I guess! Why do you cook on cow manure? How do you do it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: First, you take out very dry manure from the cow house. Then, you gather grass and put the manure on top of the then light it up fire. So, when the fire ignites you bury the sweet potato in the fire.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why do you do that? Does it make sweet potato taste better?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, it tastes better.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I should try it one day... Don't people feel disgusting?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It's quite okay. You can also wash it, so it's okay. In addition, a lot of heat is involved so it's okay.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much manure did you start it up with? You said 20 buckets of cow manure right?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, it was 20 buckets (20L buckets), or a little more than that. I think it was 25 buckets.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, water?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was 20 buckets. Water was a little less because there manure was fresh, so it was watery kind of.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How long did it take to start up?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I have forgotten how many days it took.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Maybe a month or two?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It didn't reach two months. Maybe, it was a month, if not less.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did it work after commissioning? How much cooking time did you get?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: After we fed it, they told us that they were going to come with a pipe to connect from the bag to the stove. So after some days they came with pipes and the stove, and they installed it. Then, after they went, we tried to use it and it worked but unconvincingly!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: On the day they commissioned it, did you see flame?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes, we did.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you use it for cooking?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I cooked on it this other day. I boiled water to make tea. But, as I was cooking nsima, if not dish side, it went off. Still, I have to say I liked the food, which I cooked on. It tasted good.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (Laughs) Oh
interviewee: **Interviewee**: That is God's honest truth, the food felt good.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did it feel? What was the taste?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The milk tea I drunk that day was different from the one from firewood. Of course, it was my first time to use it, but, yeah, it felt different and it was good.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (Laughs) how did it taste?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: A cup of tea made from firewood taste smoke-like. While tea made from biogas did not have a smoke-like taste.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, how much cooking time did you get after commissioning?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I did not use it for an hour from the day it was commissioned. It was always going off. But, the day I made tea, I was very surprised with it; I didn't expect that it works to a point of making tea and even nsima. That day I was able to make tea and cook nsima. While the other days it could not even flame, though the bag was full.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did it work from the day it was commissioned,? I want to have a picture.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I can say it worked weeks.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So in those 2, 3, or 4 weeks, were you getting 1 hour of cooking time?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, only that particular day I made tea, it worked for almost an hour.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay. In your opinion, what happened to that day?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I think there was too much pressure in the bag.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Then, why didn't the pressure keep on?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It is because the sun always shines brightest in summer; during, rainy season it does not shine as in summer.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Was the sun more intense on that particular day than the other days?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, it was a hot day.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: When was it installed? Was it in rainy season?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, it wasn't yet the rainy season.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Do you remember the month?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, I do not. It is only that I have lost the paper I was given, everything was there.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Were you all installed the digesters around the same time?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, if I have a paper from one it would mean I have the date and some information that is similar like the date of installation and all?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Then, I think it was installed in July. I saw the paper from one of the beneficiary. And, yes it makes sense, May to July is winter season here. Thanks.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Welcome

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So I can say, you only used the digester once in the few weeks it produced fire. And, you couldn't cook on it because it was producing very little fire and sometimes no fire was coming, right?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Very true.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So the gas was only for cooking?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, it was for cooking.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many people used the gas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were 7 people.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were the operation requirements?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: For a digester to work it requires locally available materials, for example, cow manure and water. They told us that if we feed the digester with manure and water, the bag inflates and produces gas, which can be light by a matchstick to produce flame for cooking at the stove.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How often did you feed it, and in what quantities?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I do not really remember how much feedstock, but they said we should be feeding it daily.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Maybe 5 buckets?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, it wasn't 5 buckets. I think it was 2 buckets. But, they told us to feed it daily.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much water were you adding to it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I think I was adding 5 liters of water to each 20kg of cow manure to have suitable slurry.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So it was a bucket of manure against 5 liters of water?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, think so.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: so you were getting all that manure from your cow house?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: how many cows did you have that time?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I had 15 or 16 cows.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I'm only seeing here..
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Some have gone for grazing

interviewer: **Interviewer**: how many in total do you have now?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I have 11

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where did you get water?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: From a borehole

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Is it within?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It is behind that house with iron sheet

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, about 300 meters from here.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, 300 or 400 meters.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, how did you prepare your feedstock!
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We used to mix cow manure and water with a stick. Then, we poured the feedstock into the digester bag through funnel into the inlet pipe.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did they provide the provided the funnel...
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I did not get a funnel, but I made one myself. I was using it when I was pouring feedstock into the digester to avoid wastage.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Were you told to make one, or you saw that it was necessary?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They told us that it was good to use a funnel when putting feedstock into the digester to avoid spillage. So we made one from a 5-liter bottle and it worked perfectly.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I have talked with a number of people on that subject, but many have told me that they used hands instead of stir sticks or any other mixer because with hands you are able to break lumps or take away debris. What is your take?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: If we saw debris, we used to take it out using hands. We could not leave rubbish in the feedstock, because it has the potential of damaging the digester. But, in mixing we used a stick, and it was working quite okay, because we used fresh.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Who was responsible for feeding it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I was.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Alone?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you feel about feeding it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was hard work, and people used to call us using the provocative name given to people who collect trash in the city (laughs)

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) how did you feel?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (laughs) Yeah, but we did not care biogas about that. What we cared about was to cook on biogas. And, we accepted it too because it was what it was; it was true, that's what we were doing!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Which people were making fun of you?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was the whole community. They were saying all that because it was new thing to them.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (Laughs) okay. What were the maintenance requirements?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The installer did not say anything about maintenance. But, when the people from MERA came they said that the installer didn't do what they told him to do. So, they said they were going to have a meeting to find a way forward, so that we could use the digesters again. But since that time, they have never come back.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: When was that? Last year?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was last year.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What did they say the installers did wrong? Or, they only said they did things badly?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: First, they faulted them for not giving us training. Secondly, they said the start up feed was not done correctly. They said the installers used more water than they were supposed to. Thirdly, they said that the design, which was here, was different from their design. They said the design of our digesters required the wall of the hole to be lined with a brick wall.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How could that have helped?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: First, it could have helped protected the digester in general. Secondly, it could have helped the bag to expand in a straight manner. Also, the bag would not have been moving anyhow. Moreover, I even saw that our digester bag was shaking on one side, because it had no wall around it. So, if it had a wall on top of hole it could have help to stay in its positioning. And also, the inner sides of the hole were collapsing into the hole because it wasn't lined.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Yeah, I think it could have helped because I have heard in some cases people put stones on top of the bag to increase pressure. So a brick wall around it would have also helped to push it back, and maybe, yeah.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, the installers told us to put a load on top of the bag to increase pressure when there was little pressure. And, they told us not to worry about the load because when there is too much gas or pressure in the bag it works perfectly even without putting a load.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: During its short life, did you ever get it working when it had an issue?
interviewee: No

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did it meet your needs during the time it worked?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I was only able to cook on it on the day I made the tea, and I was a very surprised that it worked. I never used it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What challenges did you encounter?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The main one was that it did not work at all. Secondly, they deprived us of knowledge and skills to manage it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What about the fact that people were calling you names?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, that was nothing. You know people always try to bring you down when you have something good.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Yeah, there is always jealous and all that. You said it produced gas or fire for few weeks, and out of that time, it was only one day that you were able to make tea and cooking nsima. So, I want to have a picture of the days you were not using it, like how was it like when you turned it on?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was like when you put something on it the fire was going down gradually, and then it would go off.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: In most cases, how long was the fire taking to die?
interviewee: It was dying in less than 10 minutes.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: When you switched it on again, what was happening?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was not starting. Sometimes, we could see fire when we light it up again. Sometimes, it was not producing fire at all. Then, we tried feeding it daily like we were told for the first time. But, nothing happened.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You mean, you tried feeding it throughout the few weeks it misbehaved?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes, we used to feed it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What happened after that?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We did not know what to do. So, we reported the issue to agriculture office because the installers came through their office.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Some are saying they were given the numbers of the installers. Were you given?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, I think they gave us their numbers. Yeah, their numbers were on the paper, they gave us indeed!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why didn't you call them?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The digesters were calling us to see how the digesters were performing. And, we told them they weren't working. And, they were okay and they find time they would come.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did they come?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No. If they came, it was last year.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: The MERA people?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah. The installers only came frequently before and during installation. After commissioning, they never came again

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okaaay, when you talked with them they were like \`\`we will come, we will come\`\` but, they never did?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Have you seen something like this \[intervention sheet\]?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No

interviewer: **Interviewer**: It is information about issues common with digesters, their causes and solutions. What do you think about the information and could it helped your case?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It would have a lot because it could have been like our reference for any problem associated with the digester.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: If they gave you that, do you think you could have solved your problem or it was out of your capacity?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: If our problem was on this information then today you could have found it was.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Do you know the last time you used it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I do not remember, but it was a few weeks after it was installed. I remember, we used to feed it as we were told, but still it was producing very little or no fire at all, then we gave up after we saw no improvements.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you fed it for few weeks after it failed?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How would you describe if the current state of your digester?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I can simply say it is dead; it is not working.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Sad!
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I took off the pipes last year, because I was expecting them to come at some point all those years.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I have seen people using the pipes as clotheslines; others are using the digester bags as a roof sheet. What are you doing with the material?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I have just kept the materials.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, you have it.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Do you think it can work again?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Of course, yes. The installers told us that the digester bag has a life span of 15 years. And that it cannot be eaten in 15 years by termites or anything. They said other think could get damaged, but not the bag.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did or do you believe that? I mean, can you believe anything from them after what happened?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: That time we believed them because we thought they had the expertise. But, now it\`s hard to believe them.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did it reach this stage and in your opinion what caused it to fail?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Personally, I think it reached this stage because they did not give us training especially on feedstock preparation. In addition, I think it is because they did not give us any training on maintenance.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: If you had received the training, things could have been different?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, maybe today we would have been talking about our shortfalls.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you think you did do anything wrong in regards to its failure?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I do not see anything we did wrong. We did everything as we were told.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, we are going towards the end of the interview. So nowadays, you meet your energy needs by firewood and charcoal?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: As for manure, you just keep and remove when it is close to the rainy season?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where do you dispose it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We just burn it in the cow house.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why do you burn it there?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Because that kills, some of the parasites, for example, ticks.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay great. How much did the reactor cost?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They did not tell us anything about its actual cost. They simply said that the digester was expensive.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay. Who paid for that?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I think it was the government, but they got the digesters in Kenya. The digesters came from Kenya.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: The installers told you that?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What kind of special items that had to be imported from another country? Or, was it all from Kenya? Or, which things are from Malawi?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I'm not 100% sure, where they got it from. But, the people who installed it are Malawians.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: During the time you had it, did it help you to save any money or did you stop going to search for wood or charcoal?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, nothing changed. Not a bit!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: We are remaining with 3 questions. What is your opinion of biogas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: My opinion of biogas is that if it is possible for the installers to rehabilitate it, then they should do so because we would like to atleast see how it works. And, after rehabilitation they shouldn't forget to train us on it... They should drill us on maintenance so that we can be able to fix it on our own.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What is the future of biogas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: When I think of the day I used it, then I have to say it is doable. However, it needs to be good installed; it's need experienced installers. So, this can have a future if and only if it there can be organization in the manner of its installation.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What do you mean organization?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They should take us through proper training just like a school itself. For example, they should be like this is the letter "A", this is how we write the letter "A" and then they should make us write the letter "A" on our own. I think this way things can work.... But, the time they came, they just said this is how we write the letter "A". So we didn't know the "A" and let alone how to write it. That's why were stranded.... Take for example electricians, they go for 2 or 3 year training. After that, they go for practicals or attachments. That helps the trainers to know or assess the students. So with this one, it would have helped and worked, if they had given us a 2 or 3 days training. I\`m sure, out of 5 people, 2 or 3 people would have gained the expertise to manage it, and the knowledge would have then spread to the community.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Yeah, you have a point because they say you know a good football player on the field, and not in training. So, you were supposed to go through hands on training and an evaluation process too. If you could have designed your own waste or any energy intervention, what would you have chosen instead of biogas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We have seen people using LPG gas, so I think it is a good alternative of biogas. So, if we could have that opportunity we would be thankful and we can manage it without issues. I cannot say solar panels because I have not seen people using them for cooking. And I'm sure if a solar panel was capable of producing energy for cooking, then the problem of deforestation couldn't have been an issue because everyone has a solar panel now.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I see. Any last words, before ending we end interview.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: My word goes to government. If they start a project they shouldn\`t just abandon it, they need to follow up. If this project was followed-up for the first 3 months, I'm sure the digesters could have been working now. They just disposed the digesters here and then after 2 or 3 years they went back to their papers and decided to come back. There was no way they could have found the digesters working. They took too long to follow-up.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: That\`s true. Thanks for the interview.
interviewee: NA

interviewer: First, where did this originate from?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They gave us a paper, which had information regarding that, but I don't know where the paper is now. We have moved from one house to another a lot for a couple of years, so it\`s hard to get track of things. And, I have not only lost the paper. My ID is also missing. And, it's unfortunate that when they gave me the paper I didn't scrutinize it much to the point that I could keep the information in my head.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you don't know where it came from, but they gave you a paper that had that information?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Who designed it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I don't know who designed it. Maybe, the other beneficiaries know or have the paper I'm talking about. But, I remember that I dug the hole, and I also made the feedstock by myself. I was only told how to do the tasks though. They told me that after preparing the feedstock, I should feed the digester and that after sometime I was going to see the bag inflated.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many people dug the hole?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I did it alone. The project installers only came to place the bag, assemble the pipes and stove.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many people from the installation company came?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was 4 people.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many people were involved in the preparation of the feedstock?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I sourced manure with my wife.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where did you get it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I went into other people's cow house to collect manure. Some people gave me 2 bags and I got the rest from other different people.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you didn't have cows that time?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah. I didn't have a cow house. So, some gave me for free; some people sold us the manure at K1000 a bag.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How was it like going to ask you for manure? I mean, did other people say no?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Of course, some people said they couldn't give us for free. So, they sold us 2 bags at K1000 each... But, we used the digester for 5 days.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How long did it take to build it altogether?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It took me one day to dig the hole. It also took them a day to place the digester. And, it took them 3 days to come and assemble the pipes and the stove, and then start it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, after starting it you saw fire.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, it worked.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, in brief what was your role?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: That was all; I dug the hole, sourced and made feedstock. After installation, I found that biogas is a good thing; it's fast especially when cooking side dish. And, out of all the beneficiaries in this village, only my digester worked. I mean, I asked all my friends how their digesters were faring and they responded that their digesters weren't working.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, nice. Why do you think your digester worked while others failed?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I think it was how we worked; some people were told to collect 50 buckets cow manure and could not manage. Some, instead of using fresh manure were using dry manure. And, indeed, after feeding it the first time the installers said our digester was going to work, and it worked.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: And, you saw the fire?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, everything was good, and I even roasted maize afterwards.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: And, were roasted nicely?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Very good.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: After that?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I cooked side dish. The next day, it worked in the afternoon. But, it didn't work in the morning and late hours of the afternoon because it needs the sun.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: In this village, there are so many people, even 300 households. How were you selected as a beneficiary was?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Before getting into the biogas project, I was in a road construction project. Before moving to biogas project, they told me I was going for 9-day training, and I accepted. When they gave us the digesters, they told us it was a pilot project, so people wanted to see who was going to be most successful. So, it brought a competitive spirit among the beneficiaries. And, some beneficiaries were doing things steady but sure, while others were doing things in haste to show that they were successive. So out of all the beneficiaries, I was the one who managed to make it work.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, you were chosen because you are a hard worker?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I was a hard worker.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, you stopped working hard?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, but I was pulled off by the fact that the digester couldn't work for a long time when there was no sun.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, did you know about biogas before?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, I was expecting to learn about biogas at the 9-day training, but it never happened.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, before they came you didn't know anything about biogas, but you expected to learn about it at the 9-day training, but it never materialized?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You have mentioned how you were moved from the road project to biogas project. How were the other beneficiaries chosen? I mean, who selected you to move from the road project to the biogas project? What was the selection process like?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: we had a community meeting at the senior chief's residence, that\'s where they chose as beneficiaries, and the people bore witness. I mean, when it was time for the people of Mcheleka to choose a beneficiary, I was chosen by the people, since I'm a resident of Mcheleka village and the people saw that I was skilled enough to run it and be exemplary to the community. Then, I was like fine, write my name.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why didn't you say no?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Saying no would have meant that I had also rejected my chief.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) oh, you didn't want to shame your chief?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (laughs) yeah, I didn\'t want to embarrass him.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: If I have had you correctly, you have said the people of your village. Do you mean there were people from different villages?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: At the community meeting, there were seven chiefs from different villages with their people under one Senior Chief. So, because they wanted five beneficiaries, three villages were taken as one village. Then, they told us that there was a project, and whoever was interested was welcome to submit their names. Many people didn't give their names because; they didn't want to handled cow manure regularly; some people didn't like smell of cow manure, so they thought biogas was worth all that. At that point, people were not told that they would go for training. People were only told that there was a project called biogas, its requirements and that the digesters address cooking needs, and whoever was interested was welcome to give their name... Then, the chief told me that they were moving me from the road construction project to biogas project, as I could not be involved in both projects. But, I was hesitant to move because I was not sure if the training was going to happen. Then, he assured the all the beneficiaries that we would go for training on biogas, and I accepted to move. And, I everyone saw my name taken out of the road project to the biogas project. So, that's how I was selected, and after some time the digester came.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What was the road project about? And, what is your role?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was a community built road project by MASAF, and I was earning K18,000 each month for taking part in building community roads.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: so you accepted to let go K18000?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes, but that was not a problem since I'm a fisherman, I make K2000 a day when I go to the river to fish. So, I make K15000 a month.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: It's K60000
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (laughs) yeah, it's K60000.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: That's a lot! Interesting, you have touched on an interesting subject for me. I remember one time I was working with a certain NGO on wash project. So, I was involved in creating and strengthening water point committees. During that time, I observed that when you are working with community people, if you want to get them engaged or get full attention, you have to bring in the element of training. It's was surprising to see how people would put in effort and so much interest in tasks once you mentioned training. I will put it to you, why are community people so interested in trainings?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: That's very true.....That time this was commissioned many people came to see me roasting maize. People were taking videos and pictures, and they commended me for the good work.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) amazing. But you haven't answered my question. I want to know why community people get so enthusiastic about projects once you tell them that one day you're going to take them for training? Why are community people so obsessed with trainings?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I can say community people become interested in projects depending on how the whole project is introduced. If you tell them that a project has no component of training they accept and the work without issues. But, once you tell them that a project will involve trainings people become even more interested because we know they will get "something out" at the end of training.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So it's about the money, the training allowances to some extent?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you receive any training? What kind of training did you receive?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, I didn't receive.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You didn't know about biogas before, then how were you able to switch it on and off, if you didn\`t receive trainings?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: On the day of commissioning the digester, they just said \`friend\` we have switched it on, how did we do that? So, I saw them taking a matchstick and lighting the burners after opening the gas valve and turning the control knob at the stove, therefore I did the same. I didn't go for training.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What else?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: An, I was also told how to make feedstock as they were installing it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How prepared to run or operate the reactor did you feel you were after all that?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Very much so! I saw them turning it on and off, and they told me what to do once there was no gas in the bag as well. So, I knew that I would be able to run it because I had gained knowledge to run it, though without the training.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What did they tell you to do when there was no gas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: There were two things to look at when there was no gas production. First, we had to see if there was the sun or not, because it doesn\'t produce gas when there is no sun; when it's hot like this, it produces gas. Secondly, if the sun was out, then we had to feed it with feedstock at the inlet pipe to produce gas.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, what were your expectations?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I would have been very happy today to see it working because I couldn't be using firewood for cooking. Now, I have no expectation of it working again because some people punctured it, and my children punctured it at some point as well. So, it is sad and it hurts to see my wife suffering sourcing firewood. So, I hope to have it again one day.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What did the installers tell you to expect from this?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I'm not sure if they were saying some of the things just to make us pumped up, so that we could make their work easy. I remember they told us that they didn't want us to handle feedstock with bare hands. So, they promised us gloves, work suit, wheelbarrows, gumboots and shovels. They didn't give us all that, but that wasn't a problem because we managed to prepare feedstock effectively with our bare hands. Still, it wasn't easy to pick manure with hands, so at some point I only managed to buy a shovel to help me in collecting fresh manure.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: At what price?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was K4000, I think.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, you expected to cook without sourcing wood, and you expected to get items like gloves and work suits and all. Apart from these, what else did you expect or what else were you told to expect?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: That was that.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you meet your energy needs before the intervention?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Before that, I was using an energy efficient stove given to us by Goal Malawi. However, the stoves were not durable, so we didn't use it for long. After that, I was using a two-hole firewood stove given to us by DAPP \[Development Aid From People To People\].

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What's wrong with those stoves \[points to the stoves\]?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It's like when you use it for 2 weeks or so, it develops a crack and it eventually breaks into two.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh,
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, and when it does that you can't fix it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I can imagine that throughout this time you used firewood for cooking. Where did you get?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We exchange firewood with sweet potato with women from the hillside.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So they come here and you do exchange?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, we make heaps of sweet potatoes and say this heap is, for example, K1000, and they make bundles of firewood and tag a price to it, and then we balance up. So, that's how we exchange firewood with sweet potato.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, how was it like around the 5 days you used the digester? Did you send them back?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Nothing changed because the digester was only working in the afternoon, so at night we still needed firewood.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You said you didn't have cows or any livestock, right?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Do you have now?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, how did you do it after commissioning?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: After the digester bag got full, the installers came. When they came, they called me to observe what they were doing. First, they opened gas valves and I had heard a certain sound indicating gas movement. Then, they asked me to get matchstick but I did not have, so I asked my little child to buy. When we got matchstick, they opened the stove and lighted the burner. Then, they asked me what I wanted to cook, so I told them I wanted roasted maize, and put maize on the stove. When people saw what was happening they started coming one by one to see me roasting maize on biogas. While, I was roasting maize people were saying that I had hit a jackpot. We managed to roast the maize, and I shared it with the people to eat. Some people from Mozambique even came to see me roasting maize.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Approximately, how many people came, and what was their reaction?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was a lot of people. I don't know how many people. It was a lot. People from the upper side of the village came to see the whole thing. People from Mozambique when passing by, were even coming to see what was happening.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What did they say?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They liked it and wanted to have one too.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much cooking time did you get after that?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The next day, I cooked dry fish and nsima \[approximately one hour of cooking time\] in the afternoon. But, when I was trying to cooking nsima in the evening, it didn't work (laughs)

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you feel?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I kind of expected that because the installers told us that it wouldn't work in the evening. They said they would bring some equipment that was going to enable us to cook in the evening and to use it for lighting as well. So, we expected that, but they never came with the equipment.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, I see. Uh, they gave you their numbers, I mean, did you follow up on this prospect?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I called them, but their numbers didn't go through. So, I went to the extension worker to ask, and he told me that he was also trying them but the calls weren't going through. I asked him if they had blocked us, but he told me that he had no idea. Then, he went on to say that, they were going to come back at some point, so I shouldn't worry. So, I think this is the day, praise be to God (laughs).

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) I don\`t even know how to install a digester, brother. How did you use the gas? Was it for cooking only?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I was also using it for cooking.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many people used the gas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were 6 people.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So have said you only used it for 5 days?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How was cooking like in those 5 days?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was somewhat similar; I was only using it in the afternoon.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Can you quantify the cooking time you were getting? How many hours did you get in the afternoon?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was 1 hour or so.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were the operation requirements?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: One of the gentlemen whose name was on the documentation paper told us that we would require cow manure and water.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What else was required?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: That was all.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, what were you supposed to do with cow manure and water?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: To start it up, they told me that I should mix six bags of cow manure with 100 liters of water. So that day I woke up at 4:00 a.m. and started searching for manure. I went to \[name redacted\] house, and then I went to \[name redacted\] house to pick manure, though he was a beneficiary too. He didn't hold back because he was my father in law. But, when I went to \[name redacted\] house, he told me that he couldn't give the manure for free. So, I bought him. I think I paid him K1000. I did this job with my wife, while my children were collecting water. After we got enough water and cow manure, we mixed it and then poured it in the digester.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I have heard about \[name redacted\] the other beneficiary. I heard his whole family was murdered in the most gruesome way. How did you prepare the feedstock?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: What happened was bizarre. I can't just figure out how some people would do that. Talking of feedstock, we were placing cow manure in a bucket, add water and then mix with bare hands, like my hands are now, since we didn't have gloves. Whenever we saw lumps, we crushed them to have a smooth feedstock. After making smooth and slightly thick slurry, I used to pour it in the digester. I finished the work around 9 AM, and around 11 AM it started making a certain sound, then after some days the bag got full and I hit it with my fingers it was producing a bell like sound. So, I knew there was gas in the bag, but after some days, it was punctured.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You said people at some point punctured your digester. Why do you think they did that? Was it out of jealous or anything?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I can't know because that time I was away on my fish trip. The problem was that my house was close to a footpath. As a result, the installers also placed the digester close to the footpath, so it was easy for people to puncture it. So you never know people, until you dine with them. Thus, some day we found it punctured because of jealousy. But, I've seen have beneficiary cutting it on purpose to make makeshift doors or roofing sheets (laughs). Then, I heard all the people from Kachere cut the digesters because they were useless. But, I was happy that out of all the people here I was the one who used it for long.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Only for 5 days?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, and even if the installers come and do an evaluation, people would see that I was the one who performed best among all the beneficiaries.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (Laughs) I think 5 days is just too little to say you use it.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (Laughs) But, if you compare with my colleagues, that\`s success.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (Laughs) who was responsible for feeding it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I was responsible.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you feel about feeding it? Didn't you found it involving?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, I didn't find it involving because I knew that was the only way that would stop us from sourcing firewood. And, it was exciting for me to use a modern technology for cooking, though I was only able to cook in the afternoon.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, what were the maintenance requirements?
interviewee: They said if the problem was at the stove, we should call them. But, if there was gas leakage on the bag or anywhere, then we could seal the punctured place ourselves with an adhesive. Then, I asked them if it was necessary for us to buy an adhesive since they told us that they would provide anything for us. Then they just said if there was a leakage, we should inform them. Then, we had problems and called them, but they didn't come. So, we knew that it was up to us to maintain it, and that's why many beneficiaries abandoned it when they faced a problem, because we didn't know what to do.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You have said it stopped working after 5 days. How did it stop? Did it go off at once or something?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It stopped working after 5 days because the weather changed. It became cloudy and cold. Then, after some days, the sun came out, but my wife didn't switch it on.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You weren't around that time?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, I was away. When I was leaving, I told my wife that I'm going for a business trip, use it when the sun is back and when the bag is full. But, my wife is illiterate, so she didn't pay attention to what I told her regarding its operation. So, she didn't use it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Do you think it needs someone who has gone to school?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes, school helps a lot because it makes people to understand things easily.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, so I those 5 days, did you meet your needs?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: After it worked for 5 days, I went for a business trip a day after. Then, when I was away, my wife called and told me that the sun didn't come out and the bag was deflated. Then, I told her that once the sun was out the digester bag would inflate. The next day, the sun rose, and she told me that the sun was out, but she admitted that she didn\`t know how to operate it. Then, I told her not to bother and let it be, so she didn't use it. Then, later that night I think some people took advantage that I wasn't around, and punctured it. Then, she informed me that people had punctured it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, it took about 6 or 7 days for people to puncture it? (Laughs)
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (Laughs) Yeah.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Jealousy people!
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Some people weren't happy to see me use it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why do you think some would just come and puncture your digester bag?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Our \[Sena\] tribe is hard to understand. It's different from people from the north \[Tumbuka tribe\]. People from the north are united; no one feels more or less important than the next person; and they support each other. People here just not like to see others doing well in life. Here you cannot get support from anyone, excerpt from very close friends. Even people who you went to school are always jealousy of your success. Jealousy is just too much here!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: We are going towards the end of our interview. What were the challenges?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We faced many challenges; one was that we did not receive training. Another problem was that unknown people punctured the digester. Secondly, it was hard for us to take it out of the house when we were told to moving out of the house by our landlord. So, you can see the challenges were just too many.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I'm also thinking of the challenge you had with it when it came to cooking during evening.... Wasn't it producing fire at all? Or, it was producing very little fire?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It wasn't producing fire at all, zero!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: They told you if it had a puncture, you could seal it using an adhesive. Did you try to fix it after people punctured it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, we didn't because we moved to another house. But, before we moved, children who liked to play around it also cut it. And this made the problem bigger than the first one. The first one, I could have tried to seal it with an adhesive. But, the second one was so big that I couldn't even dare to try (Laughs).

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) and, even if you could have fixed it, they could have come back again.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (laughs) very possible.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Have you seen that before?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: This is information regarding problems common on digesters. For example, it tells you if it's not producing fire, It is because of this and that, and it also tells you it's possible solutions. What do you think of this information and would it have helped in your case?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: If they couldn\'t manage to give us training, then they would have at least given as that information. With that information we could have at least had understand of it. But, sadly, they just gave us their names and phone numbers to call, and their number didn't even work.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (Laughs) it's sad. Today is 22^nd^ of September, if the installers can call you today and ask you describe the current state of your digester, what do you say?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I can tell them straight forward that the digester is now part of my roof structure, it's a roof sheet now! I can't keep words from them (Stops speaking to attend to a visitor)

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) so you can tell them open now that it's a roof sheet now?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (laughs) I can't tell them that, it's rude. Ah, I can't say that, I can only tell them that the digester is not working. But, we have the materials.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where are the materials?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The digester bag is on top of the roof, and other things are in the house.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I will see all that at the end. How do you meet your energy needs now that it is not working?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Now we use firewood.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Charcoal? Do you use charcoal?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Honestly speaking, I don't use charcoal. I remember this other time forest officials caught me with two bags of charcoal as I was passing through a roadblock. I told them that I didn't make the charcoal, but I only bought it, and they told that was still an offense by forest laws. So, they took the two bags from me, so from there on I don't buy charcoal.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Don't people come here to sell charcoal here? I mean, with that you can't still use charcoal because it's not like they come into the houses to check if you have charcoal?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, some women sell maize cobs at a certain place within the village, so when we don't have firewood, as it is the case now, we go there to buy the maize cobs. They come around 5:00 PM, we could have gone together to see what happens, if you had time. So, that's what we use.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you use that for cooking as well!
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: We are about to finish our interview; we have five more questions to go. How did reactor cost?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They said it was K200000.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Who paid for that?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Mmh, I have forgotten. But, if I had the paper, you could have seen. I always make digital copies of such papers and put in my phone, but I don't know why I didn't do so that time.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, did you contribute anything in kind?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I contributed nothing. I didn't give them any like a chicken or something. But, I did kill a chicken for them to eat while they were working.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Good hospitality, uh!
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (laughs) yeah! I was like to these are my visitors let's support each other. So, I got a chicken and cooked it for them!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You killed a chicken for nothing, uh (laughs)
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Ah, no. I didn't want them to go hungry, despite the fact they were getting allowances (laughs)

interviewer: **Interviewer**: That's so kind of you. Next time, I will tell you well in advance that I'm coming when I get you number. The number I had of you didn't work. I want a chicken here next time like them! Moving on, you have said you dug the hole alone, right?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, did you line it with plaster or a brick wall?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No. It's was just a round hole.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did they tell you that you could line it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes, they did. They said whoever could manage to buy a bag of cement should do so to protect soil from collapsing into the hole. But, we didn't do that because our bag was well placed and fitted perfectly into the hole. So, we only stacked bricks around it to prevent debris from getting into the hole.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You just stack the bricks?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, and at the outlet, I made a hole without lining it with plaster or a brick wall. The hole was for collecting digestate.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you use the digestate?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why? They didn't tell you that you could use it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We thought that when the digestate stays in the hole for some days it loses value, and became useless.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: But, people who use manure keep manure for some time before using it. So, didn't you think it was kind of the same? Why didn't you use it as fertilizer?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Our fields are very far away from here. But, if we had gardens around then you would have been using it. We found it tiresome to carry a bag of digestate there. Our farms are not within this community, they are in Mozambique.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you mean you don't carry a bag of fertilizer there?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The people here don't use fertilizer. Maybe, others don't, but a lot of people don't. It's only in Chidisi where people use fertilizer. But, here I don't think so, and I have never seen a person using manure.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why don't people use fertilizer or manure?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The soil here is so fertile. When we plant maize, it grows well, and it produces strong maize cobs with big ears.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, you are lucky. People are stressing over fertilizer in some areas.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: \[no response\]

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What special items had to be imported from another country? i.e. did they tell you were the materials came from?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They said the digester is from my abroad. They also said the donor was international as well. So, urged us to take good care of it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: They just said the donor was international, but they didn't say the name?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They didn't tell us the name of the donor. They only said the donor was international and that one day he would come. They went on to say that, only 10 people from two villages of Mtologo and Kachere were the beneficiaries.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you save any money in those 5 days it worked? If so, how much money?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Of course, I saved some money. I mean, when I wanted to buy firewood and cook, I was spending K500 per day; one for lunch, and the other for supper. So, in those days, I can say I was saving K250 a day, which I used to buy soap and other things.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What is your opinion of biogas? When you hear of biogas, what comes into your mind?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: When I had biogas, I was like in a different world. Of course, I was able to use it in the afternoon only; still it gave my wife an opportunity to rest. I wasn't seeing my wife going around searching for firewood as I used to. So, it gave us rest and our lives were better

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, it's a good thing?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Right?

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Its drawbacks?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It\`s what I have already said. If the bag deflates, it doesn't produce strong fire.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I though you only need to feed it to keep the bag inflated?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It\'s not possible to keep it full all the times because we don't feed it daily. They told us to feed it after every two days, so we couldn't keep the bag full all the times. When we fed it, the gas didn't stay long to go to the next day, so it's a big challenge.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh! What is the future biogas in Malawi?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I believe, if I wasn't travelling a lot, I would have managed to move with it from house to house. So, my travels resulted in its failure. Also, the fact it was punctured by people made it not to last long.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: But, we are talking about 10 people who were given to run it and hoping that the community would adopt it. But, all 10 people, including you failed to manage it, so do you think you would have managed it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, I mean out of the 10 people, I was the best and my friends were even saying that I tried managed and make it work. So if it was to work, I was the only person who would have made it work here. But, my going in and out are the cause of its failure. So, I think it just need close attention from both the installers and the users to make it work.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Last question, okay, if you could have decided your own energy or waste intervention, what would you have chosen instead?
interviewee: There are a lot of technologies that are coming into the country. Whatever it be wind powered energy interventions or solar powered interventions, which can be used for cooking. So, I can go for such interventions, and I can give my all to make it work.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why such interventions?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: There are reliable because the wind will always be there. The sun will always be there.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: That's the end; do you have anything to say?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I would to thank you for coming with your research. I'm so glad you have come. In regards to biogas, it has been many years without people coming to follow up on this, so we are thank for that. And, I have to say we feel like we have unfinished business with biogas, and we would like to maybe use it someday.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Thanks for the interview, and I appreciate for sharing your time with me. I have hold your for long, I saw that you were going for a football game, hope I haven't taken much of your time.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It's okay, and the game hasn't started yet, so it's fine.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where did this digester originate from?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The project implementers came from Lilongwe. I have forgotten the name of their organization though, But, they came here with agriculture extension workers. They said the aim of their coming was to install digesters, which use cow manure for cooking. Then, they asked us to do some work which took us 2 weeks. First, they told us to mix cow manure and water. So, we found 5 bags (50 kgs) of fresh cow manure. Then, we closed the outlet and inlet pipes, so that the reactor could produce gas. We were told that the reactor needs the sun, like it is shining now to produce gas. Then, they went on to say the digester bag inflates once it has gas that burns and produce flame for cooking. After that, we dug a hole of 2 meters wide and 5 meters deep, I think. Then, we waited for 2 weeks, but when we tried it didn't work. The fire was very little that we could not use. Therefore, I think something went wrong. After that, they came again and we told them that it wasn't working as we could not cook on it or even boil water for bathing. Then, they told us that the hole needed to be lined with a brick wall to insulate or heat the bag. We told them we couldn't manage to get cement, but we could manage to mobilize bricks and sand. So, they said they would see what they could do. We waited for over a year, but they didn't come back. Then, after two years, the digester bag collapsed. We tried to feed and get the bag back, but it didn't work out. Then, at some point, a calf that would have cost K200000 fell in the hole and broke a leg. So, we decided to take it out to protect the livestock. Therefore, we took the digester bag out and covered the hole - so that's where we are today. But, I can say we never used it. When we tried to cook nsima, but it would only simmer, and then it would stop producing gas.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many people from the installation company came?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was a lot of people. I remember they were coming in cars. They were coming often, but at some point, they stopped coming. And all that time the digester bag was full that you could stand on it without collapsing, but it wasn't just producing fire. So, we just abandoned it, and continued using firewood as you can see. Then, we bought a charcoal burner after seeing that it wasn\'t enough to use firewood only.... And as one of the person who was chosen to use benefit from the pilot project, I can say we need a different innovation, as biogas doesn't have the capacity to produce gas that people would use for cooking. And, when you go to the office tell the people there that biogas doesn't have capacity to work and meet people\`s needs So please bring a different innovation, for example, a solar system which we can use for lightning and cooking.... If you were there that time and saw how we worked, you could feel sorry for us that we wasted energy for nothing. We sourced a lot of water and 5 bags of fresh cow manure for one week from Chamtutu which wasn't easy, and people were even wondering what we were doing, and why we were getting manure from other people when we had our own cow house. So, it was a lot of manure that I couldn\`t even manage to get from my cow house for a week... So when you go back tell them that the people have removed the digesters, because it was a danger to livestock, and that they want a different solution, and not biogas.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many times did they come?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It's been many times. We have been receiving many visitors for a number of times. We've been receiving people from Lilongwe, Blantyre to check the digester together with our extension workers from Tengani EPA.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You said you dug the hole, how many people dug the hole.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I dug the hole by myself.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I can see that you have a few boys here, why did you dig the hole alone?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: That time my boys were in school getting their diplomas.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How long did it take you to dig it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It took me 2 days. So before digging they just gave me dimensions to work on. Then, l dug it according to instructions, and then we made feedstock and fed the bag. After a week or two, they came to install the digester. When they switched it on, it produced very little fire not enough to cook anything.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many people were involved in feedstock preparation?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was my wife and I. I remember we had to move around the village to search for extra manure, as our manure was not enough. It took us time because it wasn't easy to gather one bag or so a day. And it's harder to gather one bag of fresh manure than dry manure. It seems simple but it's not. And I'm sure if the project implementers saw work we did they would have felt pity and given us money.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Who funded it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They just said it was students from Chancellor College, who were trying out the digester to see if they would work. So, we thought their study was going to help us, but we were wrong as we didn't benefit anything.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How were you selected as a beneficiary? What was the selection process?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The chiefs chose the people. They chose people who were hard working and active in community development projects. Every time there is a community project I'm always there, I never miss a session. For example, if there is an agricultural scheme activity which needs volunteers, I'm always there working on treadle pumps to get water for the crops. So, chiefs saw that and thought that I could manage the digester as well.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you know about biogas before?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, not at all. I had never seen or heard about biogas before.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, so you say they chose you because of your hard work?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: yeah, five hard working people were chosen.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: And you can confirm that the other four beneficiaries are hard working as you?
