interviewee: **Interviewee**: Very much so. The man who has directed you \[name redacted\] here is a hard-working man. Even, Chief \[name redacted\] is a hard worker too. He's always pushing us in community development projects. He leads by example. So, we always work hand in hand with him. You can't have development in a community like this with a lazy chief, so our chief is a hard worker, and that's why he has good working relationship with extension workers and other community workers.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, what were your expectations?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We expected to use it for cooking and to give us some rest especially women in regards to searching firewood for cooking. So, we thought our women with the coming in of the digesters would not have a hard time sourcing and igniting fire especially after returning from the farms. So, we thought it was going to take away that burden from them. And, when it came my wife was on the forefront collecting manure, and she even told me that we shouldn't go to the farms for a week in order to concentrate on this. So, I was happy because I expected my wife to get rest in terms difficulties she faces in cooking. And when we were trying it, she was so happy to see the water boiling. I have never seen her so happy in a while. The neighbors came and saw it, and there were so happy too saying it was our time to rest. And, a lot of people came because it was a new thing and they wanted it in their houses too. But, we told them that if things go well for us, then they would have a chance to own one in the future. \[Goes away to chase goats eating maize\]

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Troublesome goats!
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I was also a beneficiary of the goats too.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What did the installers say you should expect from this?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They said if things go well, then more people would get the digesters up to the point every household gets one, so that people should stop cutting trees for cooking.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, if the digester had worked, it could have been a very good thing for the community and the environment.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, very true.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What kind of training did you receive?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We did not receive training and that's why we found ourselves in a very difficult situation. I thought at the end of it, my wife and I, were going for training to learn about biogas and even get training allowance. I thought two of us were going for training, so that if one was not around the other one would manage it. Or, at least they could have just got my wife to training because she's the one who spends most of the time in the kitchen. But, they just gave us the digester without training, and we were very saddened by that. \[Stop to chase goats eating maize\].

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you didn't receive any training?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We didn't receive any training. Not even for a day. They just installed the digester and told us to do this and that.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What was that?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They just taught us how to make feedstock. They also told us to feed the digester whenever the bag was deflating. They also told us how to make the hole. But, other than that they didn't teach us anything.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I suppose they told you how to switch it on and off, like how to operate it.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, they told us how to switch it on and off. Then, they told us that when we saw very little gas coming, we needed to feed it with a bag of manure to boost it up... That was it! \[Stop to chase goats\] ... We got these goats from DAPP to improve our livelihood. I got five goats; one buck and four nannys. The plan is that when they conceive I should give to other people who would also give to other people and so on.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, nice. So after all that talk, how prepared to run or operate the reactor did you feel you were?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I think, we would have managed to operate it, but the problem was that it didn\'t produce enough gas from the onset, so we didn't use it all. It didn't produce gas to help us in any way. So the problem was that they were supposed to line the hole a brick wall around it to make it work, but they didn't. Personally, it could have been better if they had just installed solar panels because it doesn't really depend on the sun as a digester does.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: When the chiefs chose you, you had the right to say no, but you didn't. Why did you accept to build the digester here?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: You don't say no to a project that's intended to develop the community. We felt very lucky to be chosen out of 200 or 300 people in the community. We thought God chose us, because there were so many people who could have got it. But, God favored us out of those people, so we couldn't have said no; if they chose us to go steal something, then we would have said no. If someone gives you work that you would be paid or benefit, you don't say no; so, what more to be given something beneficial for free. Thus, when we got it we were thankful to God and to the NGO because we struggle a lot in the rainy season, as charcoal is hard to find, let alone to dry wood.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you meet your energy needs before the intervention?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We use firewood and dry stems of certain plants from the fields, and it's what you are seeing there. It's very common here. The last couple of days we had no charcoal. We have bought charcoal yesterday. It's that bag there.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, before this came were you using charcoal as well?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, we were using firewood. It's only this year because of hunger. It has forced people of a certain village to sell charcoal here. They sell charcoal at K2500. So before they started bringing charcoal here we used to burn logs and use it as coal because it burns longer... Because of hunger, the people of Mpelembe have started making charcoal to sell here... But, they do it illegally and when forest officials catch them, they are sent to prison. So, they are only doing this because of hunger. There is famine there also because it's hard to find land for farming there. Even us, we don\`t have land to plant crops, so we don't plant maize here. We plant maize in Mozambique.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, you grow maize in Mozambique?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, we grow maize in Mozambique. Of course, we also grow maize here, but it's a small portion because of shortage of land. So, we get our food from Mozambique.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many cows do you have?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Right now, I have 9 cows but that time I had more than 20 cows. I sold some because of financial problems, and also because I was paying for my children's education. My son you saw there was doing a diploma in electrical engineering, and my daughter is in secondary school. So, I value my children's education because I don't want them to be illiterate like me. So, I sell cows to pay fees for them and I don't feel like I'm losing. I also sold cows to pay fees for my other child who now working with Escom. So, you can see that I\`m keen in educating my children, and it has started bearing results.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh nice. You are doing the right thing; education is the best investment a parent can make in their children. How did you manage your feedstock before the intervention?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Around this time of the year, we gather dry manure onto one place in the cow house. And then we burn the manure to repel mosquitoes and ticks, which are a nuisance to cows.

interviewer: How did you learn that?
interviewee: It's common knowledge here. Everybody knows it here.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Interesting! You said you used five bags of fresh cow manure to start it up, how much water did you use?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We used one drum (200L) of water.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where did you get the water?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We got it from a borehole.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, you also mentioned that you used cow dung from your cows as well as cow dung from other people. How was it like to get dung from other people?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Everything was okay. There was no problem. The people here are always happy when there is a community development project, so they always contribute towards its success in whatever way. Everywhere I went to ask for cow dung the people were forthcoming and they gave me cow manure as I wished.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Some people have told me that it's not easy to go into someone's cow house because some cow owners use rituals that do not allow strangers to go in their cow houses, what's your take on this?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Of course, but it depends on the reasons of going inside the cow house. If you are just going there to collect cow manure, there's no problem. You can enter. But, if you're going there to steal, then there's a problem and that's when rituals work and are for. For example, a girl who has begun puberty is not allowed to go in my cow house. A girl who is 11 or 12 years can't enter my cow house. And now with the change in life, some girls start puberty as early as 9 years, those I don't allow to go into my cow house. But, a girl who hasn't started puberty can enter into my cow house without any problem.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why? Or, what is the ritual for?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: "Nothing!" For example, if you can ask me to go there, I can allow you. But, if you could come to steal then you wouldn\`t see the cow house there, it will disappear and you might even get in serious trouble.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, maybe the ritual for you is that a girl who has started puberty shouldn't go in. Maybe for others the ritual is that a stranger should not enter their cow house...
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Ah, no. People do allow others to go in their cow houses. And the ritual works for thieves who come at night and it doesn't work for thieves who come in the day light. But that's fine, because thieves don't come in the day light.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, I see. How did it work after commission?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: On the day of commissioning, it worked for half an hour. First, we tried it with bathing water. Then, water boiled and I went to bath. Then, we put a pot of nsima, when I was bathing I heard that it had gone off (laughs). Then, we went to the digester bag and we found it full. But, after some time the bag started deflating.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What happened the next day?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: On the second day after coming from the fields, we did put a pot to heat side dish from the previous day and it heated up \[5 minutes\], here we do not throw away food, as you do in town, we keep for the next day, the side dish heated up. But, after we put a pot of nsima, it went off again. Then, when we went to the digester bag and poked it, the bag pitched, so we knew that there was no gas in it. After that, we decided to feed it with two buckets of cow manure. So after it was feed, it produced little gas and it went off. That was in November, and the bag continued to shrink back. It continued to shrink from December through April. In May, that's when the bag completely deflated, and there was no sign of air in the bag afterwards. Some people last year or previous year came to see it. They found the bag completely collapsed, and I told them that the digester had brought nothing but problems to me. So, they told me that they were going to bring new digesters, but up now I have never seen them again. Then, that's when a calf fell into the pit and broke its legs. So, I decided to simply take out the bag and cover the pit. It was so hard to get it out because it was full of manure. I remember 10 people failed to carry it, so we cut it to take out the contents.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So from the time it was installed, you never cooked nsima. If you ever used it, it was only for boiling water for bathing, and heating side dish, just once as well.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Cooking nsima on it was a tall order -- that was impossible. It was like asking for a lot. It never happened! Things have not been good for me. It started with the digester. Then my other child has been in the hospital for 8 months now, and my child was involved in an accident some weeks back, so things have been tough for me.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh sorry. I hope things will work out for you -- God be with you.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, thanks.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were the operation requirements?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was just cow dung and water.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much feedstock did you feed it and how often?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I was feeding it on Sunday. So, the feedstock was working from Monday to Saturday, and on Sunday, I was refilling it again.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You were only feeding it on Sunday?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, I was only feeding it on Sunday.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were you feeding it and how often?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I was feeding it with one bucket of cow manure, thick as this.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much water did you add?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: One bucket of 20 liters. Sometimes, after feeding it in the morning, we were also told to add water especially if it was too hot to help the reactor to breakdown the manure. When we did this, we could here certain loud sound in the bag.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you prepare the feedstock?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: First, I was placing the manure in a bucket. Then, I was filling a bucket with water. After that, I was mixing manure and water with hands to break down the lumps. Then, I was using a stick to stir the mixture until it was smooth. After that, I was pouring the mixture in the digester where it was broken down by heat as well as water. I was breaking the lumps and then stir because if I did not do that then feedstock would not have passed through the inlet pipe and blocked it eventually.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, who was responsible for feeding it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I was doing everything, like I said my boys were not around l that time.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you feel about feeding?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It wasn't in the problem. It was only intense on the first day when we were starting it..... But, we were not happy that we did not receive training. We only came to terms with that because it was free, a gift, so we could not have asked for more.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were the maintenance requirements?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It only needed to be fed with cow manure to function. Once it was fed, you just switch it on and off. If it was off, you needed to feed it, and it starts again, and so on. Secondly, we needed to prevent soil from collapsing into it pit. So, its maintenance is easy; it only needs to be fed and to ensure that the pit is protected from soil. It is only covered now because it has taken any long time without work. It has now been 5 years without working.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Ok, I wanted us to talk about if it met your needs. Apparently, it did not meet your needs as you didn't use it....
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, we had the desire to use it for cooking, but unfortunately, we did not. It only gave us a hard time. We wanted to use it for cooking nsima and side dish, but every time we did put a pot on the stove, it was going off. Then, my wife would go look for firewood to continue cooking. Then, we lost interesting after seeing the bag deflating, and it eventually collapse to the bottom.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were the challenges?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The first and main challenge is that it did not work. The second problem was that it was supposed to be lined with a brick wall as they said, but we failed to line it. A digester works well on sunny days and when the pit is lined to maintain the heat. It could have worked well, if it was lined. So because it wasn't lined there was warmth at the top bag and coldness at the bottom of the pit, so that why it did not work.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Who told you that it was supposed to be lined?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was the forth people who came.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: It wasn't the installers?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, it wasn't the installers. The first people just told us to dig the hole; they did not talk about lining it.

interviewer: \[question inaudible\]
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I think fourth people were from MERA.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You have said the problem started from the onset. I want to know was the fire starting and going off at once or gradually?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was going off gradually.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How long was it taking the gas to go stop?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was taking a very short time to go off. It couldn't stay long as we have stayed here; So, it was taking less than 5 minutes

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How long did it work before stopping completely?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: In November after the rains started, that is when it stopped completely. There was no sign of life in November because it cold.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: And this one came in July or August... and all this time it was going on and off, and you never used it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes

interviewer: **Interviewer**: After November, did you try to feed it?
interviewee: Yes, but the digester bag was the deflating more and more. And it couldn't produce even a small flame of fire. It was only making a snapping sound when we tried to light it up. That time it was also releasing slurry at the digestate at the outlet as it was doing before, and it was very disgusting.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, it must have been disgusting.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, but because you wanted it very bad, we did not care about that.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many times did you feed it after it stopped producing flames?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I fed it 3 times, I shouldn't lie. My wife was the one pushing me to feed it as she thought I was not putting enough manure. We tried very hard to feed it because we really wanted to use it for cooking one day.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you call the project implementers?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I was not given their phone number. Maybe they gave the chiefs and extension workers, but as for me, I was not given.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Have you seen something like this before?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No

interviewer: **Interviewer**: It is information regarding problems common with digesters and their related causes and solutions. What do you think about this information and do you think it could have helped in your case?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, it could not have help because the digester never worked or produced fire at all. So this information would have helped if the digesters had worked. For example, when you have a bicycle and it breaks down, you get the spare parts and ask if you lack information to fix it. With the digester, everything was intact; it was only that it wasn\'t producing fire. That's why we tried to feed it with manure but then the bag was shrinking even more.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Today is 22 September, if the installers call you today to ask how your digester is, what would you say? How would you describe the current state of your digester?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: First, I would tell them that it is not working. Second, I would tell them that we removed the digester bag and covered the hole because it was dangerous to livestock. And, I could tell them to tell their bosses to bring solar and not biogas again because biogas is a waste of time. It made us do a very hard job without benefit. So, it's better to bring solar because it's user friendly and also it can be used for lighting and cooking as well. Also, solar works even when there is rain unlike a biogas digester. So, if they call, I could tell them biogas is a burden, and it injured my calf. And, some people have cut the bag, but we have not. I only hired 15 people to carry it out of the pit. That thing is heavy.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much did you pay them?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: That time I paid them K3000 for the job, but if it was now I would have paid K7000 or so.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I can see that you have just left the digester there, and you are using the pipes as a clothesline. Where is the stove?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It's in the house. Let me go get it. This is it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, you are a keeper.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, we have everything.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Truth talking, considering all that happened, why do you think it did not work? How did it reach this stage?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I don't know exactly what went wrong. But it looks like, digesters can't work in cold season, so they can't work here in Malawi because we do have cold and rainy season. Secondly, cow manure loses its strength fast when it's in the bag. So, cow manure is not an effective or reliable source of energy \[feedstock\]. Thirdly, digesters can't just work without a brick wall lining. So in my opinion, I think solar system is better because it has no maintenance issues, and can be use for lighting. Of course, people will try to find ways to make biogas work or better, but whatever they may do it cannot just work in the cold season.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Now that it's not working, how do you meet your energy needs? You mentioned firewood and charcoal, right?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I'm using that charcoal bag. I bought it yesterday. There I'm boiling water, so that when my wife comes from the farm, she should bath and recuperate. I'll use that for cooking nsima, and by Sunday, it will be finished. I bought the bag at K2500, and in two weeks, I will use two bags. So, in a month I spent K10000.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: That's a lot. Do you still use cow manure as a repellent for mosquitoes and ticks as you mentioned. Or, what do you do with cow manure now?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, we still do that. But, some remove out of the cow how because if we don't the cow house will be full of wet manure when it rains. As a result, cows will have troubles in sleeping and will stand the whole night that we feel pity.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much did the reactor cost?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They just gave me the digester and didn't tell me how much they spent on it. I would be happy if I can be enlightened now.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) now it's K600000 or K800000. Some even go as far as a million.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Oh, they gave us lot money.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Yeah, did you contribute anything in kind? I'm seeing that you used you energy, cow manure, what else?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: And maybe water. Plus, the money we spent on the people who took it out......I'm sure everywhere you have gone you haven't find one working, but maybe the bag still in the bag. I only took it out because of the calf incidence and I keep it safe so that when the installers when come they should find it. So I just keep it there, I don't need to put it in the house because no one can come to steal that; what can it be used for?

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Yeah, what kind of special items that had to be imported from another country?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I can't know. They just told me that they were students, so I don't know if they made it themselves.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Looking back, can you say it saved you money or made you lose money?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I was doing most of the work by myself so didn't spend a lot. But, at that time, I hired some people to get manure for me at Chamtutu, so I paid them K3000.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You received a biogas in 2017, you had it here, you still have all the equipment. What is your opinion of biogas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: If you get a wife and see that the marriage is not working you divorce, and get a new wife, so I\`m going for a solar system now.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) so your new wife should be solar?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (laughs) this one has failed. She was a bad wife! We tried to make things, but she didn't want marriage.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) you tried to involve marriage counselors but nothing happen!
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (laughs) we want any innovation and you can see that we are handworkers and we did put in a lot of effort to make it work, but it just didn't work. Even tried to feed it in the cold and rainy season, but the bag was deflating more and more. We struggled a lot!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What is the future of biogas in Malawi?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I don't know in other areas. But, for people of this community, I can say it has no future. People were given the digesters here, but no one will tell us that he is still using it or he used it. If at least one or two people were able to use it, then you could say the rest were careless or not committed\... No one can say everyone who was given the digester was careless and not committed. It's just that this thing didn't work, and I doubt if it can work with the climate here Malawi.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: My last question is, but I think you have repeatedly answered it, if you could have designed your own waste or anything intervention what could you have chosen instead of biogas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: If the solar panels are available, it's better to install solar for lighting and cooking. Then, I think that way people would benefit. But, we know that resources are difficulty to mobilize, so the students who came here need to go back to the drawing board and redesign the digesters. And, before handing over the digesters, they need to train us on its operation and maintenance so that at the end we would learn about it and get training allowance to buy few things... Thus, if they are bringing digesters they need to take us for training... And, the training should involve women, that's my opinion. They need to take the women because they are the ones who spent most of the time in the kitchen. Then, maybe we can learn from them after. So the training should prioritize women. I'm not favoring women, but I think everyone has his or her role, so I believe women can do this one effectively.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: That was my last question. In closing, do you have anything to say?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Basically, it is what I have already said. First, we need a different solution not Biogas. We want solar. If resources are not available then they can come with biogas. But, it needs great technical changes so that it becomes usable.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Thanks for the interview.
interviewee: NA

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where did this digester originate from?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I don't know who brought it. I think it was a nongovernmental organization.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Do you know the name of the organization?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I have forgotten its name.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Do you remember anything about them? For example, what they were wearing, their cars or anything?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They were not wearing something like a uniform or work suit. It was just ordinary people in casual attire.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: okay, how many people were coming?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was more 8 people. Sometimes they were coming 3 people; the 2 people were simple men, but the third gentleman looked like a boss and he was fond of speaking English though. He was also speaking Chinese.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Chinese?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: \[no response\]

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Whom was he speaking Chinese with?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: He was just uttering Chinese words.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Was he Malawian?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, no doubt. But, he seemed like he lived in China at some point.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, who funded it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I think it was an NGO. But, the people who were coming were just contractors. They said they were installing the digesters as a pilot project.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Who built it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We built it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many were you?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were 2; me and this person here.

interviewer: Were you paid?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, the project implementers asked the beneficiaries to dig a hole, so we did. I think the hole was 3 meters deep. After that, we built a brick wall around it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Who did the masonry work?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was two of us again.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many bricks and cement did you use?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The wall was double layered so it used many bricks. I think we used 2000 bricks.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many bags of cement?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was 4 bags.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much was a bag of cement then?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I think the bag was K8000 then, because we spent K28000 on cement alone.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Eh, you mean you used 4 bags? That's enough to build a house....
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, it was double layered and we plastered (lined) the bottom of the hole too.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, I get it. Where did you get the bricks?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We bought the bricks.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much did you spend on bricks?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: A brick was K30.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: When was it built?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I don't remember.

interviewer: Did they install your digested together with the other people?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Then it was in the 7^th^ month of 2017.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, and we did all the work. The installers only came to install the digesters.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How long did it take you to build it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It took us 2 days to dig the hole, and another 4 days to build a wall around it and plaster it too.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So it took you 6 days. What was your role? You have said you dug the hole and plaster the hole, apart from this what else did you do?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were also responsible for sourcing manure. We also hired women to collect water.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many were they? And, how much did you pay them?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We hired 4 women to collect water during the time we were lining it. So, for 4 days we paid each one K2500. We also hired the same women to collect water when we were preparing the initial feedstock, and we paid each woman K5000.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where did you get the manure?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We got it from other people.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you pay?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We paid K200 per wheelbarrow.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much manure and water did you use to start it up?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We used one drum of 200 liters, if not 2 drums of 200 liters of water.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Manure?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I think it was 15 wheelbarrows of cow manure. It was a lot!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: We have a lot people in this community, so how were you selected as a beneficiary?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were given because we are hard workers and we are reliable. When we are given a task, we do it with commitment and with excellence.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Are you not bragging about yourself? Are you hard workers?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (laughs) Yeah, it is not easy for any ordinary man to collect and prepare feedstock.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So people who were given the digesters were all hard workers?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Were you not given because you are a chief?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No - not because of that. They choose us because of the things I have talked about. We have also other chiefs in the community, which were not chosen, so it was not because of that.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you know about biogas before?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, we did not know about biogas, and we were even surprised what it was.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What surprised you? Or, why were you surprised?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We wondered how cow manure could produce gas for cooking, and it was something that we had never heard of. We only knew of electric stoves, but not biogas. So, when they installed it we were very surprised to see fire.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did it work?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes, it worked. And we were even able to cook on it. But, its performance was dependent on the sun. When there was no sun, or cloudy the bag could not inflate and produce gas. But, when the sun was hot like this, the bag was getting completely full to the point that I could even stand on it and the bag could not shrunk.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, it was working when there was sunlight? When there was no sun, it could not work?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Right! So it was working from morning up to 4 PM.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, I hear that 10 beneficiaries were chosen from Tengani. How were you selected? What was the selection process?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The people were called for a community meeting by chiefs, so at the meeting people were briefed about the project, and then people who were hardworking were chosen.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So it was people who chose the beneficiaries and not chiefs?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, it was the people who chose the beneficiaries at a community meeting called by the chiefs.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, you must be really hardworking.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (Laughs) yes, we are.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you attend the meeting?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many people were there?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The whole community was there, and that time the village had 700 people.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were your expectations?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were so happy because we expected to stop using firewood for cooking.... And we expected to stop damaging the environment as well.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You do not like cooking firewood.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We feel happy because here we do not have electricity and it is very difficult to source money to buy charcoal. But, we liked biogas even more.

interviewer: Why?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was easy to use. It did not require going around searching for wood, and it did not need put firewood constantly to maintain the fire... Once biogas ignited, everything was smooth.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you expected to cook with ease?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, we expected to cook 3 times a day on it. However, it only worked late morning and in the early afternoon hours.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, what did the installers tell you to expect?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: After installation, they only told us that we would be using it for cooking. But they did not tell us the specific times we would be using it. They also told us to feed it every morning with 2 buckets of cow manure and 3 buckets of water.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What kind of training did you receive?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They only told us on how to use it. But, it wasn't like we went for a training or a seminar, everything was done on site.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How were you supposed to use it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Can I go get that? (Goes to get a stove)

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Yeah! Let me drink water, it is hot here
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, this was the stove. They told us that a pipe carrying gas from the digester is connected here. Then, if we wanted to cook, they told us to turn this clockwise, and when we turned it gas was coming on the stove. So, that was the training!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did they tell you anything to do with maintenance?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, they did not.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How prepared to run or operate the reactor did you feel you were?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We felt okay! And we used it with no issues.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You said you were chosen at a community meeting by the people to be a beneficiary. When one is chosen, one is at liberty to accept or not to. Why did you accept it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We accepted it because you were chosen. When you are chosen by people, it is disrespectful to say no. Secondly, we liked the technology so we wanted to try it. Also, we thought we were lucky to have it, so we could not let luck go by.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you wanted to do try it and it was your luck?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Was it really a blessing or a curse? I mean sometimes things look good on the outside, but when you have them, it is the complete opposite. Were you lucky?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (laughs) yes, indeed, I think we were lucky to have it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you meet your energy needs before the intervention?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We used firewood.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where did you get wood?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We source firewood from the bushes.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Daily?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, daily.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Was it not a tough job?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, it is.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you use charcoal that time?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, it is only recent that we started using charcoal. Back then, before it stopped working, we used firewood only.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What has changed now? I mean you have said before it came you were using only firewood, but now you are using both. What has changed basically?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It is so hard to find firewood now, so we decided to buy a charcoal burner with the little money we had to lessen the burden. So, when we do not have money, we go source firewood in the bushes.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many bags of charcoal do you use in a month?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We use 3 bags.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much is a bag of charcoal?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It is K3000

interviewer: **Interviewer**: That's expensive. In some areas, a bag of charcoal is K2500.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, if you go that far side it is K2500, but on this side is K3000.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Some people say they prefer chips cooked on firewood because it tastes somewhat different from chips cooked on charcoal. Did you differentiate the food cooked on biogas from the one cooked on charcoal or firewood in terms of taste?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Not really, but the difference has to be there since food cooked on biogas is smoke free. The one thing with cooking on firewood or charcoal is that it's easy to burn or over cook food because you do not necessarily regulate the intensity of the fire like biogas. Also, you need to be around every time when you are cooking with firewood to maintain the fire by adding firewood.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you have cattle that time? Or, you were just asking for manure from other people?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We asked when there was a deficit, for example, on the day we started it up. But, we also had our own cows.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you manage your feedstock before the intervention?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were just throwing it away.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What about using it in the farm?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Soil is fertile here, so if you apply manure you kill the crops. I think manure contains nutrients that are not suitable for this soil\... I believe soil is so fertile here that additional nutrient from manure makes the nutrients in the soil to surpass its required level thereby it kills the crops.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you don\'t apply of any type?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How does the maize perform?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It does quite good. I think it does better than maize applied with manure or fertilizer. So, if the rains are okay that year, then we do have a bumper yield.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Everybody in Blantyre, Thyolo and else applies fertilizer, so why do think your soil is fertile here? Why is it different from the soil in Blantyre or Lilongwe? What makes your soil fertile?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Ah, I do not know why.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Moving on, let us talk about how you started it. You said you started it up with 15 buckets of cow new and the one drum (200 liters), if not two drums (400 liters) of water. How long did it take to start up?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I have forgotten.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So from the day you fed it with huge amounts of cow manure and water, how long did it take you to start using it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Mmh, if I say I remember, I will lie.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did it work after commissioning?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was working okay, and sometimes it wasn't. When there was sunlight, we could cook a little bit.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: When there was sun, how much cooking time did you get?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I remember one day I cooked beans in the morning, and at lunch, I also cooked nsima.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: That's like 2 or 3hours of cooking time.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much cooking time did you get when there was no sun?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The bag was deflating.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, you mean you could not cook when there was sun?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, we couldn't cook.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You couldn't cook nsima?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes, it was not producing fire. When there was no sun and we turned it on, it was producing a hissing sound, but gas couldn't be light up.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you were getting this sound whenever there was no sun?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, yeah. It was like this when we had clouds, or during sunset.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you use gas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was for cooking only.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many people used the gas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were 7 people that time.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I want to be clear on how it worked after commission. You said it worked depending on the sun, right?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Were you able to make tea and lunch when it was sunny?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We would make tea (boil water) and cook nsima at lunch, or sometimes dish side of vegetables.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Evening?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, it wasn't producing gas.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, that's like 45 minutes to 1 hour and some minutes of cooking time a day. When there was no sun, did you manage to make tea?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So it was heavily dependent on the sun...
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So after all this, did you consult the installers or the project implementers?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I'm not sure on that. I believe my father would know.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were the operation requirements?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It only needed to be fed with cow manure and water.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you prepare the feedstock?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We used to pour manure in a bucket and add water, and then stirred the feedstock. After that, we poured the feedstock into the digester.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What did you use for stirring the feedstock?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We used a stick.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Were you soaking cow manure to be used the following day?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, they told us to use fresh manure so everything was done on the day.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Cow manure contains trash, how did you hand it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were simply removing the trash from the feedstock with hands, so no trash was going in the digester.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How often did you feed you digester, and in what quantities?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were feeding it daily with 2 wheelbarrows of cow manure and 3 buckets of water each of 20L capacity.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where did you get the water?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: From the borehole.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How far?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It wasn't far, maybe 300 -- 400 meters.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Who was responsible for feeding it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was I.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Who else was supporting?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was only me.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You said you were 7 people, why were you the only person responsible for feeding?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The others were school going children.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you feel about the work of feeding?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was hard work because I was doing it every day. And before mixing feedstock, I had to source manure and water, so was tough. I think it's tougher than sourcing wood.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh! So you think it's better to go search for firewood than prepare feedstock?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Considering the way the digester worked, it was better to source firewood than make feedstock... But, if everything worked okay, biogas was better because it's easy to use. What put me off is the work of feed it; it was intense.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Then why didn't you just abandon it and continue using firewood?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, the digester was given to us as a gift. So, if we stopped doing the hard work of feeding the digester, it would have broken down.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Let's suppose it wasn\'t given to you as a gift, would you choose to feed a digester or search for fire!
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I would choose biogas.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It's fast.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: But, because it didn't work as you thought, you think it's was better to go search for firewood?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Right!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were the maintenance requirements?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I don't remember anything regarding maintenance. Maybe, my father knows. But, I don't remember anything concerning that... I think they gave us number though.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Who was responsible for its maintenance?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I remember one time gas connector disconnected from the bag, so the digester bag collapsed, as there was no gas in it. So, we got a tire rubber and sealed it. It only worked for a month.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How long did it take for this problem happened?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I can't remember.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did it meet your needs?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, it didn't. Like I said, we expected to use it in the morning, afternoon and evening, but we couldn't. So, we were still using firewood for cooking.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What challenges did you encounter?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was difficult to source manure as we had small number of cattle. We had 7cattle that time so it was hard to get gather 2 wheelbarrows of fresh manure. Thus, sometimes we had to go ask from other people. Some people would refuse to give us manure.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why would they refuse to give you manure?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Some people use back magic. So the ritual is that no person should enter the animal house expect themselves. Some were selling us: some were giving us for free.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) do people really do that? I hear it's common to do black magic with cows?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (Laughs) people do that; some people who own cows can't let you in their cow house because of rituals.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) why is that?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It is part of protection that no thief should steal cows. Some do it to be successful in the cow farming.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (Laughs) so the main challenges I have notes are; it was hard to find feedstock as some people would not give you; it was not working as you wanted; and you had issues with the gas connector. Apart from these, what other challenges did you face?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: That's was all.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So in regards to malfunction, what other problems did you face on top of the gas connector issue?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: That's was the only problem.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did this problem manifest?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: When there was the sun, it was leaking gas that we could not have gas at the stove.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So did it make a sound? Or, did you smell gas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was both.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you don't how long this problem took to manifest. I know you can't know the exact time, but did it take a month or months, roughly?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It started small, but we didn't know what it was, and what to do with it. Then, the leak started producing water. So, we were surprised like where is the water coming from. Then we asked one another if someone had poured water on it, but no one accepted. Then, the water stopped coming out, and gas started to leak and the smell was coming out as well. Then, we tried to seal it, but after a month, it happened again.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you try to fix it again?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, My father and I left for a tombstone unveiling ceremony at Marka. We stayed away from a month. We came around the rainy season, so we didn't do anything, as we were busy with farming activities. And, we knew that we could not get gas even after fixing it since it was the rainy season and the sun was not coming out. Then, we just abandoned it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How long did you use it before it stopped working?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I think 3 months, if not 2 months.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So after 3 months it stopped completely. Before that, how was it like?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was on and off.; sometimes it was not working because it had a fault, but because it wasn't feed. So, if we didn't feed it in the morning, it couldn't produce fire. If we fed it, it would produce fire.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What caused your not to feed it sometimes to the extent of not getting fire at all?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: When I was away, no one could feed it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So it couldn't be fed without you?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: My parents preferred to use firewood because they thought it was involving to feed it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you ever call the installers or project implementers after any kind of fault?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I don't have that information, but my father does.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: After installation, how many other times did you see them?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, after installation they never came.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: No even once?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Let me see... Oh, they came one week after installation. After that, they never came back again.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: To give you papers?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, they gave us papers, you are right.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you tell them that you had problems with it i.e. you couldn't cook when there was no sun? If yes, what did they say?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I don't know because they didn't talk with me but my father.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Do you have your father's phone? The one I got wasn't working.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: yeah, he changed his number.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Share me his number so that we can talk on some of the questions. Have you seen something like this before?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What do you think of this information and do you think it would have helped in your case?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes, it could have helped.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Whenever we had a problem, we could have been consulting it and act accordingly.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How would you describe the current state of your digester today?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We have it, but it's not working?

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You have the equipment?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Ah, no, some pipes dry in the ground as you saw. Also, some people moved the pipes as was built on a path.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: But the bag is still there?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I also saw the wall you built around it is intact.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: In your opinion, do you think it can work again?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I think if the installers come and rehabilitate it, then it would work again because I think the bag is intact.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Taking all think I to consideration, how did it reach this stage?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The main issue was the gas connector. It is what is today because of the gas connector.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, you think if the gas connector was strong and durable I could have seen it working today?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: If the gas connector and the pipes were more durable, you could have seen it today.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Let suppose the pipes and the gas connector was okay, would you have kept on feeding it regardless of the fact you were cooking on it once a day on a good day?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, we could have.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How do you meet your energy needs now that it's not working?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We use firewood and charcoal. We buy charcoal on the side.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: But, you don't buy firewood?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I understand there are forest officials, how do you cope?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The forest department gave us neem seeds, so we planted them. As a result, we have our own neem trees.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where is it now?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We have a woodlot. And some of the tree we planted for personal use are there.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Was everyone given the seeds?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Everyone was given in this village, and that's why we have so many trees in this community. They gave us neem trees because it's an easy tree to plant. But, it's been a very long time. So, some people don't have it no more.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, how much did it cost?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, I don't know.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: But, whatever money was paid an NGO was responsible, right?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you contribute anything in kind? We have seen bricks, cement uh
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Cow manure and water.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You said you dug the hole with someone, like you were two?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Does this other person belong to this family?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, he was a hired worker.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much did you pay him?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: K40000

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Was that not too much in 2017?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The soil was very dry and compact.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Who built the wall around it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I built it. The hired worker supported me by simply handing me the mortar.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So the K40000 was for digging the hole and supporting you in handling the mortar?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: That was a different item. We paid him K5000 for that.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, he got how much in total?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: He got K45000.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Apart from this what other work was done?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, all the hard work was done on the first day, for example, sourcing manure and water, and making the feedstock as well as digging the hole

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What kind of special items had to be imported from another country?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes, I think they told us the digester bag came from China. They didn't tell us about the white PVC pipes for the inlet and outlet though.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: When are going towards the end. Ah, a digester releases digestate at the outlet pipe, how was the digestate collection point like?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We dug a big hole and plastered it with cement, so the digestate was failing into the hole.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were you doing with the digestate?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We used to take it to our vegetable garden as manure.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You have told me you don't apply manure to your maize...
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, we don't.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: But, you do apply to vegetables
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, we do apply to vegetables, tomato, but not maize

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you save money when you were using it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How? I thought you don't buy firewood?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Sometimes we do buy firewood when we feel like our trees need to regenerate. And, we don't go to the mountains, so we buy sometimes. But, this doesn't happen regularly; it\`s very rare.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay! What was the biggest change in your life that you had when you had the digester?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It minimized the cutting down of branches from our trees.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: We are remaining with 3 questions. What is your opinion of biogas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Biogas is good because it's easy to use. And, it was very handy especially after coming from the farm, as we didn't need to search for firewood and it was also fast since fire was coming upon ignition.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Its drawbacks?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The gas connector needs adequate care, as it doesn't last long. Also, the pipes need proper handling.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: When you saw the pipes, do you think you can find the in the local market?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I don't know if they can be found. But, I have never seen them anywhere else. My first time to see them was when they brought the digester.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What is the future of biogas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It's hard to answer that because our experience with this digester was very short, so it's hard to say. But I can say it's good because it's fast. In regards to people adopting it, I would say it's highly unlike because most of the people who were coming to see us using it said they couldn't manage.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were they saying?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was involving. The work we were doing was hard to many. I also feel the same way though. I think it can be adoptable if it can be feed once a week or once every month.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Last question. If you could have designed your own waste or energy intervention, what would you have chosen instead of biogas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I would be willing to work with any other intervention.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What intervention?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Any intervention?

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) someone will bring a bomb, any you will accept it because you think it's an intervention. Okay, thanks. Do you have any last words before we end the interview?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Mine is a concern. I think for biogas to be adopted it needs to be fed once a week or once a month, and not daily. If biogas is like that, I don't think it can work, because I feel it was a burden for us to concentrate on farming activities and feed it as well. So, it needs some modification to be adoptable.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, thanks for the interview.
interviewee: NA

interviewer: First question, where did this digester originate from?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I have forgotten. It's been a very long time.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Yes indeed, 2017 is far.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, I have forgotten.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many people from the installation company came?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was mostly two people. They were parking their car there, and would go to the place where the digester was installed, and then tell us one or two things.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, it was two people?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was a mostly two people; sometimes, they would come three people.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Do you remember what they told you, or what they were telling you?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I remember they told us to dig a hole, and then they gave us the dimensions for the hole. They also told us how to make feedstock to start up the digester. After feeding the digester, the bag got full. Then, after some days, they came and I recall they asked us to switch on the stove after they showed us how to. Afterwards, they took pictures, videos, and left.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: This was 2017, right?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, that was 2017. But, after sometime, some people came and they asked us questions regarding its functionality. We told them that biogas is good, but our digester was going off whenever the sun disappeared. Sometimes, it was happening whilst cooking, so we had to start fire again on firewood. Then, they said they were going to come with solar panels to supplement biogas. Then, they got in their cars and picked papers for us to sign. So, we signed and since then they have never come back.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How long did it take to build?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It took about a month for everything to be done, from the first came to the day we started it. The first week, we dug the hole. After that, we sourced fresh cow manure and made the feedstock. I have to tell you, mister, it was a heavywork (laughs) - to feed the bag with manure was not easy at all.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, I can imagine. Let's start with digging. How many people from your side took part in the building process?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was two people, my husband and one hired worker.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much did you pay him?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: He charged us K3000.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Who collected water?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I did that myself with the help of my three kids.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where did you get the cow manure?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We got it from the cow house of our chief; when we went there, he showed us fresh manure in the cow house, and we got it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, he didn't say no?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, they knew that we wanted to use the manure for biogas, so there wasn't any problem. So, when we got it we made feedstock for the digester.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much manure did you get?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We got 6 or 10 bags of cow manure, if I have forgotten. To this, we added 12 buckets (20 liters) of water separately from the ones we added to the cow manure for mixing.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How were you selected as a beneficiary?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Biogas needs hard working people, so the chiefs and community development committee saw that we are hard workers, and chose us - I just think so. A person who is not hard working or committed cannot manage it. It's involving. It's not easy to handle fresh manure daily. So, I accepted it, because the project was to develop the community. I liked it also because it presented us an opportunity of cooking without firewood. We simply switched it on whenever we wanted to cook. It was very easy and fast to use. And, many people were coming to appreciate the digester .So we were simply telling them to come at lunch when the sun was brightest, and make a cooking exhibition. It was good and the people liked it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you know about biogas before?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Not at all. We learned about this when the senior chief communicated to the people that an organization was coming to install digesters to certain individuals, and that we were beneficiaries. So, we accepted it.

interviewer: What procedures or steps did the chief take to select the beneficiaries?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The chiefs called us for a community meeting and briefed as about the project. The communication at the meeting was that running a digester is very involving, so hard working and committed people would be chosen. So, people were choosing amongst themselves who they thought would manage it. Then, they would ask the chosen person, if he or she was willing to accept.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did people react? Didn\`t people feel jealousy and bitter after not being selected?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, it was fine.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay. You had the right to accept it, why did you accept to build it here?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The people here did not know about it, so they explained that it is used for cooking, and you don't need firewood when you have it. They also explained that it helps people to save money especially those that buy charcoal. Then, they told us that we would learn more from the project implementers when they came.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were your expectations?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I expected it to last longer. I thought I could be using it today. And, if it had worked longer, many people would have adopted it here. We liked it because it was fast cook on, and it prevented people from searching for firewood. So, it gave us rest and peace, and we liked it a lot. It was good. And, again, I'm sure, if the project implementers worked with us to the point where we could run it on our own, many people would have adopted and valued it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You mentioned that at the community meeting you were told by the community leaders that you would learn more from the project implementers. What did they tell you? What did they tell you to expect from this?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They told us a lot. First, they told us that we would use it for cooking. They also went on to say that, it's like electricity so we would use it as a source of energy for our TVs. and charging phone batteries. It was a lot.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What kind of training did you receive?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We didn't have any training.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: If you didn't receive training, then how were you able to switch it on and off?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It wasn't training, but when they came, they just told us instructions. For example, they showed us a button for switching it on and off. They also told us how to make feedstock. So if there was training, maybe I have forgotten it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: No, you haven't forgotten. That was it. How did you meet your energy needs before the intervention?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I use firewood.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where do you get firewood?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We get it from a very far place.

interviewer: How far? I mean, if you leave at 6:00 in the morning, what time do you return?
interviewee: We return around this time.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Around 2 PM?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, it's very far. We pass the houses you see there, and get to the mountains. That's far.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How often do go there?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Maybe in a week we go there once because it's far. And, when go there our legs hurt. We don't go there sick or when we don\`t have the strength, because going there you are okay could be disastrous. So, when we are not ready for it, we just look for small pieces of wood around. But, we are forced to go there, when we need good firewood.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Are there forest officials there?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, but it's not as if we go into the mountain to cut trees. We just go there to pick dry wood or we get firewood around the mountain.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Do you use charcoal?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: To use charcoal it means you have money. We are poor, so we don't use charcoal.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Do you differentiate cooking on biogas from using firewood?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: In terms of taste, there is no difference. But, when you cook on the firewood, we sweat a lot because of the flames. While when we cooked on biogas, we didn't sweat because flames are concentrated on the pot. Another thing is that, biogas doesn't produce smoke; it's clean. So, after cooking on biogas a person doesn't smell or the clothes don't smell smoke-like.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Were you using cow manure from your cows or you were getting manure from other people for feeding it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We had our cows, but it wasn't enough. So, we were getting cow manure from other people too.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many cows did you have that time?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I had five cows.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Do you still have them? I haven't seen any.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, they have gone out for grazing.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you manage you feedstock before the intervention?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were just waiting for the manure to dry, and then take it to the farm.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, some people have told me that they don't use manure
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Maybe, on that side of Tengani, but here we apply manure as fertilizer. Even agriculture workers advise us to use it. They also educate us how to make fertilizer from manure. We make fertilizer in two ways. First, we bury it a pit and cover it. Or, we just pile the manure and turn it regularly for some time, and then take it to the farm. It's only people who are lazy that don't use manure. Of course, the soil is good, but it still needs additional fertilizer.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You said that to start it you used six bags of cow manure and more than 12 buckets. How long did it take to start up after feeding it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It didn't take long to start up. After feeding the bag, it got full, and they told us that it was enough to start it up. Then, they assembled the pipes and stoves, and told us to switch on and it worked.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How long did it take to produce fire from the period you fed it with the initial feedstock?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The whole thing took a month from feeding it to starting up. And throughout this time, we were communicating and updating them as we had their numbers, and when we finished we called them and they came.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, that's like you waited for 2 weeks or so, since it took you a week or so to dig and make the initial feedstock. How did you use gas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I used it for cooking one.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where did you get water?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We got it from the borehole.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How far is it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It's far.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Like how far?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: One is close to the chief's house. That's the closest.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: That's like 500 - 700 meters. How many people stay here?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: 6 people.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were the operation requirements?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The digester only needed feedstock of cow manure and water.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you prepare the feedstock?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: First in the morning, we used to go and collect fresh cow manure from the cow house. Then, we placed manure in a bucket and filled it up with water, and then mix until the slurry was smooth. After that, we used to pour it in the digester.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Nice, how did you mix it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We used bare hands to collect, crush manure lumps and mix the feedstock. Then, we would use a stick to mix it further. But, most of the time we used hands because you can't collect fresh manure without hands, so we proceeded with hands as well.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you feel disgusted or unhealthy?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Not at all. We were simply collecting manure; add water, and then mix, done! Take another set, put it in a bucket and add water, and then mix. Done! So on and so on. (In the background) \[A six to ten years girl said she helped in feeding\]

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I heard this one saying she helped preparing feedstock. Were the kids doing that too?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah! They know how to make feedstock.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, they wanted it bad. How often did you feed it and in what quantity?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: If we wanted to boost it up we used to feed it with 2 buckets of cow manure and water. We used to skip a day to feed it again.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So the 2 buckets was ready prepared feedstock, not just cow manure?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, that was after mixing cow manure with water. We used to see the thickness of slurry before stopping adding water to the manure.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What was your feedstock like?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We didn't make it too watery; it was a little bit thick.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did they give you the ratio of the feedstock?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, we were simply looking at the thickness of the feedstock. And, after the thickness was good, we fed it in the digester.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Some people soak the manure the day before feeding the digester. Were you doing that?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I can only imagine a person using dry manure to do that. As for us, we used fresh cow manure throughout, so there was no need to soak it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you never fed it with dry manure or do any pre-treatment?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They told us to use fresh manure all the times, so everything was done on the spot and no pre-treatment was required.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you feel about feeding it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was a tough job especially the day we made feedstock to start it up. On the other days, I collected manure together with the children and my husband was preparing the feedstock itself, so it was not that tough. After, we fed it, the digester bag was getting full and it worked fine. But, I have to say the first day of feeding to start it was very hectic.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Your digester had 2 big white pipes, one an inlet and the other an outlet. How was the outlet like?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, it had 2 pipe white pipes. And, I think the outlet was more elevated than inlet.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I mean, did you dig a hole at the outlet? And, did you get digestate at the outlet?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, it was making a huge boiling-like sound most of the times it was releasing the digestate.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you put a bucket at the outlet? Or, you simply dug a hole for collection of the digestate?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: At the outlet pipe, we dug a hole to collect digestate. So, when we fed the digester, the digestate was failing into the hole.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, what were you doing with the digestate?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They told us that it could be used as fertilizer for crops and vegetables. But, we made a very big hole, so the hole didn't fill up to collect and use it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you line the hole?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, it was just a hole.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Wasn't it bringing mosquitoes?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, we didn't see any mosquitoes in the house. Maybe, it didn't come because the hole was deep, and the digestate was not on the surface or close to the surface.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were the maintenance requirements?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They gave us their numbers and told us to call them whenever there was a problem, so they could come to troubleshoot and solve the problem.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Like what problem?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Any kind of problem. For example, if it wasn't producing gas or when there was a gas leak. So, we were supposed to call them whenever there was a problem of any kind.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did it ever develop a problem that you called them?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No. We never called them.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, did it meet your needs?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No! Like I said, when we fed it, we couldn't use it in the morning. We had to wait up to 10 or 11 AM, when the sun was out to use it. Even then, when we did put a pot on the stove, it was going off once the sun disappeared. Then, we could start looking for firewood to start up fire and continue cooking. The next day, I would put a pot of beans, and then the sun goes and I had to start firewood to continue cook. Then, I was fed up, I was like what type of cooking is this, and then I abandoned it. I stopped feeding it, and it stopped working as well. That's how it was!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How long did it take you to say this is enough?
