interviewee: **Interviewee**: I expected that after installation and upon completing everything, I would be able to use it for cooking.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were you told me to expect from the digester by the installers?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The installers told us that the digesters were forcooking.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Apart from this, what else were you told to expect?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Apart from cooking, if I'm not mistaken, they told us that it could be used for lighting, and as a source of fertilizer.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where did they say the manure was going to come from?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They said that digesters produces digestate, and we only needed to collect and use it as fertilizer.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you ever use the digestate, or for lighting?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, it never occurred.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I've seen that one woman accepted it, and it's not too far from this here...
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Oh yeah. That's Nyama Village. So, when the people of Nyama Village sat down to choose a beneficiary, she was chosen. As for Mkasaulo Village, nobody accepted it and that's why Group Village Headman (GVH) \[name redacted\] took it. And the question you are trying to put out, we got asked at the T/A\`s meeting place. They asked us why we chiefs got the digesters. Didn't we have people who could have got the digesters? So, we told them everything that had happened, and that people refused to accept the digester. So, we got asked the same question (laughs)

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Yeah, honestly it doesn't look good because it may seem as you used your powers or your position to get the digesters.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (Laughs) Yeah, but we told them that people had denied it, and we couldn\'t have afforded to let it go to another area.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: When I look at the three of you; Chief \[name redacted\], you and the woman, I can't say you used it; it all ended in total failure. But, the woman at least did better than you. Why did the chiefs fail miserable, when you were supposed to be exemplary as leaders?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Interesting... mm-mmh... In a community setting like this, we do have people who are smarter than chiefs. Some people do things better than the Chiefs, and are even more successful in wealth. It happens, that's life. But in this instance, we felt because they didn't give us a full set of the equipment - they only came once. As for that woman, she was given everything.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What kind of training did you receive?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: If I ever learned about biogas, it was at the community meeting at the TAs meeting place. But, there was no special training for the beneficiaries.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What did you learn at the TA\'s meeting place?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They only ask us to take good care of the digesters and that it's helpful. So, they told us how useful it is, and that it needs manure to work, and also that the installers would teach us more about the digesters.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were you told in regards to taking care of it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They told us that when the installers come and finish everything they would tell us how to manage it in order to keep it safe and long. But, they didn't tell us how we were supposed to take care of it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why do you think of the installers never came back?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: mm-mmh, I don't know. I heard at GVH \[name redacted\] place they didn't finish everything too.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Yeah, they only brought a digester and a pipe. But, after some time, some people came to follow up on the digester. Did they come here?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, they didn't. Maybe they thought it wasn't necessary to come here after what happened at Mpita's place.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Yeah, you mentioned that you accepted this because you wanted to use it for cooking. Secondly, you wanted other people to learn it, so that they could appreciate and adopt it later. Apart from these, is there any other reason why you accepted it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Also, when I looked at the environment, it's trees which makes the environment flourish, so I wanted to reduced the cutting down of trees and make the world a better place. Also, I feel like if we are going to continue cutting trees as we are, we are not going to find firewood for cooking in the near future. So to avoid that, I decided to accept the digester.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: The environment is flouring because of tree, could you please elaborate on that.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I'm saying the environment flourishes with trees because we get rains because of trees. Of course, it's God who provides rain, but for that to happen you need trees to facilitate the process. Thus, if we cut trees and use it for silly thing, the amount of rain decreases as well.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, how did you make your energy needs before the intervention?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: That time I was cooking with firewood, but it was a struggle as firewood is not easy to find. Sometimes, my wife was using dry pigeon plants as firewood. But, we were luck that time because a certain NGO came and encouraged us to plant private trees. So, we get firewood from the private trees.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What is the name of this organization, and what was their project like?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Every year we do have a tree-planting program, which is spearheaded by government forest officials with funding from a certain NGO. At this tree planting session, we plant trees at our community forest and also people are given free seedlings of tree to plant for personal use. So, some people have personal woodlot, which they get firewood from.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay nice. How do people benefit from the community forest?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Sometimes the whole community is asked to go to the forest take care of it, and then people get dry fallen wood, which they use as firewood in their homes.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Nice. How did you manage your feedstock before the intervention?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Now that I don't have goats, I'm struggling because I only rely on inorganic fertilizer. When I had goats, I was only buying one bag of inorganic fertilizer then I was mixing it with goat manure to make two bags of fertilizer. To make this, you only need to mix one bag of inorganic with goat manure and add yeast, or baking soda or ash, then put it in a plastic bag for a week. After a week, you find the goat manure completely broken down and ready to be used as fertilizer. You only need to be careful when you are opening the plastic bag because the heat that comes out of it is intense, it can even affect your eyes if you are not careful (laughs). This type of fertilizer is effective and once you have it, you can't bother to buy fertilizer from the shops.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, where did you learn this?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We learnt this from a certain NGO.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What's the name of this NGO?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Mm-hmm, I have forgotten its name.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What about agriculture extension workers?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Oh yeah, they also teach us this.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Let's try to see what transpired from this digester though it never worked. First, which materials were you given?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I was given a digester bag and two white pipes as an outlet and inlet.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you get the material yourself? Or, they brought it here?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I went myself to collect the equipment on a bicycle.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: They didn't bring the equipment?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, they didn't. I got it myself from the agriculture office at Nsanama.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did all the beneficiary got the equipment by themselves?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I remember we got it ourselves -- I haven't forgotten. I took it myself.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why didn't you get all the equipment, for example, the stove and other pipes?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They didn't give us those. They said they would bring the equipment themselves. No beneficiary got all those things that day.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you take the equipment first? Or, the installers came first?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We took the materials first, and then they came here to advise us on how to dig the hole.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How long did it take?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They came before 2 weeks, I think

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So on the day the installers came, what did you do?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We started digging the hole, and it took us 2 days.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you place the bag on your own?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, the installers came.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I hope you also fed it that day.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, they guided us how to make feedstock, and then they told us they would come back to assemble it and teach us how to operate it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much feedstock did you feed it with?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They advised us to feed it with 2bags (50kg) of manure, if not more.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: And water too I guess.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much water did you add, and where did you get it from?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I got the manure from my animal house, and I got the water from the borehole.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Like how far from here?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Our community borehole is not far from our house. It's about 400 meter.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you fed the feedstock into the digester?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much water did you add to the feedstock?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We added 4 or 5 buckets (20 liter), and after a week, the bag got full.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: After this what happened?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: After we fed the bag, it started inflating. But, it was not completely assembly as other pipes were not there. Then, after we saw the installers were not coming, and that the feedstock was producing strong odor, we decided to remove the digester.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I thought when you fed it, the inlet and outlet pipes were covered, so how was it producing odor?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes, the pipes had covering. But, after some time, I decided to go and take out the coverings and that's when I smelled the odor. And, that's when I knew the inside was not good - rotten. After this, I wanted to call them, but I didn't do so as I had no contacts of them.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: When the installers were leaving, when did they tell you that they were going to come back?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They left on the 15^th^ or so of month, and they told us that they would come at the end of the month to assemble the remaining equipment.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: When did you open the covering, and why?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: After I saw that two or three months had passed, I decided to check it out, because I was like they are not coming back.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: After feeding it the first time, did you ever feed it again?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, I knew that even I feed it nothing would happen because I knew that the installers were not coming again -- so there was no need.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were operation requirements?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They told us that it's easier for people who have cows to run it, as manure is not a problem. But, for us since we had no cows, we would use goat manure to start it up, so it was going to take a lot of effort and time to gather. Then, there was no need to worry because we would be feeding it with small quantities of feedstock.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: After starting it up, how much feedstock were you supposed to feed it up with and how often?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They didn't tell us that.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did they tell you how to make feedstock?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were the maintenance requirements? Did they say anything about repairs?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They told us that after installation they would give us their contact to call them whenever there was a problem.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So they didn't give you their numbers, but you expected to get their numbers after commissioning?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, but they didn't come again to commission it (laughs)

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why do you think they never come back?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: That I don't know.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Or, do you think they didn't come because they saw that you couldn't manage it to the extent of thinking that returning to assemble it was simply a waste of time. What do you think?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, goat manure is not a problem in this community. People can't deny me goat manure. So, on my part, manure wasn't a problem. Even when I don't have enough inorganic fertilizer, I go around asking for goat manure and people give me without challenges.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: My next question was to ask you if it met your needs, but to ask that question would be wrong. What are your cooking needs?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I just want to cook at least 3 times a day.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Many things happened with this digester, when you look back, what were the challenges?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The challenge with this digester is that it didn't work, and I was very saddened by that.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you follow up? I mean, did you inform the TA or Senior Chief?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I informed the Senior Chief, but not the TA. I think, I was wrong on that. Maybe, he could have followed up the matter.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What did you tell the Senior Chief and what did he say?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I told him that the installers were not coming, and he just said it was hard to follow up since we had no contacts. So, we were lost and there was nothing we could have done.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You have admitted that you don't know how to read and write. So, what I have here is information regarding problems associated with digesters, their causes and related solutions. What do you think of the information and do you think it would have helped in your case?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It would have helped.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How and why?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It would have helped us because it could have given us clues on what to do. But, the information should have been given to us after installation, and not before it was not fully installed because we could have done nothing with it. So, maybe they didn't give us this information because they weren't done with the installation.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What is the current state of your digester?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Honestly speaking, the digester bag is damaged. I should not lie to you because it won't do us any good, it is broken.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Do you have the pipes?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, we still have the white pipes.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What about the bag?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It's what I said it's damaged.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I mean, how? Or, what is the extent of the damage?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was eaten by termites, and it was damaged in the house by rats too.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, you mean termites can eat that hard thing?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeaaah, termites were eating it up! And, even if you can see the bag you can know that termites were eating it up.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you remove ii?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: After a year when we saw the installers were not coming, we removed it, and that's when we noted that it was being eaten by termites. Then, we got it to the storeroom and there too rats were eating it up.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What happened to the manure that was inside?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: After we removed it we just disposed it anyhow because didn't know it's use.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: so, you didn't use it as fertilizer?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, we didn't.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I can see you are using the digester bag as a roofing sheet.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, I just decided to use it that way after finding no real use for it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I have also seen you are using it as a makeshift door for your pit latrine.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: That's true... it's not like after I got it out I sold it, no! I didn't thought about selling it (laughs)

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) Can a person buy that, for what?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (laughs) Aah, it's useless

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why didn't you sell it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It's not good for a chief to sell government property. I mean, what if other people see you, then how would you discipline them (Laughs). So, we should be the first ones to show respect to other people's property, so that others can learn from us too.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What happened to your digesters is a pity, that shouldn't have happened. It's making laugh at times because what happened was bizarre. In your opinion, why would an organization send people to do a job and then stop in the process?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I don't know. But, in my head sometimes, I'm not judging anyone though, I think the installers decided to sell the equipment somewhere else. I do think so. I mean, the way we talked the time they came, I didn't think more than 4 years would pass without returning. God forbid, I think that the boys who came to install the digesters sold some of the equipment. Honestly, I did think the boys did sell the equipment somewhere, and I was saddened by it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Yeah, it could be possible. I mean, where is the equipment? Now how do you meet your energy needs? Do you still use the firewood and dry pigeon peas plants?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, it's still the same.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Now you don't have goats or any livestock, right?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I don't keep any livestock now.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much did the reactor cost?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They didn't tell us. Maybe if they had come to commission it, they would have told us.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: And they didn't tell you who provided the funds, right? And, it's not the government, right?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you contribute anything in kind?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, we contributed nothing\... Frankly speaking, we didn't contribute anything\... Of course, it's been a long time, but I can certainly say we didn't contribute anything.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So if you ever spent anything on it, then it\`s was just the energy
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Right!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Is it two of you, who dug the hole?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was me together with my two grandsons. So, it was three of us.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You said you did put the digester in the hole, was the hole lined?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, they didn't say anything about that.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I've heard some people were told to find sand, and bricks, and that the installers promised to provide cement, so that they could line the hole in which the digester was placed.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I have heard they did that to some people, and they never brought the cement. This clearly show that they stole cement -- I feel bitter about those guys -- and If you were them, I would have asked " is this how you conduct yourself?" The government want the livelihood of people from rural communities to change and you are robbing us (laughs heavily).

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) Oh, you were robbed?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (laughs) Obviously!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: If you are certain that you were robbed, why didn't you take the issue somewhere, for example, the police or any other relevant government authority?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It never crossed our mind. That's why I always say education is good because it makes people became far-sighted. Of course, I'm a chief, but I'm not educated. I just use God's given knowledge and wisdom. That's why most things do not work for us. And, that's why I encourage me children to go to school. I don't want them to suffer like me, and that's why I allow myself to do menial works to gain something, so that they should go to school.... I do feel pain for being uneducated!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I like the desire you have for children, do that, and never slow down; you will gain great rewards someday.... So, you think if you were educated, this wouldn't have happened?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, that wouldn't have happened because I would have pressed them to finish this. The problem is that I only have natural intelligence. But, I feel lucky that I'm a chief and I'm able to connect with intellectuals.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) so you only have natural wisdom...
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (laughs) that's what I use -- I use natural intelligence, and the knowledge that I gain from meetings, trainings and conferences to lead the people without troubles.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What special items had to be imported from another country?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: When I saw it, I knew that it was from another country.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What did you see?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I mean, we were given the digesters to try them here, so I believe someone from outside the country wanted to try the digesters in Malawi -- That's what I thought!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What do you think who brought the digesters here in Malawi would say about what happened?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It could be that the project implementers gave them the report, and they want to verify the reports through you... so they have sent you to investigate the matter to see what really happened, so we can't hide or hold any information from you, because if we do that it will not do anyone good (laughs).

interviewer: **Interviewer**: That's true. If it could have worked as they said do you think it could have saved you any money?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It could have basically helped us in cooking and in saving trees as well, so these have serious economic implications.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What is your opinion of biogas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I feel like I have unfinished business with the digester, though it may seem that I didn't take good care of it by taking it out and use it for other purposes. I did that against my will and I was forced to do that because I was just seeing the bag doing nothing. I removed it because a lot of time had pass, so I thought they had abandoned it and it was useless. But, my position on biogas is that it is good especially when I consider how populated we have become, we really need an alternative to firewood because it's no sustainable, and it's not good for the environment too.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: If you could have designed your own waste of energy intervention, what would you have chosen instead?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Instead of biogas, I would have chosen a good solar system to use it for cooking. I think solar system can help a lot. I can't say electricity because it needs money. For example, in my area, we have electricity lines, but I'm not connected because it needs money.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, you electricity in your area?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, we have it, but my house is not connected because I'm poor and can't manage to pay connection fee.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, I see. Last words, before we conclude the interview.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: You should help us.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How? Should I find the person who didn't bring the materials? (laughs)
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (Laughs) help us get solar system or even another biogas.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I get you, thanks a lot chief.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (laughs) I thank you for coming too.

interviewer: Where did the digester of originate from?
interviewee: It came with people from University; I don't know the name of the University thought. The people told me that they were going to put a stove in the kitchen, and that I had to dig a hole for the digester. They also told me that the digester would use animal manure, for example, goat, pig and cow manure. They further explained that I would be able to get energy for cooking as well as fertilizer from the digester.

interviewer: The installers mentioned that they came from a university, but you have forgotten the university. Was it Poly, Mzuzu or Chanco?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I didn't pay much attention to where exactly they were coming from, but I was more focused on the technology they were bringing here. So, just like many villagers would do, I simply accepted the technology without asking questions.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Who funded it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They didn't explain that. They just told me that they were going to install a technology that produces gas for cooking. Then they told me that they would line the hole for the digester bag and another hole with a brick wall, and that they had people who would do that. After that, they also mentioned that I would be collecting manure from the other hole, which I could use as fertilizer. When I heard about the fertilizer, I called three other chiefs to come and join me in digging the hole, so that they could be getting manure from the digester as well. After we dug the hole, we waited for the installers to come but they never came. They only gave me the things you took pictures of \[a digester bag and one PCV Pipes (110mm)\] on the day they asked us to dig the hole.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many people from the installation company came?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I think it was four or three people. After this, years went by and five other people visited the digester too.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What was the purpose of their visit?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They told me that their records showed that I was a beneficiary of a digester, so they wanted to follow up on the digesters. Then, I told them that certain people came and left a digester bag and one white pipe. But, they didn't even place the digester bag in the digester hole. I took them to the hole to see it and they took pictures. Then, I told them that I felt like I was robbed and things didn't make sense to me. I also asked if the same had happened to other beneficiaries. Then, they laughed and said that's why they had come to find out what happened to the digesters. Then, I said okay and I asked if they would bring the remaining parts in the future. Then, they told me that they would come back, but before leaving, they stood on that mango tree and asked me to give them their privacy. They stood there for 10 -- 15 minutes, and then they told me that they were going, and would come back at some point. Since, then they have never returned and I have never heard of biogas until I got your call the other time, and talked and provided you directions and all that.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What do you mean when you say you were robbed?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They took advantage of me and deprived me of what I was supposed to get. They were cunning that I shouldn't get the digester. Let's say they did want me to get the digester, so they stripped and deprived me of the digester.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Then, why did they give you some other things if they didn't want you to get the digester?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, sometimes you may think you are given meat when it's just a bone! Then, you release later that it's a bone and not meat!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) Oh
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (laughs) I thought I had meat and I started chewing it, but then I bite it and found out that it was hard bone.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) It's common to see chiefs mobilizing community people to help them when there is a project, why did you call other chiefs, not just community people?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It's not as it was in the past where chiefs would just choose people to do certain things for them. Of course, some chiefs to do that, but I'm not that type of person. So, I called the chiefs because I wanted them to inform their subjects that when the digesters become fully functional to bringing manure, so that they could also be getting fertilizer out of it too.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, you wanted to make it a community thing, nice. What was your role?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I took the role of a "treasurer". I accepted to take care of digester so that other community members would gain processed fertilizer from it by providing raw animal manure ... So, I can say I was a "treasurer" because I was a custodian of the digester!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, that's one part. The other thing you mentioned that you took part in the dig of the hole together with other three chiefs. How big was the whole and how long did it take you to dig it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The hole was 3 meter deep and 1.5 meters wide, if I'm not mistaken, and it took us 2 or 3 days. So, after we dug it we waited for them to come and advise us, if the hole was sufficient or not.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you get the bag and that white pipe?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The digester bag and the white pipe came before we dug the hole. On that day, they advised us how to dig the hole, and then they gave us the bag and the pipe. Then, they told us that the pipes were not sufficient, so they would come back with pipes and bags of cement to line up the hole with brick wall. So, that day I kept the bag and pipe waiting for them to come back at some point.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, I get it.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: And that's when the next people came to follow up the digesters. So, you told the same story.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So the bag was not installed in the hole? You did put the bag in the hole?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, we don't know how to do that, so didn't do anything afterwards. And the time they were leaving, they told us that they would bring a builder to line the wall and place the bag, and then assemble the whole digester.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) and they didn't come?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (laughs) yeah, they didn't come.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you follow up?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Where would we have gone?

interviewer: **Interviewer**: At the T/A (Traditional Authority)
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were 3 or 10 beneficiaries, if I heard that one had followed up, I would have followed up too.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, I see. In this village, that you have many people and a lot of households, how were you chosen as a beneficiary?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The digester was not given to me directly by the T/A. The digester was first given to Senior Chief \[name redacted\], who the identified me as a beneficiary because I'm a chief. He chose me so that I could use it for generating fertilizer. And, if I had wished too, I would have given it to an ordinary person too. But, I thought that it wouldn't have been in safe hands. I believed that an ordinary person would have sold it to bicycle taxi people to make seats, or to people who make beehive boxes. You have found it today because it was in safe hands. If it was given to an ordinary person, you wouldn't have found anything. If I was not a chief, I could have sold it way bag (laughs).

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) how can people use that in a beehive box?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Because it is good plastic, people use that to make a cover for the beehive to prevent water from getting inside.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you didn't sell it or didn't make a beehive box, I have seen you have one, because you are a chief. You wanted to save face? (Laughs)
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (Laughs) and that's why it's still here.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) I understand you got the digester because you thought if it was given to an ordinary person, it was not going to be safe. But, surely, there is another reason you accepted it. Why did you accept to build it here apart from what you have told me?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: When we want to grow maize we start by digging holes and then put animal manure to act as fertilizer months prior to planting. We use manure here because the soil is so degraded and without doing that, we can't harvest maize. So, when I was told that the digester produce fertilizer I had no choice, but to take it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Some people have told me that animal manure is not a good fertilizer, what's your take?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It helps a lot; what you do is, you mix 20 kg of ash with 20 kg of animal manure, then add baking soda of K50 or K100 (50g) and yeast of K50 or K100 too. Then, add water and mix again until the mixture gets wet as mortar. After that, you put the mixture in a plastic bag, and then cover it with a sack bag. After a week, you take it out and add 5kg of inorganic fertilizer and mix as the first time. Then, you put back the mixture in a plastic bag, and then cover it with a sack bag and wait for a week or so. After that, the manure becomes effective as inorganic fertilizer and the maize you get is the same, as you would get after using inorganic fertilizer. And with that manure, you don't whine when you are left out of the agriculture subsidy program.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Well explain. How did you learn this?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We have agriculture extension workers who teach us this, and they call this type of fertilizer "Whitman". So clever people make and use this type of fertilizer, and others who are lazy they don't. But, this type of fertilizer is good.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I didn't know that it\`s name is "Whitman". Did you know anything about biogas before?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No. I learnt about biogas the time they told me that they were going to bring it here, but I haven't been given up to date.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What did they say about it? When you asked them, what did they say it is?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I didn't ask them. They told me about it without asking them, and they told me that with biogas I would be able to use it for cooking and a source of fertilizer for vegetables and maize.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, how was the selection process like?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I don\'t know how Senior Chief \[name redacted\] was chosen, and how he chose me. I don't know if he was chosen by the T/A - I don't know. I just know that the instrallers we are directed here by Senior Chief \[name redacted\].

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were your expectations? First time I have seen that you expected to use it for cooking. Secondly, you expected people to be getting manure from it. How was this going to happen? What was your plan?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: After installation, I expected to go to training. Then after the training, I would have made this a community thing by mobilizing all the chiefs under me to sensitize their people about biogas. Also, I would have asked everyone who had livestock, not to throw away manure, but to bring it here so that they could get processed manure from the digester after sometime. I wanted to do this to develop my community.

interviewer: **Interviewer**:That was a brilliant idea. If it could've worked, a lot of people would have benefited.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I'm a chief who is known for spearheading community development initiatives. I remember one time I went to Hippo Lodge for stakeholders meeting, and I was applauded for my works. The people there commented that I'm doing a good job, and that they thought I was a big tall person because of my works. But, I'm just a short and slim old person. So, I thanked them very much for the compliments - and it's a good thing to do the good work because when you die you are rewarded by God afterwards for caring for his people.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, nice. What religion are you?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I'm a Sunni Muslim.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, nice. What kind of training did you receive? Did you have a pre-installation training?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, we didn't have anything in regards to biogas

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Were you told about training?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, they didn't. I think training would have only happened after installation. After installation that\'s when they would have said let\'s go to Hippo Lodge or any other extravagant place for training (laughs).

interviewer: **Interviewer**:You have been in some nice place, uh.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (laughs) yeah, and I thank the railway company here for that. They have got me to some nice places and they even provide fertilizer to people.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you meet your energy needs before the intervention?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Here in Mkasaulo and Malawi at large, when we want to cook anything, whether it is sweet potato or cassava, we use traditional three-stove-cooking fire.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where did you get firewood?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: In the past, firewood was not hard to find. That time we used to go to the game reserve to steal firewood, as it was not fenced. Some used to go to the mountains and bush lands to get wood. But, now firewood is scarce because of high population growth, so we use maize cobs and firewood. Luckily, we have now energy efficient stoves that use less firewood. With that, only three sticks of firewood are enough to cook without problems.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Do you buy wood?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I shouldn't lie, we don't.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How far are your firewood sources?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It's very far to go to the mountains to source firewood. As for me, I thank the European Union for giving me trees, which I get firewood from.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did that happen?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The European Union came here with a tree-planting project where people were given tree to plant, and they made a community woodlot. So, every (group) village here has a forest, and the people have trees too.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: For a digester to work it needs animal manure. Did you have livestock that time?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes, I had goat manure. And, many other people in this community have goats too.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many goats did you have?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I had 15 goats. But, people were stealing from me, so I transferred the remaining two goats I had to my mother's house. But, if you another digester could come, it wouldn't be a problem because I can easily get manure from other people or even buy. It's common to get manure for free because people find removing manure from cow houses a difficult task, so when you offer to do that, it's appreciated a lot.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) how would someone steal from a chief?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Thieves don't steal without using juju. They make you go to the farm and upon returning, you just find the doors open and your goats gone. They even kill the goat in the goat house without you even noticing. (Laughs)

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I thought that only happen to ordinary people not chiefs!
interviewee: **Interviewee**: You can't understand thieves; they steal from a highly guarded place and you wonder how what is even possible. So, if people are able to steal where there are guards, what more here.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: My next question was to ask you how it worked after commissioning. But apparently, that question can't be answered because it never worked - it was never installed.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It wasn't installed and they didn'tcome to line the hole. If it was installed and lined, then I would have been following up to see what was happening. Today, I don't say that I was given a digester, but I say some people came to me, so that I could keep a digester bag and a pipe safe for them. And, I haven't been paid for that service, so it's as if I have worked for nothing too.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: In your opinion, why was it not installed here?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I keep asking myself that question. Sometimes, I think it's because I'm a chief, so they thought that if I got it people would not benefit anything out of it. But, if they had told me that I was not supposed to get the digester, and an ordinary person from this community was suppose to get it, I would have given it up. And it's not like I wouldn't have benefited from that arrangement, no. I would have been going to that person as well to get manure from the digester. So, I accepted it because I'm old, so it was only necessary for me to stop going around searching for firewood to make life easy for me and my wife too.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So they thought if you get it other people wouldn't see its benefit, and maybe they didn't like how you were chosen. They thought it wasn't necessary for a chief to get it. So to make life easier for themselves, they just decided not give you the digester.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: On that, I totally agree. It could be that.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many people were expected to use the gas and fertilizer?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was four people.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I believe that even before installation, you were told what things you would require to operate it, and when you saw that you could manage to get the requirement, you accepted. What were the operation requirements?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They just told me that it would need feeding with animal manure, whether it is cow manure, goat manure, pig manure, or chicken manure.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: And water?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They didn\'t reach that stage. I think they would have told us about that at the training. After that time, we were only told to find animal manure.

interviewer: **Interviewer**:So they didn't tell you how prepare to cow manure?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They could have told me about that during a training at Hippo Lodge (laughs). And, we could have had our note pads writing everything down (laughs)

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So up to date that digester bag never got fed?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We never installed it, and we never fed it. After the installers gave me the bag, I just kept it in that white building.

interviewer: **Interviewer**:From this, I don't think my next set of question can be answered... I wanted to ask you if it met your needs and even challenges. Did they talk about maintenance?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I think they would have told us about repairs after it was installed after the training. They would have also given us their numbers to report any issues, but after installation.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: If it was installed, what would have been your cooking needs?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: To cook on it three times a day. First, I wanted to be able to cook breakfast in the morning. Then, cook lunch and supper before going to bed.

interviewer: **Interviewer**:What challenges did you in regards to this whole thing?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It hurts that we didn't have an opportunity to learn about it. The other thing is that the digester bag was damaged by termites.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How? Did you put it on the ground?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Initially, we kept the bag in the house but later found out that the rats were eating it up. So, we got it out and that's where termites started eating it up too.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you think it could be safe outside?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It's a thick plastic bag that cannot be damage by water, and it's not like I literally put it on the ground. I did lay some bricks on the ground, and then I placed the bag on top the bricks. And at that time, most of it had already been damaged by the rats, so I didn't care about it, and that's why I even put it outside.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What do you think of this information? Do you think it's helpful?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were supposed to learn this information at the training. What I mean is after installation, they were supposed to get all the beneficiaries, not just me, to training and teach us these things, so we could have operated and maintained it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: We are in September of 2022, let's suppose the people who gave you the digester bag and pipe call you, what would you say?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It's straightforward, I can simply ask them to tell me what stage of the project are they now? When are you coming? And then I would tell them that the digester bag was eaten by termites and rats. It's been a lot of years, is it 5 or 10 years? And, all the children that were born around that time have reached puberty stage now (laughs)... So, if I can have a chance to talk to them I would ask them to update me on the project, and to tell me if they would ever come again or not. And if they are coming, I could ask them to bring a new digester bag because the last one is broken, and to bring a stove and the remaining pipes as well.

interviewer: **Interviewer**:I have seen that you are using the digester bag on your pigeon house?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I had a thin black plastic sheet, but after strong wind, it was damaged. So I just decided to cut the digester bag and use it as roofing sheet for the pigeon house. And, it's better to keep it there because it can't be lost and it may be used as an evidence that I received a digester bag. I remember, I worked in the gold mines in South Africa, and to get new protective clothes you had to show the old protective clothes, and that's why I keep it too.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I've seen you have used some remaining part of it as a fence for cassava stalks?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes, one day I saw that rabbits were eating the cassava stalks from that edge of a corner, so I decided to put it around there and use it as a fence.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: We are going towards the end of the interview. How do you meet your energy needs now?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I get wood from the trees around my house and use it on the energy efficient stoves.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Now you don\'t have livestock. The only two goats you have you keep it at your mothers place\...
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I decided to put it there because I didn't want thieves to steal it, and give me a heart attack and die. So, if I want to make manure I go there to collect manure and make "Whitman" fertilizer.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much the reactor cost?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I wasn't told, but I think it's a lot of money. But, I can't know the actual amount though.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you contribute anything in kind?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Nothing, I only lost my energy on it without getting anything out. But, since it was dug within my compound, I can always use the hole as a refuse pit when I want to

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I have seen that you haven't covered it up..
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It's a big compound and it's outside the fences, so I have no problem with it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You said you didn't line the hole, right?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Do you think the reactor or the pipe was imported from another country?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Everything here in Malawi is imported from South Africa, Japan or China. Even the organizations that support us are from outside the country. Of course, we have our local organizations, but they also get funds from international organizations to survive.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you think it's from another country?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Certainly.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: If it had worked, do you think it would have helped you to save money?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: If it was installed properly and worked, chiefs especially those who weren't given would you have learnt about it here and eventually adopted it in their villages. And, also we could have create a community team to oversee its operation and even be responsible for managing and selling the fertilizer to other people, and also telling them about the digestate. So, in the end we could have made biogas known to so many people. It would have also brought money to the community, and the same money would have been used for repairs too.

interviewer: **Interviewer**:What is your opinion of biogas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Biogas seems to be a good thing and we would like to have it here. But, whoever is going to bring it here again shouldn't do thing unorganized and in haste. He should do it a way that it should work and help people. So, I would be happy if someone else gets it. Or, if they decided to bring it here, I can also be happy.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: When you say things should not be done in an organized manner and haste, what do you mean?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They should bring the bags, the pipes, line the hole and take us to Hippo View Lodge for training.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Last one. If you could have designed your own waste or energy intervention, what would you have chosen instead?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I choose a solar system, so that people who sell sweet beer (thobwa) can come here to keep their drinks in a refrigerator. Also, I would like people to come here and charge their cell phones, though I don't like cell phones because they perpetuate prostitution and are affecting cultural norms and practices. Nonetheless, I would choose a solar system because I can use it for lighting, while I'm using it for business in the afternoon.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Many thanks, do you have any last words?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I'm a chief of development, so if there's any type of developmental project consider me.

interviewer: Understood**.** Thanks for the interview.
interviewee: NA

interviewer: Thanks for granting us an interview. Since, the actual beneficiary has transferred to Chingale, Zomba, and her phone is not going through. You can answer for you sister, and where you don't have an answer, let me know to move to the next question. First question, where did this digester from?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I do not know who brought here.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many people were coming?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I do not know how many people are coming, but I was just seeing people carrying manure and all that.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: But, you saw the visitors?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many were they?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was three or four people, I think.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Do you know where the funds for the digester came from?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Mmmh, I do not know.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Before any development project, they always say the one responsible for funding the project, and in most cases it's the government or an NGO or even member of parliament, who funded this digester?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Mmmh, I don't know.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What was your role?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We sourced cow manure and water to make feedstock, and then we fed the reactor.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you have a cow house?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So where did you get the manure?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We asked from different people within the community.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Which houses?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We asked from that house, and we also asked from another family, but that one is very far.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Let us say more than 800 meters far together. Okay, where did you get water?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: There is a borehole there. It is about 100 meters away.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: That side where I passed by?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Let's say it is 200 meters... or 100 meters as you have said.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did people give you the cow manure for free, or you bought them?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It's true some people ask for money. However, the people here just give out for free.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I think they don't see value of it. In addition, people here don't really use manure as fertilizer. It's only a very few who use manure strictly as fertilizer here. So, people don't see value in it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why don\'t people using cow dung as fertilizer?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Maybe, we are not just used to it. Or, maybe we are used to inorganic fertilizers.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: During the time you were building it, how many people were involved?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was five people who were involved in sourcing and preparing feedstock, collecting water from the borehole; it was three females and two males.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you hire people to help you?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No

interviewer: **Interviewer**: We have many families in this community, how were you family selected as a beneficiary?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I don\'t know what the selection process was, but I think it's because we are very poor, and they wanted to improve our livelihood.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Some people have told me that there was a community meeting where community members chose the beneficiaries? What's your comment?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes, it's true. We had a community meeting and people were chosen there. Nevertheless, people got selected for a number of things, for instance, in our case I think we were chosen because we are poor, so they wanted our livelihood to change. Some were chosen because were hardworking and trustworthy, so people trusted them that they could manage the digester.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, did you know about biogas before?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We didn't know anything about biogas.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: On the day of choosing the beneficiaries, did you attend the meeting?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You had the right to say no. I have seen people chosen as village champions but refusing to take up the role, why did you accept it to be built here?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We found it to be a good thing; with it, we thought we could use it for cooking as well as lighting.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, what were you expectations?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I basically expected to use it for cooking as well as for lighting.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What kind of training did you receive?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: People at the community meeting were told that the beneficiaries would go for training, but it never materialized. I didn't go for training, but I don't know if others went.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you meet your energy needs before the Intervention?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We used to get wood from there bushes and mountains.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where is it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It's far

interviewer: **Interviewer**: If you go there at 6:00 in the morning, what time do you come back?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Maybe 2 or 3 in the afternoon.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How often do you go there?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I go there four times a month.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Is it for free?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What challenges do you encounter there?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It's just tiresome, as we carry heavy loads. It's very far; imagine we cross three rivers in the process.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What do you call a river here?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: "Mkuwu"

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I knew that you meant a river, though you didn't say it as we say it. We call it "Mtsinje"
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (Laughs heavily) yeah, it's "Nkuwu" here

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, it's far. What about forest officials?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We go there very early in the morning and we usually go Saturdays, and not during weekdays.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You have told me had no livestock, right?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Were there people who had cows that time, but weren't chosen?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, lots of them.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Some people who had cows were not picked in favor of people who had no cows. Why?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, people were chosen based on personality. Some people weren't given because people considered untrustworthy, so people thought they would sell it or something. Even some people who were considered rich did not get the digesters because people thought they would not value it, or would find it involving to the extent of not using it, and then continuing buying charcoal.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much manure did you start it up with?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I have forgotten how manure cow manure we used it to start it up. But, I think we use 50 buckets (20 liters) of water.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: That was a lot.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, if you ask anyone, who was involved in this would tell you that it was hard work. It wasn't easy to feed it the first time.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I believe you heard or you saw how it worked after commissioning. How did it work after commissioning?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It never worked at all.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Not even for a day?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I\'m not sure if it worked after installation. It never worked.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you intend to use the gas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was cooking only.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many people were intended to use the gas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were six people.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were operation requirements?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It required feeding with cow manure and water.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you prepare the feedstock?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was just like the first day; first we collected manure and placed it a bucket. Then, we used adding water and stir. We stirred the feedstock until the slurry was thick and smooth. After that, we used to pour the feedstock into the digester.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How often did you feed it and in what quantities?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I don't remember how often we feed it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Who is responsible for feeding it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was the mother and her son.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What did they say about feeding it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They said it was very tedious especially the first day.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were the maintenance requirements?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I don't know what the arrangement was like. But, I know that they didn't use it. I don't think people used it. It never worked.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were the challenges?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: She used to complain that it didn't work after all the effort she did put. I think that\`s the only challenge she had.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How would describe the current state of your digester?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: After sometime everything, for example, the digester bag and the pipes were taken inside to protect them from thieves.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: In your opinion, how did it reach this stage? Or, what caused it to fail?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The digesters failed because the installers did not follow up the project after installation of the digesters. They just planted the digester and disappeared. So, it was hard for the people to maintain it. In addition, she found it difficult to keep the bag outside since she is woman, so she just decided to hire people too take it out.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How does she meet her energy needs now that it\'s not working!
interviewee: **Interviewee**: She uses firewood.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Charcoal?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: People who use charcoal are considered rich. Charcoal is not for everyone. People sell charcoal at K2000 a bag that doesn't even last a week. So, she uses firewood only.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: We are going towards the end of the interview. How much did the reactor cost?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We don't know.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you contribute anything in kind?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We only contributed cow manure, water. The rest of the things came with the installers.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Was there any masonry work that was involved?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, the hole was simply dug without and it had no brick wall around it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What special item that had to be imported from another country?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We don't know whether it's from Malawi or not. We don't know.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, we are remaining with two questions. What is your opinion of biogas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Biogas is a good thing. It is good source of energy. It\'s good because it free. You don't need money to spend on anything.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: But, it never worked...
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It never worked. But, they way they explained it; one has to say biogas is good.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What is it that they explained that you thought this thing is good?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The fact that it makes people without searching for firewood is very crucial. Another thing is that, you don't spend money on it since it uses things you don\`t buy, for example, cow manure.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why do you think it failed?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It failed because there was no close monitoring of the project itself; Also, they were taking long to offer support on every phase of it; they took time to come after feeding it, and they never came after installation as well. After commissioning, they were supposed to come and see how people were faring, but they never came. That's why it failed.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: If you could have designed your own waste or energy intervention, what would you have chosen instead?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Aah, I don't know, maybe a solar system because as it can be used for cooking as well as lighting. Alternatively, the installers simple need to install biogas properly, so that it can be usable. It's a good thing because it requires things that are readily available, for example, cow dung, water. Therefore, biogas is good because it is cheap, and it doesn't need money.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Which alternatives need money?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Even a solar system; to maintain a solar system you need money to replace the bulbs and batteries. Moreover, it's not easy to find such things. As for Biogas, cow dung, water is always available and free.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, you would go for biogas first, but it needs to be installed in a manner that it could work. Alternatives, you would choose a solar system. Okay, thanks for the interview. And, please share her contact, so I can reach out to her and ask some specific questions.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Okay, sure. We have here number.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Do so, please. Thanks.
interviewee: NA

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Sorry for the loss of your uncle who passed on 2020. I know it is going to be difficult for you to answer the question, as you were not staying with him. But since you stayed very close to his house and interacted with him regularly. I hope you will be able to answer some of the questions. And, if you don't know the answer the question that's fine, we can always move on.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Okay, fine.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: First question, where did the digester originate from?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I believe it was a non-governmental organization, but the government.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I also believe that it was funded by the NGO?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Obviously.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where you around when it was being built?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, I was not around.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: But, I can imagine you we told or you found out who built it? Who built it? Is it your late uncle or the installation company?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: That time when I asked him, he told me the visitors installed the digester

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What was his role?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: He was responsible for gathering and preparing feedstock for the digester. And, this was easy for him because he had a cow house.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Some beneficiary say they were responsible for digging the hole....
interviewee: **Interviewee**: That's true. He dug the hole, but the visitors placed the bag in the hole and assembled the pipes and other fittings. So, I think he was responsible for digging the hole and preparing the feedstock.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: In this community, we have a lot of people and a lot of households. How was he selected as a beneficiary?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: My late Uncle was a very hard working person; he was not lazy in all his doings. So, I think the people who brought the digesters here thought that he would manage it, and it would reach to other people, as he was not a stingy man. You know when some people get this kind of things they always keep it to themselves and block other people from learning from them or even giving them a chance to appreciate the technology. Also, he was a very trustworthy and reliable man, and you can tell that by the simple fact that he worked with almost every non-governmental organizations, which came here for developmental projects.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: And as you have rightly said, he might have been chosen because he had cows, because most of the beneficiaries are chosen based on that.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, he had cows, so I think that's why he was selected.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Do you know about biogas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I know a little about it

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What little do you know?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I know biogas is a technology that uses biodegradable things to produce energy for cooking.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, what was his expectation of biogas? Or, what do you know about the uses of biogas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I believe he expected to use biogas for cooking, like I said, he used it for cooking. The other thing was that he had expectation of protecting the environment by stopping using firewood and charcoal for cooking... Simply put, biogas stops women from going to the mountains to search for firewood. It also stops people from making charcoal, thereby protecting the environment. I mean, you can't use firewood or buy charcoal when you have biogas. So, he expected to stop using such things for cooking, and it was beneficial to the family -- that's what I know. And when I saw all that, I thought to myself that the project implementers brought the digesters to protect and conserve the environment by stopping people from reckless cutting down of trees.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, what kind of training did he receive in regards to biogas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I think he expected to go for training, but he never went. I remember this other time, we talked and he hoped to go for training to learn one or two things about biogas. But, he did not go for training. This thing was only brought here, but not everything was completed.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did it produce fire?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes, it did.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did he ever cook on it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, and for a long time.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Like how long?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I think it was 7 to 11 months. But, it didn't last a year.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: He had the right to deny the digester, but he did. Why do you think he accepted to build a digester here?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I think he accepted to save money he was spending on a charcoal or firewood; I also think he accepted it to enable his wife to stop going to the mountains to search for firewood. On top of this, I think he accepted the digester to protect and conserve the environment.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you meet your energy needs that time?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Bluntly speaking, the first and common means of cooking here is by firewood. This is followed by charcoal. Statistically, I can say 75% of the people here use firewood; if you go to 100 households, you would find that 70 to 75 households are using firewood, and the rest use charcoal. I'm saying this because the charcoal we use here is not made here. It\`s made in Mozambique. So, sometimes it's hard to find and it's expensive too.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, you get charcoal from Mozambique?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Oh, yeah.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What do yourself use?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I often use firewood. Still, sometimes I use charcoal.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: In 6 months, how many bags of charcoal do you buy?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Maybe, I use two or three bags. We usually buy charcoal during the rainy season because firewood is usually wet around that time. Around this time is not common to find the people cooking using charcoal.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much is a bag of charcoal?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It's sold in range of K3000 to K5000 depending on the size.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where do you get firewood?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We get it from the mountains.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I have seen a lot of mountains around this part. Everywhere you look you see a mountain, and you house is even on a foot of a mountain \[less than 50 meters\]. How often do you go there to source firewood?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We go there four times a week. It's within.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you manage your feedstock before the intervention?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Before that digester, he was getting the manure to the farm to be used as fertilizer.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Does it work?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It works, but it takes time to work. For example, if you put the manure in the farm today, you should expect it to start working next year.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How do you make it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We collect manure from the cow house and heap it at the farm. Then, we place the manure on top of the ridge and place vegetation i.e. maize stalks on top, and then we make the ridges again onto which seeds are planted. So, when the rain comes it breaks down the manure, and it takes about a year to complete break it down. So, it takes a year or so to work as fertilizer. Though, it takes time for this method to work, it's good because it helps the soil to retain moisture, and it generally improves the soil.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did it work after commission?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I can't really say because I never got the chance to see the stove working. But, I knew that they were cooking on it, because I would hear them talking about it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were the operation requirements?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I think it was only manure. As I said, I didn't really interact with it to know it fully.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: And water too?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah! Water too!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did they prepare the feedstock?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I just heard about that they mixed cow manure and water, and then feed it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Do you know how often did they feed it and in what quantities?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Hmm, I don't know.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were the maintenance requirements?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: That I can't know as well.

interviewer: In own words, what were the challenges?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Aah, in his own words, he mentioned that the installers didn't come back from the time they installed it. Also, that it was malfunctioning sometimes, which was hard for them to fix because they did not receive any training. Then, after sometime, the bag shrunk and that was the end of it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So one major problem was that the installers did not follow up after installation of the digester...
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, for example, if they could have come after the bag shrunk, I believe they could have fixed it using the expertise.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What went problem?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I don't exactly remember what it was, but he said something like the bag shrunk and it was not producing gas, and I don't know what caused it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did he call the installers?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes, he did. But, they only told him that they would come to fix it and they didn't.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How would you describe the current state of digester?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I can only say that it's broken.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did it reach that state?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I can't know, but I remember I asked him about the digester and he told me that it doesn't work.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: It sounded to me like when you want to cook you use firewood, and you use manure as fertilizer for your crops even now, right?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah! Nothing has changed.

interviewer: We are going towards the end of the interview. Do you know how much reactor cost?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, I didn't hear anything on that.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did he contribute anything in kind?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I don't know anything about that.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What is your opinion of biogas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: When the digester came here, we admired it. And when we heard that many people would get the digester after the first roll out, we were happy because we really admired it. We admired it because life is hard when you cooking on firewood or charcoal. And, when we look at the environment, the mountains, we feel sad because we don't know how bad things will be if we continue like this. So, if there is a solution other than biogas, then we would really appreciate it. What I want is we community people to move away from what we were told by our fathers that firewood is for cooking and start using modern methods of cooking. I remember, this other day I was passing through Namonde village in Group village Ching'ani and I saw solar panels mounted on people's houses by a certain NGO. I was so attracted, so I asked the people and they told me that 10 people were given the solar panels by a certain NGO, and they use solar panels for cooking. They went on to say they stopped using firewood and charcoal after the got the solar panels. So, if I can be given a chance to choose between biogas and solar panels, I would go for solar panels without a doubt. And, I believe that if organizations can supply the people with solar panels, I'm sure we would save the environment.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: If think you have touch on my next question, I wanted to ask you that if you were given an opportunity to choose or design your own waste or energy intervention, what could you have chosen instead?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: When I look at the time that my uncle used the digester, I think it's too short to be considered as an alternative to firewood. But, I think solar can work for a long time because it relies on sun, and you know the sun is ever-present (laughs).... So Personally, I would go for solar panels.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why do you think your uncle's digester didn't work for long?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I think the digester didn't work for long because project implementers did not follow up after they installed it. It is also important to give beneficiaries training regardless of what kind of technology it, so that you enable them to manage the technology. For example, if you can give me a dairy cow and leave, of course, I will accept it, but something will be missing. I will need is training, for example, I will need you to tell me what I should do to maximize milk production especially in regards to feeding. Because without that, I might be feeding it with local feed and it may fail to produce milk. And after a month or two, I might even call you to tell you that the cow is not producing milk. Then, you will ask me what I'm feeding the cow, and then you will learn that I'm not feed it accordingly and you will advise me on feeding to maximize milk production.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, it failed because the people did not receive training?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, you can't give anyone a new thing without explaining what thing is about. You need to explain what ought to be done for that thing to last long.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why do you think an organization would do that? Because when you think of an organization you think that, everything is well planned and organized. Why did this organization fail to do the training or implement this accordingly?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It could be that they failed to come and monitor the project because of the transition of government. In my thinking, I believe change of government also affects the operation of NGO. I think governments do have special working relationship with certain organizations, so when the government goes out of power, certain organization also crumble.
