Then, another group of people came, I think it was the third group to come, and they told us the digesters seemed not to work everywhere, so they were thinking of bringing solar panels -- so that's what happened!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So the first time they came, did they came alone as project implementers or they came with people from the community?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They came with the person you are with, the former ADC (Area Development Committee) chairperson.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, so ADC members came?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, it was just him and them. So, they came like 4 people including him, and he came in his capacity as ADC Chair. And, that's when they started talking about bringing the equipment for cooking.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You had the right to deny the technology. Why did you accept it to be built here?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I accepted it because I thought it was beneficial. Firewood is difficult to find here, so I expected to use it for cooking, and I was very excited to get a digester. And that time, as you can see, I was ready old and I had just lost my wife, so I expected it to help me personally by providing an alternative that would have stop me from going to the mountains to get firewood -- so, I was very grateful to get it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you know anything about biogas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, I didn't know about biogas. No one here knew about it. It was my first time to see it - It was a first of its kind here in this village.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you became aware of biogas when they brought it here?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah. I leant about it when they came and talked about it as I have said.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were your expectations?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I was very happy to get it. And, I had high expectations of it. I expected it to be beneficial.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How beneficial?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I expected it to relieve the struggle we face in finding firewood for cooking; firewood is difficult to find, so we expected to cook with ease by its coming.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I take it that they told you that you would be using it for cooking, what else?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They just told us that we would be using it for cooking food and boiling water for bathing.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did they tell you about lighting?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No. But, after it failed to work, they brought the idea of bringing a solar panel. So, I believe that's when we would have had an opportunity to use it for lighting.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did they tell you that it produces digestate that you can use as fertilizer?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, they didn't tell us. They only told us to feed it with manure, and that we should dig a hole at the outlet in which slurry would fall into. But, they didn't say anything about using the manure as fertilizer in our farms.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So after everything was done, or before everything was done, what kind of training did you receive?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, we didn\'t.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Then, how were you able to operate it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I asked them that if is it malfunctioned, what were we supposed to do, and they told me that we should report to the extension workers.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Which ones?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The agriculture extension workers.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, fine. I imagine that it wasn't the only thing you were told. I mean, with that you wouldn't know how to operate it - how to turn it on and off and the like.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Okay, I understand. They called us to the kitchen where there was a stove, and then they showed us the button for turning it on and off. So, after turning it on, it was producing flames, and they told us to use a matchstick to light up the flames, if it failed to light up on its own -- that's what they told us.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So there were times you were lighting it up without using a matchstick?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah. It was lighting up the flames without striking a matchstick. But, sometimes it needed matchstick to light up the flames.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Under what circumstances were you striking a matchstick to start up the flame?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: When we turned it on and saw that no flame was lighted up, that's when we struck a matchstick to start the fire. So the matchstick was there only to boost and light up the gas when it couldn't on its own.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, I understand. So, you were taught how to start up the fire, and I can imagine you were told how to prepare...
interviewee: **Interviewee**: feedstock, yeah, we were told how to prepare feedstock -- yeah, they to us that.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What did they say?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They told us that to make feedstock, we need fresh cow manure; add water, and then mix. Then, they told us that to make feedstock we need one bucket (20 liter) and add 4 buckets (20 liters) of water.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you were putting one bucket of cow manure like that one, and then add four buckets of that?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, we were using a bucket of that size.

interviewer: Okay. How did you meet your energy needs before the intervention?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We used firewood for cooking. We were using the bluegum trees around. So, we used to cut the trees, and then dry them up as you can see there.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Yeah, and I can also see a lot of bluegum tree here, and not just here, people here in general have bluegum trees. How did that come about?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We planted these bluegum trees long ago, even though the mountains had trees had trees that time. We knew that the trees in the mountains were not ours, so that's why we planted our own. So, these are our private trees, and I feel like we were right in our thinking then. Because now you can't find a 3-meter tree in the mountains, so we only depend on these trees for firewood.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where did you get the trees? Did you get it from an NGO?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We got it from the government through the agriculture office.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So when you want to cook you only use your trees,?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Is it enough?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, we get enough. But, it's depleting because we have cut enough trees, so we need to plant more trees again.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Do you buy charcoal?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, I don't.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: By any chance, do you know how much firewood do you use in a month? Or, is it difficult to estimate?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We can't know because it's very hard to measure.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You say you had cows, and I believe you still have them.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, I still have.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: And, how did you manage your cow manure that time?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I was using it as fertilizer.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, does it works?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It works, but you need to mix it with inorganic fertilizer to boost up its strength.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Let's talk about how your digester worked. For a digester to work, it needs feeding. First, you feed it with large huge amount of feedstock to start it up. Then, you feed it regularly but this time the quantity differs from the first charge. How much feedstock did you start it up with?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We used two bags (50kg) of cow manure and large volume of water.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Like how much water?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We used six water containers.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Which containers?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Those ones!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, the plastic jelly cans \[20 liters\].
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How long did it take to start up? I mean you can't feed it and expect it to start working on the same day; it takes time for the process to start up and produce gas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The same day the woman came to prepare feedstock, it was the same day that we started it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Mm-hmm
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, it wasn't as if they said they would come another day -- it was the same day. It was not as they gave us a week or a year, no. It was the same day.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How long did it take that day? Did they came in the morning and you started up in late in the afternoon?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, it was around the same time they came. We just said fed it that day and after sometime we started up the stove.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Same day?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Same day!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah! It was the same day, for sure.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: They didn\'t give you time to commission it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, they didn't say they would come back to commission it. It was the same day?

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Let me get you clear on this. The first day you fed the digester with cow manure and water, was it the same day you commissioned it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, we commissioned it the same day. That was what happened!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, okay. How did it work after commissioning? Or, how much cooking time did you get? Or, let me put it this way, what did you cook on that day?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: A cup of water started to heat up (less than 2 minutes), then it went off. The first time, it started with strong flames, then it started going down, and then it eventually went off. And, we didn't even cook nsima or side dish of anything.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, what happened on the second day?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was the same thing. We didn't cook anything and it didn't even start.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What was the gas for?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was only for cooking.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, if you ever used it, that was when you tried to boil the water?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: That was tough
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Very tough, indeed, because it was not easy to make the feedstock - it was hard work. Then, we saw that it couldn't help us, so we abandoned it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where did you get the cow manure you used to start it up? Where did you get two the bags you used to start it up?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I got it from my cow house.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many cows did you have that time?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I had 15 cows, but now I have less.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Now, how much do you have?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I have 14.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, you still have a lot. Where did you get the water?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We got it from white house you can see there. They have a solar powered water pump, which pumps water from the ground.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What's there?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: A catholic priest resides there.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, I see. That's like 800 meters from here. Did you buy?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, he just helped us.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were the operation requirements?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They told us that, if we wanted it to use it, we needed to feed it every day with cow manure and water -- and nothing else.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much feedstock were you supposed to feed it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They advised us to feed it with one bucket (20 liter) of cow manure and two buckets (20 liters) of water every day -- Yeah, the water was supposed to be more than cow manure.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you prepare the feedstock?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We used to place cow manure in a bucket, add water, and then mix thoroughly to get suitable slurry. Then, we used to feed the digester through the white inlet pipe.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How would you describe this task?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I found the job very tough. Had it been that it was working, then it could have been understandable. So, you just had to feel sorry for us. And, I felt like I was abused to do all that job without gaining something out at the end.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Yeah, sorry for that. Who was responsible for feeding it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I was the only person feeding it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were maintenance requirements?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They didn't tell us anything about maintenance. They only told us to feed it to get gas, and to dig at hole at the outlet to contain the digestate.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you use the digestate?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were simply throwing it away.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Behind the kitchen, we had a refuse pit so that's where we used to dispose of the digestate.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: And, you have told me that you were told to consult the agriculture extension workers whenever there was a problem, right? So, if thing that had to do with maintenance was in the hands of the agriculture office, I suppose.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: My next question was to ask you if it met your needs, but clearly, it didn't...
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It didn't indeed. We never cooked nsima on it, no even once! My wish was to use it in the morning, at lunch to cook nsima, and in the evening to cook as well. But, it never did. I didn't even use it boil water!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were the challenges?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The only problem we face with it is that it didn't produce fire -- it didn't work.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: If you saw fire that was only after commissioning and that was for less than 2 or 3 minutes, and after that it never worked.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did the fire go off that 2 or 3 minutes? Did it go off at once, or it declined and eventually stopped?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The fire was going down slowly. It only worked for 2 minutes. And after that, I tried to feed it, but it didn't work. I fed it for 3 days then I stopped feeding it and that was its end.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, when you said you used it for 5 days, you mean interacted with it for 5 days but never used it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Definitely!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why didn't you feed for a week or so, and then see that what was going to happen?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I feel like I was committed and did my best to feed it for 3 days, but nothing happened. So, I knew that it was not going to work.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How can I see your commitment when you fed it for just 3 days?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I fed it first day with loads of feedstock, and the day or two after I fed it also. The following day, I fed it also. So I feel like I tried. I wouldn't have kept on when I was seeing any results.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What went wrong? Did you notice any leakage in the pipes?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: There wasn't many pipes. It was just one pipe, which traveled from the bag to the stove.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What happened after?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I had their numbers too, so when I called them they were just like they would come.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: And, they didn't come?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, never.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you report to the agriculture office?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, I just reported directly.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why? I thought the told you to report to them.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I didn't interact with the agriculture at any point in the installation of this, so I did think of them.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: But that was what you were told.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah. But, I believe that if I had interacted with, I believe I would have.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Have you seen something like this \[Table of intervention\]?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: This is information about common problems of biogas, their causes and solutions. What do you think of the information and do you think it would have helped?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The installers never said that the digester malfunctions. And, they didn't explain to us how to respond to any problem. They only told us to consult the extension workers when there was a problem. Then, they also told us how to switch it on. And, it was not difficult to start it up the fire -- it was easy.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Has anyone else to come to follow up on the digester?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, one has ever come.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So if you were given information on how to respond to problem, do you think the information on would have helped you?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It's a very important because it would have given us a clue on how to respond to the problem. As I have said, I didn\'t do anything to solve the problem. So maybe if I had such information, I would have tried my best to fix it

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How would you describe the current state of your digester? In other words, if the installers call you today on your phone to find out about the digester, what would you tell them?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I would inform them the digester is not working, and I'm sure they know that it's not working because they left it not working. And, the last time they were here, we talked about it, and that's why they said they would bring solar panels (laughs). They saw the pot of water failing to boil, and they admitted that it didn't work, and that's when they brought the idea of solar panels. That was their last words, and that was their goodbye.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did it reach this stage? And, what cause it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I don't know why it failed. We were told to make feedstock, we did and fed it, but it didn't work. So, I don't why it didn't work.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: It wrong to suggest the installers had no technical skill to install it and make work?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: After it did not work, I asked the installers if they had installed the digesters anywhere else and worked. And they responded that the digesters work, and I told them that it's not good to give someone something that's useless. Then, I quizzed them if they had installed the digesters somewhere else and worked, and that's when they brushed me off saying that the digesters work. So, I did question their capabilities, and they responded that the digesters work.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How do you meet your energy needs now that it's not working?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We still use firewood.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How do you manage your feedstock now?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We use it as fertilizer in our fields. So what we do is, we get the manure and place the manure between ridges. Then, we make new ridges between the old ridges.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay. How much did the reactor cost?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, they didn't tell us.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did they inform you who funded it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, they didn't.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you contribute anything in kind?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, I only dug the hole.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you line the hole?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, we didn't.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why not? You weren't told?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We saw that we would waste cement. And, out of the beneficiaries, I think it was only one person who lined it. It didn't make sense to use it for a week and line it with a brick wall or plaster.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Were you told to line it before installation or after installation?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: At whatever point, we could have lined it up. So, when it didn't work, we didn't even think of lining it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Apart from digging the hole, sourcing water and cow manure, what else did you do?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, that was all.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What special items had to be imported from another country?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They didn't discuss that with us.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What's your take though?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I have never seen it in any store, so that makes me think it's from abroad.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: My next question was to ask you if it helped you to save money or helped, but it's clear, it didn't save you any money or helped you in any way...
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, I only wasted my energy.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: And, even the money used to hire the person who helped you to dig the hole. If you could meet the installers today, what would you say to them?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I can't thank them because we were helped in any way. If it had worked for some time and then stopped, I would have thanked them. I can't thank them for what they did -- what should I thank them for? (Laughs)

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What is your opinion of biogas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Biogas is much needed, but it's sad that it didn't work. If it had worked, it would have helped us a lot

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why was it much needed, and how could it have helped you?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It could have helped us to meet our cooking needs.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What's the future of biogas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Biogas is very helpful in improving livelihood. So, I would like to see it continuing.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: If you could have designed your own waste or energy intervention, what would you have chosen instead?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I would have chosen a solar powered stove, and not a stove that uses firewood.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It has more benefits than woodstoves. Wood stoves take time for igniting. So, that's why a solar powered stove is better than a woodstove.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Yeah, maybe solar is really a good alternative, and even the installers recommend solar. What are your last words?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I thank you for coming. What I've said about the digester not helping us, I would have also told the installer, if they had come. So, thanks for coming, and if you can have a chance to meet them, you can tell them that we thanked them for nothing and for a useless thing. So, thanks for coming you have helped us to release our concerns and cries.... What happened is a sad story, a very sad story. We expected to benefit, but we didn't anything from it -- overall, I feel like a digester is a very beneficial thing.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: It's really a sad story.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: and you just have to feel sorry.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Yeah, some of the things sound dramatic and funny, but it's really unfortunate that it happened. Thanks for the interview.
interviewee: NA

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where did the digester originate from?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The project implementers told us that they were trying out the digesters, and that they came from Chancellor College.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Who funded it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They did not tell us the organization that provided the money. They just told us that they wanted to try out the digesters.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Who built it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I have just forgotten. I think his name was \[name redacted\], I'm not sure though.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Let me put it this way. How many people from the installation company came?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: There were two people. Every beneficiary had two installers, so the whole team was composed of eight or ten people who went four or five other beneficiaries. I remember that the name of man as \[name redacted\], but I don't remember the name of the woman. I am sure husband would have remembered their names, because he was the one who was interacting with them.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What was your role?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: When the installers came, they simply advise us to dig a 1-meter hole. After that, they placed the digester bag in the hole, and then assembled the outlet and inlet pipes as well as a green pipe and a stove. Then, they advised us to make me feedstock and feed the digester afterwards. We fed the digester bag with two drums of cow manure, and we waited for a week to start using it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many people from side did the work?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Three people dug the hole; my husband and my two boys.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How long did it take them?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The soil was dry and compact that time, so it took them four days.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So after a week or so, they came to place the bag and assemble the pipes and the other fittings?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: We have so many people and households in this community. How were you selected as a beneficiary?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They told us the community had many people, but they wanted people who interested and willing to manage the digester. So, we were basically chosen because of our interest and commitment.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What was the selection process? Or, how were they able to separate the willing and committed from those who weren't willing?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: There was no selection procedure. I think \[name redacted\] \[Area Development Committee chair\] identified and selected us based on our activeness in doing things. I think, I was the only one in \[location redacted\] that was chosen. But, in total about 10 people were chosen in T/A \[Traditional Authority\] Chiwalo. Thus, for a start, they wanted 10 people. After that, more people would have been chosen. Thus, there was no selection procedure; they just chose people who they thought were active under the recommendation of \[name redacted\]. Also, they chose people who were at least close to me road, so that the project implementers could easily reach them.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Is it true that you are active or you were active?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes, it's true.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How can I believe that?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (Laughs) you can believe this by the simple fact that I've told you that you haven't found everything intact because my husband passed on. My husband was a hard-working man, and if he was alive, you would have found everything.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, he was always involved in community projects?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: He was always active and present in every community project.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Like which projects?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: In every community project.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were your expectations?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They told us that they were trying out the digester, so were expecting to benefit at the end of it. So, at the end, we expected to use it for cooking.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So they made it clear to you that you were trying out the digester?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, they told us that they were from Chanco and were trying out the digesters. So, we had huge expectation to see what was going to happen -- so, we were expecting lights too.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Even though they were trying out the digester, I believe there were some things you were told to expect from the digester. What were you told to expect by the installers?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We used it for cooking. And, they told us that in modern age people should not rely on firewood for cooking. Instead, we should start relying on biogas for cooking to conserve for the environment. That is what they told us.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Do you think biogas is the way to protect the environment?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Biogas is a way to save the environment. Nowadays, we don't have trees in the mountains because of high population growth. So, biogas is a good solution to that especially to people who are interested and committed to use it and to save the environment.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you think people need to be committed to realize its potential?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, people need to be keen on this, and committed too to realize its potential. But, if people like you want to advance the project, you should consider bringing solar panels to overcome the difficulties we faced. The main challenge we had with biogas that time was sourcing manure -- it is very hard to source cow manure. So, we would like to have a solution like solar technology and we would appreciate it a lot.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, what kind of training did you receive?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We didn't receive any at all, and I just feel like the project implementers were not committed and lazy in their doing. They didn't tell us how to fix it. If there was any problem, when we tried to call them, they didn't respond - The installers were very lazy -- they just installed the digester and left. So, when we started using it, we didn't know what to do; how to act and where to go, if it stopped functioning -- they were so lazy.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: When you say lazy, what do you mean? Could you please elaborate on that?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I'm saying this because they just installed it and showed us how to use it. But, they never came back to follow up and see what was happening.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Apart from being taught how to use it, and make feedstock, what else?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They taught us how to control the fire on the stove. Also, they told us that after feeding it, we should be waiting up to 12:00 noon after to use it. They digester relied on the sun; when the sun was out cooking easy.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: When they brought the digester, you had the right to say no. you could have said thanks, but it's involving, no. Why did you accept to build the digester here?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I accepted it because a person doesn't refuse development; no one denies development from government -- no way! You can't say no development.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why shouldn't person say no to Development?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The government is there to serve the people. There job is to look after our lives. So if the government decided to try the digesters here, we wouldn't have said no.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you know about biogas before?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I didn't know about biogas. So it was not like a thing we wanted. At that time, as a less privileged community, we wanted electricity from Escom. We envy people living in communities where there are electricity lines, without electricity people a hard life. We live a hard life here.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, you live a hard life?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We live a hard life. As you can see, there is no electricity in this community and the road is very here. I think you have seen it yourself.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Yeah, it\`s bad. How did you meet your energy needs that time?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I was using maize stalks. Sometimes, I was using firewood.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where did you get the firewood?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We get it from the forest

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Which forest?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We get it from the forests around the mountain. But, forest officials protect them.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, what do you do?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We sometimes get tree branches from within -- we cut trees from within, dry them and use them as firewood.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: And, sometimes you just sneak into the forests?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah (laughs). We just wait for them to knock off and go... In regards to training, frankly speaking, I didn't go for training, and if they can say they want people to go for training, I would really appreciate it, if I could go.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You want training?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, I want training.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How would you want training when the digester is dead?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I want to learn about biogas, and I would also like to tell them my concerns and grievances -- I would like to tell them to bring solar panels and electricity to use for cooking.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why are community people, so obsessed with trainings?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Development can't come without training. For example, in your case you can't just come and say I want to do this and that. What you do is you would brief the people on your research, and then you need to train the people to know what exactly what they are supposed to do -- so that's it goes!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I can't agree more. Let me put it to you; you are saying you want to go for biogas training, but it sounds to me like you don't want biogas, you want solar panels or electricity. So my question, do you want the training to learn biogas or something else i.e. the money?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (laughs) No, we just go there! (Laughs heavily) So, the money is just part of it. I mean, they can't just keep you there without food allowance. We just go there with a heart to learn, but you money just comes in because they can\'t just make you sit for hours for nothing. Thus, they give the money to us to buy food, and to buy other necessities like soap. That's how it is.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (Laughs) great! Do you buy charcoal?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, I don\'t

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why not?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I don't have the money to buy charcoal.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, did you have cows when the digester was installed here?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes, I had.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you manage the feedstock i.e. the cow manure?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We use it as fertilizer in our fields.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Some people say it doesn't help, so how do you use it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Fertilizer is expensive these days, so you can't say it does help. So, after harvesting, we go put the manure in the fields, and when it's time to make ridge, we just mix it together with the soil.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Do you add in organic fertilizer?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: If it's available we do, but fertilizer is hard to find.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So when your name is included in the list of agriculture input subsidy programme beneficiaries you do?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, definitely!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Let's talk about how it worked and how you started it up. How much feedstock did you start it up with?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: As I mentioned earlier, we started it up with it six bags (50kgs) of fresh cow manure and two drums (200 liters) of water.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: That's a lot of manure. How did you manage to get all that manure?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I got three bags from my cow house, and the rest I got from other people.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Like how far from here?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It's far; I got it from Ching'ani village.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How far is it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: When my boys went to collect manure on a bicycle around 9 or 10, they were coming somewhere after 12 noon.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you buy the manure?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, but if it was these days I'm sure they would have been selling us at K250 a bag.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) what has changed?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Everything is about money these days; only a greeting is free these days

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) where did you get the water?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We have two boreholes in this community; one is there and the other one is at the end of the village. That's like 300 meters. But, it was a lot of work and we even asked girls from neighbors to help us.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you pay them?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: What could we have paid them with? And it's good that not everything was about money that time.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, how long did it take to start up?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They only waited for 3 days to commission it after feeding it with the first charge.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did it work after commissioning?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: At the first, it didn't work, then we called an \[name redacted\], then it started working.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Was it the same day you commissioned it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, it was a different day.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So that time you tried it, were the installers or \[name redacted\] there?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, they weren't there. They just told us how to start it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you were told how to start it, and that you should start it after 3 days?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, they told us to start it up when the bag was full.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, when tried it up and saw that it wasn't working you called \[name redacted\]?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, then he suggested to my husband that maybe he was doing something wrong, and he told him the correct way of doing it. And, when he did what he was told, it worked.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What was the problem?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: My husband was doing that, so I don't know where he got it wrong. But, I think he said something like a pipe or gas valve at the kitchen was the problem.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did it work after commissioning? Or, how much cooking time did you get?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It worked the quite okay, but it had problems when there was no sunlight. So every time we say that the bag was full we were using it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Let's talk about the cooking time were getting? Were you able to cook porridge or tea in the morning?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I was able to cook porridge (15 - 20 minutes), but only after 9 o'clock when the sun was out -- it was working when there was sunlight.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How was your cooking like in a day?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: In the morning, I had issues as I was waiting for the sun. In the afternoon, I was able to cooknsima and side dish (1 -- 1 hour 30 minutes). But, in the evening when the sun was gone, the bag was shrinking and it wasn't working.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How long did you use it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Like I said, we used it for two years.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, you mean in two years you were able to cook nsima, side dish and porridge.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, for two year.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Aaah, then you are the first person to use it that long.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, and you can even ask \[name redacted\] there. He even used his for quite a long time too.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Mmmh?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You are the first person to use it the long...
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, but when it stopped working when we called them they didn't come. And, that\'s why I have said that the installers were lazy people.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you use the gas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: He used to the gas for cooking only.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many people used the gas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Six people.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were maintenance requirements?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It didn't require a lot of things. After feeding it with six bags of manure and two drums during the first charge, they advised us to feed it with 2 buckets (40 liters) of cow manure every day. So every day we were feeding it, and waiting for 9 o'clock to start using it. So that's how it worked.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much water did you add?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The water was included in the 2 bucket; I was placing about half cow manure in a bucket and then I filled water in the bucket until suitable slurry was reached.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How were you doing it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: My son, I was doing that with my hands and without gloves (laughs). After feeding, that's when we washed our hands.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, you think gloves were necessary?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, but we still used bare hands because they didn't give us gloves.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you feel that it was unhealthy? And, didn't you feel disgusting?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Mm-hmm, I remember one time health officials came, and they asked us and saw how we were preparing feedstock. Then, they said it was unhygienic and didn't agree with that. Then, I told them that you are coming from government, and the people who brought it here came from the government as well, so if it's unhygienic then it's the government that has brought poor hygiene here.... I remember, they were like our compound was looking unpleasant and that it was attracting a lot of flies - and I told them that the government that brought the digester and it didn't come of our own accord. So, if we would get diseases, it's the government's fault.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, what happened?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They didn\'t do anything, we told them straight facts.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you design the outlet?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We just dug a hole, so that digestate would flow into.

interviewer: What were you doing with the digestate?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They told us that we could use it as a fertilizer.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you use it as fertilizer?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes, I did.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did it work?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes, it did.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you pre-treat the feedstock?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, we were using fresh manure, so we used to do everything on the spot.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Who was responsible for feeding it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was me together with my girls and boys. And, they didn't express any resentment of handling cow manure.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They didn't express resentment because they were doing what was best for their lives in that moment.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were the maintenance requirements?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: That's why I say the installers were lazy people. And if we are not using biogas today, it's because the installers didn't train us. If they had taken the beneficiaries for training to teach them how to fix issues, then things would have been different today.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you meet your needs?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes, it did. It very much met my needs. In the late morning hours, I was able to prepare breakfast, warm water for bathing. In the afternoon, I was able cook nsima and side dish. It was only not working in evening because it needed the sun to work. They bag was never full when there was no sunlight and it wasn't working.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What time did you see the bag shrinking?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The bag was shrinking after 4 PM, when the sun was going down.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Was it shrinking completely? Was the bag still appearing above the ground?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, it was appearing above ground, it just that it wasn't completely full as when there was sunlight.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you meet your needs in the evening?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I was getting tree branches from the trees around.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were the challenges?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The one problem is what I have already told you, it was very hard to find cow manure. The other thing was that health officials didn't agree with its hygiene aspect. So, that's why I have said that if this project is continuing they should consider bringing solar panels... But, the main challenge was on sourcing manure. On top of this, we had also a minor problem that concerned children. The children liked to smear themselves with the cow dung when we were making feedstock.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You have told me that you had cow house, then how come you had challenges in sourcing cow manure?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Of course, we had a cow house, but we had very few cows. So it was hard for us to collect the two buckets of cow manure in a day. And, the surprising thing was that our two cows pooped more when they were outside the cow house. So, it was tough to gather all the manure together.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) when it rains, it pours. So, how did you cope?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Fearing that would sleep on an empty stomach, we were going around seeking for cow manure from people who had cows. So, when we added that manure with what we had it was somehow working. And when we saw that the fire was dying we were trying as much as possible to go fast, and when then fire was eventually off we used firewood.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, this is how it was in its entire working life?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, yeah, but in some cases we were able to get the manure from our cow house.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did it stop working?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Strong winds blew the roof off and ended up cutting off the green pipe. The cut was so severe that we couldn't fix it. After that, we called the project implementers numerous times to report what happened, and that we couldn't manage to fix it, but to no avail. So, they never came and we eventually gave up.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Was the call going through or not?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: When we called them, theirs number couldn't be reached. I don't know if they changed their numbers or something.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where exactly was the pipe damaged?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Our kitchen roof that year was blown off by strong winds, and it damaged the pipe, so we couldn't have managed to do fix it. And that\'s when we called the project implemented to come and fix it. But, they never came and that's why we abandoned it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you get smell of gas around?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were getting odor at the outlet after an overflow even before the pipes got damaged. And that's why healthy officials were against it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So it took two years?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, we used it for 2 years.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Before I get to my next question, I want to be clear on this. Did you use it for 2 years? How much cooking time did you get in those 2 years?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We used it for two years, of course. If we had breakfast food, we were using it in the morning and at lunch. But, in the evening, we were not able to use it. So, sometimes when we went to the fields, we would find the children cooking on biogas -- so it was a joy tohave it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: That was amazing.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, it was so easy to use; you couldn't notice that pot had been on the stove as it was clean and; it was more like cooking on an electric stove.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Have something like this?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: This is information regarding common problems associated with digesters, their causes and solutions. What do you think about this kind of information and do you think it would have helped you?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It would have helped us a lot.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How or why?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I\'ll give you an example. We had a washproject by water mission there, and the project implementers took people for training. They did train people on operation and maintenance of the water facility. At the end, people were able to maintain the facility. Also, in this community, we have a certain man called \[name redacted\]; he is very active and interested in such things, so organizations usually get him to trainings. And, indeed, he fixes many problems in this community. So if they had given us such information, or even if they had trained, few individuals on maintenance like on the water mission project, we would have reached to those people to help us fix the problem.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You have said that projects that come here usually involve trainings, and I totally agree with you that most projects of this nature involve trainings. And, I personally think that a project of this magnitude and nature should have had some sort of training for things to work. Why do you think this project had no trainings?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I don't know why. I just don't know why. And we had no opportunity to ask them why they didn't train us.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: We are in October; let's suppose the project implementers call you today to find out about the digester, what would you say to them?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I would tell them that the digester you gave me it's no longer working. It stopped working because strong winds blew off the roof and eventually cut off the green pipe. Then, I called you but you didn't come. So, I'm not currently using the digester because you did not give me the expertise to maintain it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What was key cause to the failure of your digester?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The problem is not the project implementers were lazy people. If the project implementers were not lazy and if they were coming to follow up on us, I'm sure many people would have adopted the digesters. And, I feel like we are not to blame for its failure, and that the project implementers are totally responsible.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: It sounds like when you want to cook these days you use the same old methods --you use firewood, maize stalks, right?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: That's true.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: And you still use cow manure as fertilizer in the fields, right,?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: We are going towards the end of the interview. How much did reactor cost?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Honestly speaking, I don't know anything about that. Maybe my husband was told, but I'm not aware. Or, maybe \[name redacted\] knows.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, did you contribute anything in kind?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, we only contributed human power, which we used in digging the hole, and in sourcing and preparing feedstock. And we had no problems with that because it was our thing.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Again, who dug it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: My husband dug it with the support of my two boys.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You didn't hire anyone else to help you dig?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, we didn't.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you line the hole? Or, was any masonry work involved?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Were you told you to line it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, we weren't told. But, we had the plans to build a structure of bricks and cement for the stove. It didn't happen because we had no money to buy cement.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Apart from digging the hole, sourcing the feedstock and preparing the feedstock, what other tasks did you do?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Nothing, that was all.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What special items have to be imported from another country?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I should say that I know. But, I think the bag is outside the country.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why do you think the bag might have been from outside?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I think the bag was written that it was from China.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) so you think the bag is from China and not Phalombe?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: If it was from Phalombe, I would have know. So, I think the bag is from abroad.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I have to say that out of all the people I have talked to you are the one who has used it for long. It is kind of surreal to me. So in those two years did it help you to save money?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: A lot. Since, we stopped relying on firewood. And, even when there was rain, we didn't worry about using wet wood.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Two years is a lot of time. How did it work during the rainy season and summer? Did it differ?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were still using it in rain season long as the sun shone after the rain; it needs the sun to work.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Here in Malawi, sometimes it rains all day, and sometimes it can stay for a week without the sun shining especially during the rainy and wet season. What were you doing after that?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We had to find plans to cook -- so we were forced to cook using firewood.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, it wasn't working sometimes?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, the bag wasn't getting full. It needs the sun. So, it wasn't working.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you feed it in rain season? i.e. when it was raining maybe for 3 or 5 days continuous when their was no sun, did you fed it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yes, we were still feeding it because we knew that once we stopped feeding it wouldn't produce gas. As a result, we wouldn't be able to cook after the sun was out.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What was the biggest change in your life when it was working?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The biggest change was that when we went to the fields we did bother to look for firewood to cook afterwards. We were simply turning on biogas.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What is your opinion of biogas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Biogas was good to our lives as it was helping us a lot in terms of cooking. And we still want that type of cooking, so we would really appreciate it if they could give us a solar panels this time. So, that's our wish.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You are talking highly of Biogas, but you seem you want solar panels more than biogas, why don't you want to keep using Biogas?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Like I said, we had challenges in finding cow manure. Also, nowadays everything is about money, so you can't go about asking for manure, people would obviously charge money, maybe K500 a bucket. So, that's why we want solar technology because you can't pay for the sun. Whom would you pay for the sun? (Laughs)

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You have answered my next question, but I will still ask you maybe to confirm you answer and maybe you can add something on it. If you could have chosen your own energy or waste intervention, what would you have chosen instead?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: You can only ask you for electricity. I can\'t ask you for anything else, for example, water tap because if I ask for that it wouldn't reach me first, but the chief. But, if it's electricity, it will reach out to a lot of people and not just the chiefs.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Then how were you able to get biogas? Why didn't it go to the chief the first?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It\'s because it needs a lot of effort, you can't just say I'll get it, it needs commitment to make it work. And lucky enough that time my husband was very active and hard working.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: To cook on electricity you need money. Can you manage?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The government could see how best it would help us.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You want the government to do bring electricity and electric stoves as well?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: (laughs) they would need to bring both for sure.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Then, let's just go for solar panels, maybe. Why do you exact want a solar technology?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I'm choosing a solar panel because it's cheaper than electricity. Electricity is expensive; you need to pay bill and all that. So, I think a solar technology is better than electricity.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: That was my last question. Before I go, what are your last words?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: If the project implementers are still around and you communicate with them, ask them to take \[name redacted\] for training -- we want development here.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Noted. Thanks for the interview \[name redacted\].
interviewee: NA

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where did the digester originate from?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I simply saw \[name redacted\] coming here to ask me if I was interested to own a digester. I told him I would like to own it, and I told my boys about it and they said if the digester was going to help us cook then we should go for it. Then we started sourcing manure and bricks, and if I'm not mistaken, I spent about K25000 on that. Then after that, I was buyingcow manure every day to feed the digester, so I was spending about K300 a day because I had no cows that time. So, I can say we spent a lot of money on feedstock and on trying toline the hole, but I only used it even to cook side dish of fish \[20 minutes\] -- And, I couldn't even boil water for bathing after (laughs) -- It was even failing to heat up water, imagine (laughs).

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Not even water?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, then, we went to the person who brought it here, \[name redacted\] to tell him that they had given us a thing that wasn't working. Then, he was like the digester at his house wasn't working as well. Then, I asked another beneficiary too, and they also told me that the digester wasn't working at their house as well. I asked another beneficiary, and I was told the same thing too (laughs)\[interrupted by a visitor\]

interviewer: **Interviewer**: And you asked another beneficiary and you were told the same thing?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, then I kept on trying to the point that I realized that if I continued I would lose more money on buying cow manure than I had already lost. Then, I abandoned it, and it didn't even last for 4 months. But, I have to say I lost a lot of money on a thing that didn't work. From there I have received 3 groups of people to enquire about the digester. Then, last group came a year ago, and I told them openly that I had failed and the thing didn't help me at all. Then, they took pictures just like you have done and they went.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, did \[name redacted\] tell you that the digesters came from the government or from a non-governmental organization?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Mm-hmm, let me say I didn't ask. So, I don\'t know whether it came from the government or NGO -- that I don't know!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many people from the installation company came to install this?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was a lot of people because they came in a car. I think here, they dropped 2 people to do the installation and the others proceeded to other sites to install the digesters.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What did they do? And, what did you do?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were responsible for digging the hole. I hired 2 people to do the job, and I paid them K5000. On top of this I paid, K20000 for the bricks to line it with a brick wall around it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, you lined it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We wanted to and we spent a lot of money on the whole thing. The figure may sound small now, but it was a lot of money then. And, if we had jotted everything down, you would have seen that it was a lot of money.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, I see. Did you buy cement to line it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, I would have used mud as mortar.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How long did it take you to dug the hole and build it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Because we wanted the digesters so bad, we did everything, as we were told and as fast as we could. I think it took some weeks, and everything from digging to commissioning took about a month.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: In this community, we have a lot of households and a lot of people too. How were you chosen as a beneficiary?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I can say it was God; when something comes unexpectedly and you are selected, you should only be thankful to God. I mean, I didn\'t know anything about it; I only became aware of it when they came to say they wanted to install it here, if I was interested. So, I was very excited about it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, \[name redacted\] came to you just like I've come to you...
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, he only asked me if I was interested and willing to get it. So, when I saw that I could use it for cooking, I became so interested and I hired someone to help me because I couldn't have done the work on my own. My boy was skeptical about it, but they installers and other people said it was an easyway of cooking, so I was convinced and decided to take it. So, my boy when it didn't work was like I told you, and I have lost a lot of money for you to build it. Simply put, I was chosen by God to have it.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You have said you couldn't have managed it on your own so you asked other people to help, why did you feel that way? Or, where did you see that you could not manage?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was because I had no bricks; I felt that I couldn't have managed to dig the hole too. Also, people were not giving me manure for free, so I had to buy to startit. On top of this, I had to buy manure everyday for regular feeding, and it was not practical. A bag of cow manure, if I'm not mistaken, was K150. So to buy 4 or 10 bags of manure, it was a lot of money.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did you know about biogas before?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, I didn't know anything about it. And, even today, I even have troubles in pronouncing the word "biogas" (laughs)

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) really?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, so I just say a "cooking device".

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So \[name redacted\] and his friends came here to see if you would be interested in the digester and you accepted it. You had the right to deny it, why did you accept it to be built here?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I accepted it because the stove was designed to stay inside the house, so I thought it was safe from thieves and also I could use it easy since it was within. It would have been a good thing if it had continued, because I like the intensity of its fire. It was taking little time to get water boiled.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Do you think the digester came here without consulting the chiefs?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: There was no way it could have come to the community without consulting the chiefs.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you think \[name redacted\] and the installers liaised with the chiefs before it came here.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah! Because I have never went to the chief or attended any community meeting regarding biogas.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were your expectations?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I expected the digested to give my family some kind of peace and rest.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What do you mean?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: By simply going to the kitchen to cook and then serve food, that's peace! It was strange and surprising to see food being cooked without searching and using firewood. And, many people were coming to the kitchen to see how I was able to cook nsima without firewood. Many people desired it a lot, and many people wanted to have it as well. But, once I started complaining, all the people lost interest.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Can you estimate, how many people came and were interested in owning the digester?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was a lot, my brother.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Like 10, 50?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Maybe 20 people and most of them were men who wanted to adopt the technology in their houses. Many strangers were coming too, and some of them were people we had never seen before. And, the installers advised me to call them whenever someone was interested in the digester. But, I didn't call them, because the digester wasn't helping me.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What were you told to expect by the installers?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They told me that I would be able to warm water for bathing, cook nsima, and everything else that needs cooking. But, I was not able to do any of the things that they mentioned.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did they tell you that you could use the digestate as fertilizer.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Fertilizer? No!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: They were supposed to tell you that it produced slurry at the outlet that can be used as fertilizer. What about using it for lighting?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We asked about lighting and one of the people left us his number to make that arrangement with other people to bring solar panels. We have tried to communicate with him, but nothing has happened.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: But, you can also use the digester for lighting if you make certain arrangements.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Oooh, they didn't tell us that.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Maybe if it had work properly, then they would have told you about that. What kind of training did you receive?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Hmm, no.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: If you were not trained, then how were you able to switch it on and off?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They just showed us the button for switching it on and off.That was all I learnt.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: And maybe how to make feedstock?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, they told us how to make feedstock and they also told us to make sure that there was no lumps and trash in the feedstock to prevent blockages.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How prepared to run or operate the digester did you feel you were after they told you how to turn it on and maybe have to make feedstock?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I just feel like they made us work and spend our money for nothing. They made us handle cow manure without any benefit. I mean, when you're doing something you expect to gain something, but on this one we gained nothing after all the hard work... We spent money for nothing!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did the people react when they saw that your digester was not working?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It's only a few people who are happy when somebody is blessed with something. Most people like to see people on the same level as them or below. People don't like to see people doing better than them. So when we failed people were happy and started demeaning us in their talk. People can talk when you fail my brother, my brother.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Yeah, people talk. How did you meet your energy needs before the intervention?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I was buying charcoal and sometimes I was cutting the bluegum trees around.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You don't go to the mountains? You just use the trees around?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The mountain is protected, so it's hard to get firewood there. So, we just use bluegum trees around. That's why I say it was ablessing to get a digester.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much was a bag of charcoal then?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: That time a bag of charcoal was cheap; a bag of charcoal was going at K1500 or K1000. Now seeing that there are no trees in the mountains they charge K5000. However, energy for cooking is not a problem around these months (after harvesting) because we use maize stalks and cobs. I only have that log of firewood there, because we had wedding ceremony and food preparation was done here, so it was left there. But, around this time, people only use maize cobs and stalks.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many bags of charcoal do you use in a month?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: To be honestly with you, I rarely use charcoal because of the bluegum trees around.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: I can see that you have a lot of bluegum trees, how did you manage to get all these bluegum trees?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We got a lot of tree siblings from the agriculture extension office. I think it was a government program to encourage people to plant trees.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You have said that time you had no cows....
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, we used to buy there, and also from another place.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: That's not far. That's like 200 or 400 meters. What about the other place?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, this was close and a lot of people liked this place because it was cheap. The other place was far and when you went there, you couldn\'t find a person because people thought they were charging a lot more. Here they were charging K150, and the other place was charging K200.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Why were people going after the manure?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: There was also another beneficiary that side who used to come to buy manure too for their digester. And, the other people were coming to buy manure for fertilizer purposes.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You mean the \[name redacted\] family?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, they were also beneficiaries. That time a lot of people were approached but ended up denying it because they thought it was involving, and that they couldn't manage to source manure. So, beneficiaries were chosen from each village, and in this village, I was the only one who was chosen.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: You had no livestock, why do you think you were chosen?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Honestly, I don't know why I was chosen.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, let's talk about how it worked. But before that, how much feedstock did you start it up with?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We were told to charge it with 10 barrels of feedstock. That's we got 10 barrels of cow manure, add water and mix to have suitable slurry.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So those 10 barrels was it just cow manure or cow manure with water.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We started feeding it with 2 barrels of pure water. And, that's when we started mixing 10barrels of cow manure with water to make suitable slurry.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much water did you add to the 10 barrels of water?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I can't really say because we weren't counting. But, it was a lot of water too because the bag was very huge.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Where did you used to get water that time?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: We have a borehole in this community. It's somewhere there, close to the chief's house (500 meters).

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What type of barrels are you talking about?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I'm not talking about the plastic drums but the metallic ones.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many 20 liter buckets goes into that?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: 6 buckets.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, that's like 120 liters per barrel. Oh, that must have been some work.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, it was a lot of work, and flies were over the place as we made feedstock.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So they instructed you to make feedstock?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah, and it was the installers who started preparing the feedstock. They made feedstock out of one barrel, and then we hired workers to make feedstock from the remaining 9 barrels of cow manure.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many people did you hire to make the feedstock?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I hired two people.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much did you pay them?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I have forgotten how much exactly I paid them to make feedstock. But, all I can remember is that they were tough. They said they couldn't handle cow manure for little money (laughs). So, I paid a lot of money on that!

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How long did it take to start up?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I believe it started producing fire after two weeks from the day we fed it with the first charge.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did they come to commission it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Before commissioning, I have to say they were coming time and again. But, after commissioning, they stopped coming.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did it work after commission? Let's look at the first day.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Oh, it produced a very strong fire, and it was a joy to watch. And, at some point, it started producing little fire. The installers came and they saw that as well.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did they see that?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Four or five people came this other day to follow it up and I told them it was not taking long for the fire to die. Then, we went to the kitchen to see it. Afterwards, they asked me to put a pot of water and they turned it on. Then, the fire died before the water boiled. So, they went to the digester bag and started writing on a piece of paper. When they were going to the digester bag, I thought they would fix it, but I just saw them writing on a paper and then they left. I believe when I told them they didn't believe me, and that's why I asked to them to go to the kitchen to see it themselves. And when they turned it on, it produced strong flames for a very short time and died.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Like how did it take?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: you wouldn't walk from this place to that place, return, and find it on. No way, it wasn't producing fire that long.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Oh, you couldn't walk for 200 meters back and forth.
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah

interviewer: **Interviewer**: After that, it was stopping completely?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Yeah.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: On the first day, were you able to cook on it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: On the first day, I was able to cook side dish of fish (10 -- 20 minutes). But, afterwards when I tried to cook porridge it didn't work (laughs)

interviewer: **Interviewer**: (laughs) What about the second day?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: After the fire dying, we had to wait for sometime for it to produce fire again. On the second day, when we tried to boil water, it went off.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So you were able to use it only once when you cooked side dish of fish?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Not once. It was twice. And, I was also able to warm water for tea for a month. It was not a lot of water, it just 2 cups of tea (3 -- 5 minutes). It was working out because the flame that was coming out once it was started was very hot.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: So, if you were able to use the digester, it was for tea making basically?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was only for tea. I never used it for cooking nsima.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How many people were staying here what time?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Since it came here, I have always stayed alone. I'm mostly alone with that boy who comes in the evening only to sleep as he stays with his mom along the road.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Okay, what were operation requirements?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They just told us that it needs manure.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: What type of manure?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: Cow manure.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you prepare the feedstock?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: First, I was getting a bucket with a wide opening. Then, I was placing manure in the bucket, add water, and then mix it. Afterwards, I was pouring the feedstock into the digester.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How did you mix it? Did you use a stick, or a mixer or hands?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They told us to break all the lumps in the feedstock, so we couldn't use a stick because it wasn't working. As a result, we used hands to make the feedstock -- I have to say I was involved in some unpleasant work.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Didn't you feel gross doing that?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was the installers who started that, so we just followed suit. I mean, if educated people who eat good food were doing that, who am I not to do? (Laughs).

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How often were you supposed to feed it, and in what quantities?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: They told us to feed it everyday with 2 bags (50kg) of cow manure.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How much water?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: The water was just for making suitable slurry. So we didn't have a standard, and we were counting the quantity of the water; apart from that water, we weren't adding any other water.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Roughly, how much water were you adding to a 20-liter bucket of cow manure or to one bag?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I can't know. We were just adding water to have suitable feedstock.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Who was responsible for feeding it? Were you solely responsible?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: I was solely responsible.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: How would you describe the task of feeding it?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: It was hard because it was done every day. I mean, it couldn't produce fire, if it was not fed. Also, you need to feed it first before doing anything, because if you feed it later in the day, you couldn't give it time to produce gas. So, that also was a challenge. But, I feel like if it was working okay, we could have gotten used to all that and we wouldn't have complained too.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: In your opinion, how often should it be fed to be fair on the user?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: If they had said that it needs to be fed once or twice a week with 3 bags (50 liters) of cow manure, then it would have been fair. It was tall order to ask someone to feed it everyday.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Did it meet your needs?
interviewee: **Interviewee**: No, like I've said I was not able to cook nsima on it, I was only able to boil water for tea.

interviewer: **Interviewer**: Sure. What were the challenges?
